questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a recent history of acute myocardial infarction is being monitored for inflammatory markers to assess the resolution of inflammation. The patient’s C-reactive protein (CRP) levels were elevated immediately post-infarction and are now being rechecked daily. Understanding CRP kinetics is important in interpreting these results. What is the half-life of CRP?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 18 hours

 

  • The half-life of C-reactive protein (CRP) is approximately 18 hours. CRP is an acute-phase reactant produced by the liver in response to inflammation. 
  • Once the stimulus (such as infection or inflammation) is removed, CRP levels decrease with a half-life of around 18 hours, reflecting the clearance of CRP from the circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of C-reactive protein (CRP) is approximately 18 hours, making it a reliable marker to monitor the progression or resolution of inflammation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and signs of liver dysfunction. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and mild hyperbilirubinemia. A detailed metabolic panel suggests an issue with amino acid metabolism. Given these findings, which enzyme activity that requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transamination

 

  • Transamination reactions are critical processes in amino acid metabolism, involving the transfer of amino groups between amino acids and α-keto acids. 
  • These reactions require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6, as a coenzyme. Enzymes involved in transamination (known as transaminases or aminotransferases, such as ALT and AST) are abundant in the liver, and deficiencies in PLP or issues in transaminase function can lead to elevated liver enzymes and impaired amino acid metabolism. 
  • The elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels in this patient are indicative of liver dysfunction, which often involves impaired transamination processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxidative decarboxylation: Oxidative decarboxylation reactions, such as those carried out by the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, typically require coenzymes like thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) but not pyridoxal phosphate (PLP). This process does not primarily involve amino acid metabolism, making it an unlikely explanation for this patient’s symptoms.

 

Option C. Carboxylation: Carboxylation reactions (e.g., in gluconeogenesis and lipid synthesis) commonly require biotin as a cofactor rather than pyridoxal phosphate (PLP). These reactions are unrelated to amino acid transamination, so they are not relevant to this patient's impaired amino acid metabolism.

 

Option D. Dehydrogenation: Dehydrogenation reactions, which involve the removal of hydrogen atoms, typically require NAD+ or FAD as electron acceptors, but they do not require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP). This type of reaction is not primarily involved in amino acid metabolism or associated with liver enzyme elevation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transamination reactions, which require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme, are essential for amino acid metabolism and are particularly active in the liver. 
  • Deficiency in these reactions can lead to elevated liver enzymes and impaired amino acid metabolism, as seen in liver dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with Parkinson’s disease presents to the clinic with concerns about recent behavioral changes. He reports an uncontrollable urge to gamble, which has led to significant financial losses. He also mentions increased impulsivity, such as binge eating and excessive shopping, over the past few months. He has been on a stable medication regimen, including a drug prescribed to manage his motor symptoms.

Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pramipexole

 

Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist commonly used in Parkinson’s disease to stimulate dopamine receptors and improve motor symptoms. However, dopamine agonists are associated with impulse control disorders (ICDs), including:

 

  • Pathological gambling
  • Hypersexuality
  • Binge eating
  • Compulsive shopping

 

ICDs are more common in patients on dopamine agonists than those on levodopa. These behaviors often resolve after dose reduction or discontinuation of the medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levodopa/carbidopa: While levodopa can cause dyskinesias and other motor complications, it is less commonly associated with impulse control disorders compared to dopamine agonists.

 

Option C. Selegiline: Selegiline, a monoamine oxidase-B inhibitor, can enhance dopaminergic activity but rarely causes ICDs.

 

Option D. Amantadine: Amantadine is used for dyskinesia and has a different side effect profile, including hallucinations and livedo reticularis, but it is not typically associated with ICDs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine agonists like pramipexole and ropinirole are effective for managing motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease but carry a significant risk of impulse control disorders, necessitating careful monitoring and patient education.

choices.text: Transcription of nuclear factor mediated by NF-κB, which recruits cytokines

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms describes how Toll-like receptors (TLRs) recognize bacterial components and stimulate an immune response?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transcription of nuclear factor mediated by NF-κB, which recruits cytokines

 

  • Toll-like receptors (TLRs) play a crucial role in the innate immune response by recognizing pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), which are commonly found in microbial components such as bacterial lipopolysaccharides and flagellin. 
  • Upon recognizing these PAMPs, TLRs activate a signaling cascade that leads to the activation of the NF-κB (nuclear factor kappa-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells) pathway. 
  • NF-κB is a transcription factor that promotes the transcription of genes involved in the production of various pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. 
  • These cytokines are essential for recruiting and activating additional immune cells to the site of infection, thus mounting an effective immune response against the invading pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caspase activation and apoptosis: Incorrect. Caspase activation and apoptosis are involved in programmed cell death and immune regulation but are not mechanisms directly related to TLR signaling or NF-κB activation in response to bacterial products.

 

Option B. FADD ligand apoptosis: Incorrect. Fas-associated protein with death domain (FADD) is involved in apoptosis triggered by death receptors, such as Fas and TNF receptors, which is not related to TLR function or NF-κB activation.

 

Option D. JAK-STAT pathway activation: Incorrect. The JAK-STAT pathway is involved in cytokine signaling, primarily for cell growth and differentiation, but not directly involved in TLR activation or the NF-κB pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toll-like receptors (TLRs) activate the NF-κB pathway upon recognizing pathogen-associated molecules, leading to the transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines essential for the immune response.
  • TLRs are pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) located on immune cells like macrophages, dendritic cells, and neutrophils. Their primary role is to detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) found on microbes (but not host cells).
  • Examples of TLRs and their ligands:
    • TLR4 → Recognizes LPS from Gram-negative bacteria
    • TLR2 → Recognizes lipoteichoic acid (Gram-positive bacteria)
    • TLR5 → Recognizes flagellin
    • TLR9 → Recognizes unmethylated CpG DNA
    • TLR3 → Recognizes double-stranded RNA (viral infections)

 

Other immune effector molecules

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered an effective method for emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Danazol

 

  • Danazol, is not used for emergency contraception. Danazol is an androgenic medication primarily used for the management of endometriosis, fibrocystic breast disease, and hereditary angioedema, but it does not have any role in post-coital emergency contraception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: Known as the Yuzpe method, high-dose estrogen-progestin pills are an approved emergency contraception method and are effective if taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

 

Option B. CuT200: The Copper T 200 IUD, if inserted within 5 days post-intercourse, is highly effective for emergency contraception, making it a reliable option.

 

Option D. RU486: Also known as Mifepristone, this medication is an antiprogestin that can act as emergency contraception by delaying ovulation or preventing implantation when taken shortly after unprotected intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Danazol is not a method for emergency contraception. Instead, emergency contraception includes methods like combined high-dose estrogen-progestin pills, copper IUDs, and Mifepristone (RU486).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with dysphagia and chest pain that worsens with stress and eating. He describes the sensation as food getting stuck in his chest. The physician suspects a motility disorder and orders an investigation to confirm the diagnosis. Identify the investigation based on the image provided:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal manometry

 

  • The image provided is characteristic of esophageal manometry, which measures the pressure and the pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. 
  • This test is crucial for diagnosing motility disorders like achalasia and diffuse esophageal spasm, which can cause dysphagia and chest pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24-hour pH study: This test is used to measure acid exposure in the esophagus and is typically used to diagnose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not motility disorders.

 

Option C. Trans-esophageal ECHO: This is an ultrasound test used to get detailed images of the heart and is not related to diagnosing esophageal motility disorders.

 

Option D. Virtual esophagoscopy: This is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize the esophagus, but it does not measure muscle contractions or pressure within the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Esophageal manometry is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing esophageal motility disorders such as achalasia and diffuse esophageal spasm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of Wegener’s granulomatosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Involves large vessels

 

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis, also known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), is a small-to-medium vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomatous inflammation, typically affecting the respiratory tract and kidneys.
  • GPA typically affects small to medium-sized vessels, not large vessels. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granuloma formation in respiratory tract: This statement is correct. Granulomatous inflammation in the respiratory tract is a hallmark of GPA and can lead to symptoms such as chronic sinusitis and nasal crusting.

 

Option B. Crescentic glomerulonephritis: This is correct. GPA often involves the kidneys, causing crescentic glomerulonephritis, a rapidly progressive condition associated with hematuria and proteinuria.

 

Option C. High association with c-ANCA: Correct. c-ANCA positivity is a well-known serological marker for GPA, aiding in its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener’s) is a small-to-medium vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas, crescentic glomerulonephritis, and association with c-ANCA. 
  • It does not typically involve large vessels, distinguishing it from Vasculitis that affect larger vessels.

questions.text: A 40-year-old gardener presents with multiple nodular lesions on his forearm that started at the site of a thorn prick and have spread along the lymphatic channels in an ascending pattern. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this pattern of cutaneous lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix

 

  • The clinical presentation is characteristic of a sporotrichoid pattern, where nodular lesions spread along lymphatic channels. 
  • This pattern is commonly associated with Sporothrix schenckii, a fungus found in soil and plant material that can infect individuals through skin breaks, particularly after activities like gardening. 
  • The infection typically begins as a nodular lesion at the site of inoculation (e.g., thorn prick) and subsequently spreads along the lymphatics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nocardia: Although Nocardia can cause cutaneous infections, it more commonly leads to non-lymphatic spread or abscess formation, not a classic sporotrichoid pattern.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: This bacterium is a common cause of skin infections but typically presents with localized abscesses or cellulitis rather than lymphatic spread.

 

Option D. Actinomyces: Actinomyces causes chronic infections characterized by draining sinuses and sulfur granules but does not typically show a sporotrichoid spread pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sporotrichoid pattern, where lesions spread along lymphatic channels, is a hallmark of infection by Sporothrix schenckii, particularly in individuals with recent exposure to soil or plant material.

questions.text: A patient who was recently started on haloperidol presents with fever, confusion, muscle rigidity, and autonomic instability. Labs show elevated CPK (1500 U/L), leukocytosis (15,000/μL), and elevated liver enzymes. His temperature is 39.5°C. Which combination of treatments would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dantrolene + supportive care + stop haloperidol

 

  • The presentation of fever, confusion, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, and elevated CPK in a patient recently started on haloperidol is highly suggestive of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS), a potentially life-threatening reaction to antipsychotic medication. 
  • Prompt cessation of the antipsychotic and supportive care are essential, and medications such as dantrolene or bromocriptine are used to manage symptoms. 
  • Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that helps reduce rigidity and hyperthermia, while stopping haloperidol and providing supportive care addresses the underlying cause and symptom relief of NMS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bromocriptine + supportive care: Bromocriptine alone is generally insufficient without haloperidol cessation.

 

Option C. Supportive care + stop haloperidol: This is crucial but may not be sufficient alone in severe cases of NMS with marked rigidity and high fever. Additional pharmacological intervention, such as dantrolene, is often needed to control symptoms effectively.

 

Option D. Switch to clozapine + supportive care: Switching to clozapine is inappropriate here, as antipsychotics should be discontinued immediately in NMS. Clozapine is also not indicated for acute management of NMS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) is a serious reaction associated with antipsychotic use, characterized by fever, rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic dysfunction. 
  • Treatment includes discontinuing the antipsychotic medication, providing supportive care, and considering the use of a medication like dantrolene, dopamine agonists such as amantadine and bromocriptine to address the dopamine dysregulation associated with NMS.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is developed from the paraxial mesoderm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skeletal muscles

 

  • The paraxial mesoderm is a key germ layer in embryonic development that specifically contributes to the formation of skeletal muscles. 
  • This mesoderm segment organizes into structures called somites, which further differentiate into various tissues, including the skeletal muscles that control voluntary movements throughout the body.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal peritoneum: Incorrect. The parietal peritoneum is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the paraxial mesoderm. The lateral plate mesoderm forms the somatic mesoderm, which contributes to the body’s cavities’ lining, including the parietal peritoneum.

 

Option B. Peritoneal cavity: Incorrect. The peritoneal cavity itself is not formed from any mesoderm but is a space located between the parietal and visceral peritoneum. It essentially represents a cavity within the body and does not arise from germ layer differentiation.

 

Option C. Visceral peritoneum: Incorrect. Like the parietal peritoneum, the visceral peritoneum is developed from the splanchnic mesoderm portion of the lateral plate mesoderm, which lines the external surfaces of the internal organs, not the paraxial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paraxial mesoderm plays a crucial role in developing skeletal muscles.

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is correct regarding the components of the NRP (Neonatal Resuscitation Program) protocol?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The preferred chest compression to ventilation ratio is 3:1

 

  • In neonatal resuscitation, the chest compression to ventilation ratio is 3:1. 
  • This ratio is specific to neonates to ensure adequate ventilation in addition to circulation, with 90 compressions and 30 ventilations per minute if the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temperature should be maintained between 37.0°C and 38.0°C: Temperature should be maintained between 36.5°C and 37.5°C in neonates to prevent hypothermia, which can worsen outcomes in newborns. A temperature range of 37.0°C to 38.0°C is outside the recommended range.

 

Option C. The "head tilt-chin lift" position is recommended for airway management: For airway management in neonates, the "sniffing" position is recommended to help open the airway by aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes. 

 

Option D. Epinephrine should be administered with a compression rate of 60:30 (compression to ventilation ratio): Epinephrine can be administered during neonatal resuscitation if heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation and chest compressions. However, the correct compression to ventilation ratio is 3:1, not 60:30.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In neonatal resuscitation, the NRP protocol includes specific guidelines for temperature control (36.5°C to 37.5°C), airway management using the sniffing position, a 3:1 compression to ventilation ratio, and the use of drugs such as epinephrine when necessary.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 5-day history of a spreading rash. She reports that it began as a small red spot on her thigh that has expanded progressively and now measures approximately 15 cm in diameter. The lesion is not painful but feels warm to the touch. On examination, you observe a target-like lesion as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema migrans

 

Erythema migrans is a characteristic rash seen in Lyme disease, an infection caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, which is transmitted by tick bites. This rash typically appears within 3-30 days of the tick bite, beginning as a small red spot that gradually expands in a circular or target-like pattern. The lesion can reach sizes of 5-30 cm or more and is usually warm to the touch but not painful. The expanding nature of the rash without pain or itching, combined with its target-like appearance, strongly suggests erythema migrans, especially if the patient has a history of potential tick exposure in endemic areas.

 

Erythema migrans is often diagnosed clinically based on its characteristic appearance, especially in regions where Lyme disease is common. Immediate recognition and diagnosis are essential, as early treatment with antibiotics can prevent further complications of Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythema annulare: Erythema annulare centrifugum is a rare condition characterized by annular (ring-shaped) red patches with a trailing edge, but it typically does not present with a central clearing or the classic "bullseye" appearance of erythema migrans.

 

Option C. Erythema marginatum: Erythema marginatum is associated with acute rheumatic fever and appears as pink rings on the trunk and proximal extremities. It is migratory, but it typically does not have a target-like appearance or a strong association with a history of tick exposure.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme: Erythema multiforme is often associated with infections or medications and presents as multiple target lesions, typically on the hands, feet, and extremities. However, the lesions of erythema multiforme are usually smaller, and patients may have systemic symptoms, which are not noted in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Erythema migrans is a hallmark rash of Lyme disease, characterized by an expanding bullseye-like appearance. It typically appears days to weeks after a tick bite and is warm but non-painful, expanding over time without systemic symptoms in early cases.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to his left flank during a street brawl. On examination, he has active bleeding from the wound site, and his urine sample shows hematuria. Based on the location of the injury, which of the following organs is least likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The left flank is the lateral area of the abdomen on the left side of the body. 
  • Injuries to this region can involve organs located near or within the left upper quadrant and retroperitoneal space. 
  • The spleen, left kidney (including the suprarenal gland), and portions of the stomach are situated in or near this region and are at higher risk of being injured from a left flank stab wound. 
  • Hematuria (blood in urine) suggests that structures related to the renal system, like the kidney or suprarenal gland, could be affected.
  • The inferior vena cava (IVC), however, is positioned more toward the midline and right side of the body, making it less likely to be injured from a left-sided flank wound.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: The spleen is located in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen and is vulnerable to injury from trauma to the left flank. A penetrating wound to this area could readily affect the spleen.

 

Option B. Left suprarenal gland: The left suprarenal (adrenal) gland sits atop the left kidney and is situated in the retroperitoneal space near the flank region. It is at risk of injury from a left-sided stab wound.

 

Option C. Stomach: The stomach, particularly its greater curvature, extends into the upper left abdomen and can potentially be injured by a left flank wound. However, this is slightly less likely than injury to the spleen or left kidney but still more likely than the inferior vena cava.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inferior vena cava is positioned more toward the midline and the right side of the body, making it less likely to be injured in left flank trauma. 
  • In left-sided injuries, structures such as the spleen, left kidney, and stomach are at greater risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing evaluation for an autoimmune disorder. The physician explains that certain areas in the body are protected from immune system attacks due to their "immunologically privileged" status, helping to prevent inflammation and damage. Which of the following sites is considered immunologically privileged?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminiferous tubule

 

  • Immunologically privileged sites are areas of the body where immune responses are limited to prevent potential damage to delicate tissues. 
  • The seminiferous tubules in the testes are one of these sites, where the immune system's activity is suppressed to protect developing sperm cells from autoimmune attack. 
  • This privilege allows for immune tolerance within these areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Area postrema: This is an area of the brain that lacks a blood-brain barrier but is not classified as an immunologically privileged site.

 

Option C. Optic nerve: Although part of the central nervous system, the optic nerve itself is not specifically considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Option D. Loop of Henle: This structure in the kidney plays a role in urine concentration and is not involved in immune privilege.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Seminiferous tubule, spermatozoa, lens protein, placenta and the fetus are the immunologically privileged site. 
  • Brain is no longer considered immunologically privileged.

questions.text: Which hormone is primarily responsible for acting on the post-ovulatory endometrium?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progesterone

 

  • Progesterone is the primary hormone responsible for transforming the post-ovulatory endometrium into a secretory phase, which makes it suitable for implantation if fertilization occurs. 
  • After ovulation, the corpus luteum (formed from the remnants of the follicle) begins secreting progesterone. 
  • This hormone stimulates the endometrial glands to secrete nutrients and thickens the endometrium, creating an optimal environment for a fertilized egg. 
  • If pregnancy does not occur, progesterone levels fall, leading to the shedding of the endometrial lining (menstruation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Although estrogen plays a significant role in the proliferative phase (pre-ovulation) by thickening the endometrial lining, it is not the primary hormone responsible for post-ovulatory endometrial changes. Its levels decrease after ovulation as progesterone takes over in the luteal phase.

 

Option B. Luteinizing hormone (LH): LH is essential for triggering ovulation and the formation of the corpus luteum. However, it does not directly act on the endometrium post-ovulation. Its role is mainly in initiating ovulation and maintaining the corpus luteum briefly.

 

Option C. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH): FSH is crucial in the early menstrual cycle for stimulating follicle growth and estrogen production. However, it has no role in the post-ovulatory phase and does not influence the endometrial changes after ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Progesterone is the hormone responsible for converting the post-ovulatory endometrium into a secretory phase, preparing it for potential implantation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old researcher studying cell death mechanisms notes that a specific form of programmed cell death involves activation of caspase-1 and results in the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1β and IL-18. Which form of cell death is the researcher most likely observing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyroptosis

 

  • Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is distinct from apoptosis and necrosis, primarily due to its role in the inflammatory response. 
  • This process is triggered by inflammatory signals and is specifically dependent on caspase-1 activation. 
  • Activation of caspase-1 results in cleavage and activation of gasdermin D, which leads to pore formation in the cell membrane, causing cell swelling, lysis, and subsequent release of pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18.
  • Pyroptosis serves an important immune function by releasing cellular contents, including cytokines, that help recruit and activate immune cells to fight infections. 
  • This process is especially critical in response to intracellular pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrosis: Incorrect. Necrosis is a form of accidental cell death often due to injury or trauma, leading to cell swelling, rupture, and inflammation. It is not a programmed process and does not involve caspase-1 or controlled cytokine release.

 

Option B. Apoptosis: Incorrect. Apoptosis is a caspase-dependent, programmed form of cell death that does not involve inflammation. Unlike pyroptosis, apoptosis is characterized by caspase-3, -6, and -7 activation, cellular shrinkage, and DNA fragmentation, without IL-1β and IL-18 release.

 

Option D. Autophagy: Incorrect. Autophagy is a cellular process that recycles damaged cellular components to maintain cellular homeostasis. While it is a form of programmed cell survival under stress, it does not involve caspase-1 or release pro-inflammatory cytokines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pyroptosis is a caspase-1-dependent form of programmed cell death that releases pro-inflammatory cytokines, specifically IL-1β and IL-18, to promote an immune response. 
  • It is distinct from other forms of cell death, such as apoptosis, necrosis, and autophagy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, who had recently recovered from tetanus without any residual symptoms, dies in a road traffic accident on his way home. His body remains at the accident site under a high ambient temperature of 40°C for around 6 hours before being taken to the morgue. At the morgue, his rectal temperature is noted to be 39°C. What is the most probable reason for the elevated body temperature postmortem?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High ambient temperature slowing the body's cooling process

 

  • The elevated ambient temperature (40°C) surrounding the body delays the normal postmortem cooling process, leading to a higher body temperature even 6 hours after death. 
  • When environmental temperatures are high, the body’s natural heat dissipation is slowed, causing an elevated postmortem temperature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Residual neuromuscular excitation from tetanus, causing elevated temperature after death: This is incorrect because the patient had fully recovered from tetanus, so there would be no residual neuromuscular activity influencing body temperature.

 

Option C. Muscle contractions after death due to previous tetanus infection: This is misleading; tetanus does not induce muscle contractions postmortem, so it would not contribute to heat generation after death.

 

Option D. Rapid decomposition due to prior tetanus infection: Decomposition is influenced by environmental factors but would not begin significantly faster due to a prior tetanus infection, especially within a few hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Postmortem body temperature is significantly influenced by ambient conditions. 
  • When a body is exposed to high environmental temperatures, cooling is delayed, which can result in an elevated temperature several hours after death.

questions.text: A person is able to abduct his arm, internally rotate it, place the back of hand on lumbosacral joint, but is not able to lift it from back. What is etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subscapularis tendon tear

 

  • The subscapularis is the largest and most powerful muscle of the rotator cuff, located on the anterior (front) part of the scapula. It is responsible for internal rotation of the humerus (upper arm) and plays a role in adduction and extension of the arm.
  • A tear in the subscapularis tendon affects the ability to internally rotate the arm and lift it behind the back. This tendon is crucial for the internal rotation of the shoulder and for bringing the hand behind the back, as seen in this patient’s inability to lift the arm after it is placed behind the back.
  • The test for a subscapularis tear is called the "lift-off" test. In this test, the patient is asked to place the back of their hand on their lower back and then try to lift the hand away from the back. If the tendon is torn, the patient will be unable to do so.
  • Subscapularis tear leads to weakness in internal rotation, making it difficult to lift the hand from the back. Despite the intact ability to abduct the arm and place the hand on the lower back, the person cannot lift it due to the lack of effective internal rotation and shoulder stabilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teres Major Tendon Tear:

 

  • The teres major muscle is located on the posterior (back) part of the scapula and plays a role in internal rotation, extension, and adduction of the arm, especially when the arm is in a raised position. The teres major works synergistically with the latissimus dorsi.
  • However, a tear of the teres major tendon would not typically result in an inability to lift the arm from the back after placing it there. This is because the teres major is less important for the specific movement of lifting the hand from the back compared to the subscapularis, which is responsible for internal rotation and lifting.
  • A tear of the teres major would likely affect movements like adduction and extension, especially when the arm is in a raised position. While it may affect the overall function of the shoulder, it wouldn't specifically impair the ability to lift the hand from behind the back in the way that a subscapularis tear would.

 

Option C. Long Head of Biceps Tendon Tear:

 

  • The long head of the biceps tendon originates from the scapula (specifically the supraglenoid tubercle) and attaches to the biceps muscle. While the biceps is primarily known for its role in elbow flexion, the long head of the biceps also contributes to shoulder flexion and stabilization of the shoulder joint.
  • A tear in the long head of the biceps tendon would most likely result in weakness in shoulder flexion and pain during activities involving overhead lifting. However, it would not directly impair the ability to place the hand behind the back or lift it from behind.

  • A tear of the long head of the biceps may lead to a popeye deformity (bulging of the muscle) and decreased strength in shoulder flexion, but it would not prevent the arm from being placed behind the back or lifting it in the same way as a subscapularis tendon tear.

     

Option D. Acromioclavicular (AC) Joint Dislocation:

 

  • The acromioclavicular (AC) joint is located where the acromion process of the scapula meets the clavicle. Dislocations of the AC joint, also known as shoulder separations, typically occur due to trauma (e.g., falling on the shoulder or direct impact). These injuries often lead to pain, swelling, and decreased ability to move the shoulder, especially with overhead or cross-body motions.
  • An AC joint dislocation might cause pain and limited range of motion, especially during arm elevation or when moving the arm across the body. However, it does not directly affect the specific motion of lifting the hand from behind the back after it has been placed there. The patient's ability to internally rotate and position the arm behind the back might still be intact, even in the presence of an AC joint dislocation.
  • AC joint dislocations primarily cause discomfort, swelling, and weakness in overhead motions. While there may be difficulty lifting the arm, the inability to lift the hand from the lower back as described in the scenario is more likely to be due to a rotator cuff issue, such as a subscapularis tendon tear, rather than an AC joint dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subscapularis tendon tear directly impacts the ability to internally rotate the arm and perform movements such as lifting the hand from behind the back. 
  • The subscapularis is a key player in this motion, and a tear in its tendon would result in the specific functional limitation.

questions.text: In the diagnostic evaluation of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT), both impedance plethysmography and leg scanning after injecting 125I-fibrinogen are performed simultaneously. What is the primary outcome of using these tests together?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increasing the negative predictive value

 

  • Performing impedance plethysmography and 125I-fibrinogen leg scanning simultaneously constitutes parallel testing. In parallel testing, a positive result from any test suggests the presence of the condition, while all tests must be negative to rule it out. 
  • This approach enhances sensitivity and negative predictive value, meaning a negative result is more reliable in confirming the absence of DVT. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing the positive predictive value: Parallel testing can decrease positive predictive value due to increased false positives.

 

Option C. Increasing the pretest odds: Pretest odds are determined before testing and are not directly influenced by the combination of diagnostic tests.

 

Option D. Increasing the specificity: Parallel testing may reduce specificity because a positive result in any test leads to a positive diagnosis, potentially increasing false positives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In parallel testing, combining multiple diagnostic tests increases sensitivity and negative predictive value, making a negative result more reliable in ruling out a condition like DVT.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) requires a blood sample for coagulation testing. Which anticoagulant is preferred?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3.2% Trisodium citrate

 

  • 3.2% Trisodium citrate is the anticoagulant of choice for coagulation testing because it works by binding calcium ions, which are essential for the clotting process. 
  • By sequestering calcium, trisodium citrate effectively prevents blood clotting, allowing for accurate measurement of clotting times, such as prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). 
  • The citrate concentration is critical, as 3.2% is preferred due to its balance of efficacy in anticoagulation without significantly altering plasma volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that activates antithrombin, inhibiting thrombin and factor Xa. It is not ideal for coagulation testing because it directly interferes with clotting factors, potentially distorting test results, particularly for PT and aPTT.

 

Option B. EDTA: EDTA is commonly used in hematology for complete blood counts, as it prevents clotting by binding calcium. However, EDTA is unsuitable for coagulation studies because it can interfere with factors required in the clotting cascade.

 

Option C. Sodium oxalate: Sodium oxalate prevents clotting by precipitating calcium. However, it is not routinely used in coagulation testing as it can affect some blood components, potentially leading to inaccurate coagulation results.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For coagulation testing, 3.2% trisodium citrate is the anticoagulant of choice due to its ability to prevent clotting by chelating calcium without significantly interfering with the measurement of coagulation factors.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 36 weeks of pregnancy is found to have a fetus in a transverse lie on ultrasound. Amniotic fluid levels are within normal range, the placenta appears normal, and no fetal anomalies are identified. Her two previous deliveries were uncomplicated vaginal births. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) External cephalic version

 

  • At 36 weeks’ gestation, a fetus in a transverse lie poses challenges for a vaginal delivery, as the fetal shoulder or arm would present first, leading to obstructed labor if not corrected. 
  • The recommended management for a transverse lie at this stage of pregnancy, with no complications, is an external cephalic version (ECV). 
  • ECV is a procedure where manual pressure is applied on the mother’s abdomen to rotate the fetus to a cephalic (head-down) position, improving the chances of a vaginal delivery.

 

The eligibility for ECV in this case is supported by the following factors:

 

  • The pregnancy is at 36 weeks, an ideal time for ECV, as the fetus is mature enough to maintain a new position, and ECV is still likely to be successful.
  • There is adequate amniotic fluid, reducing the risk of complications and facilitating easier movement.
  • There are no contraindications such as placenta previa or fetal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While cesarean delivery may be required if the transverse lie persists, it is not the first-line management at 36 weeks. Attempting ECV first can avoid unnecessary cesarean sections and facilitate a vaginal birth.

 

Option B. Expectant management: Simply waiting without intervention is not advisable, as the fetus in a transverse position at 36 weeks is less likely to spontaneously turn head-down by itself. Expectant management would increase the risk of an obstructed labor if spontaneous labor occurs.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Induction is contraindicated in transverse lie, as it increases the risk of complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a fetus in a transverse lie at 36 weeks without other complications, external cephalic version (ECV) is the most appropriate intervention to attempt turning the fetus to a head-down position, potentially avoiding cesarean delivery.

questions.text: A forensic examiner is tasked with analyzing a preserved set of clothing from a 4-month-old case, with suspicion regarding the presence of seminal stains on the fabric. Considering the potential degradation of the sample due to age, which of the following biochemical tests would be the most reliable to establish the presence of semen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine phosphokinase test

 

  • The Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) test is a reliable biochemical marker for identifying seminal fluid, even in aged samples. 
  • CPK is more stable over time compared to other markers, making it a suitable test for detecting semen in samples that have been preserved for an extended period.
  • This enzyme remains present and detectable in seminal fluid stains, providing forensic examiners with a dependable tool for such analyses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acid phosphatase test: Although commonly used for fresh seminal stains, the acid phosphatase enzyme may degrade over time, reducing its reliability in older samples. In a 4-month-old sample, acid phosphatase may no longer be detectable.

 

Option B. Barbario test: The Barbario test is a classic method for detecting sperm cells; however, it may not be effective if the sample has significantly degraded over time. This test is also less commonly used due to its lower sensitivity compared to modern biochemical tests.

 

Option C. Florence test: The Florence test is used for detecting choline crystals, a component of semen, but its sensitivity decreases as the sample ages. This test may not yield reliable results in an older sample due to degradation of choline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For identifying aged seminal stains, the Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) test is the preferred biochemical method due to its stability and reliability in older samples.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent falls, particularly backward, stiffness while standing, and difficulty maintaining posture. He also reports mild difficulty with upward gaze but denies tremors or other significant motor issues. Neurological examination reveals axial rigidity, a wide-based gait, and impaired voluntary vertical eye movements. MRI of the brain is taken and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Progressive supranuclear palsy

 

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by:

 

  • Postural instability and backward falls: Early and frequent backward falls are a hallmark feature.
  • Vertical gaze palsy: Difficulty with voluntary vertical eye movements, especially upward gaze, is highly characteristic.
  • Axial rigidity: Stiffness that predominantly affects the trunk, unlike Parkinson’s, which often affects the limbs.
  • Hummingbird sign: Atrophy of the midbrain, leading to the appearance of a "hummingbird" on sagittal MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson’s disease: Although rigidity and postural instability can occur in Parkinson’s, patients usually fall forward rather than backward. Vertical gaze palsy and early postural instability are not typical.

 

Option C. Cerebellar degeneration: Cerebellar pathology causes ataxia and a wide-based gait, but falls are generally in multiple directions, not predominantly backward. Vertical gaze palsy is not a feature.

 

Option D. Multiple system atrophy (MSA): MSA may present with autonomic dysfunction, parkinsonism, and ataxia, but backward falls and vertical gaze palsy are not characteristic. MRI in MSA may show "hot cross bun" sign, not midbrain atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Backward falls with vertical gaze palsy and axial rigidity strongly suggest progressive supranuclear palsy. Early imaging (e.g., hummingbird sign on MRI) helps differentiate PSP from other neurodegenerative disorders.

choices.text: Both statements are true, and the reason explains the assertion.
Both statements are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.
Assertion is true, but the reason is false.
Assertion is false, but the reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion and Reason

 

Assertion (A): ‘Second sight’ is seen in cases of cortical cataract.

 

Reason (R): Change in the refractive index of the nucleus causes index myopia, improving near vision.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assertion is false, but the reason is true.

 

  • "Second sight" or the temporary improvement in near vision is typically seen in nuclear cataracts, not cortical cataracts. 
  • This occurs due to an increase in the refractive index of the nucleus, which causes a shift towards myopia and enhances near vision. Therefore:
  • Assertion is incorrect because "Second sight" is not associated with cortical cataracts.
  • Reason is correct, as the change in the refractive index of the nucleus in nuclear cataracts can lead to index myopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "Second sight" is associated with nuclear cataracts due to a myopic shift from changes in the refractive index of the nucleus, not cortical cataracts.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman experiences recurrent sharp lower abdominal pain lasting for 2–3 days each month, typically occurring about 14 days before her menstrual period. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mittelschmerz

 

  • Mittelschmerz, is a term that refers to the mild to moderate, often sharp or crampy pain some women experience during ovulation, which occurs around the midpoint of the menstrual cycle (approximately 14 days before the onset of menses in a typical 28-day cycle). 
  • This pain typically lasts for a few hours to a few days and is associated with ovulatory activity. 
  • The recurring nature of the pain around ovulation supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysmenorrhea: This refers to painful menstruation and is characterized by crampy pain that occurs just before or during menses, not two weeks prior. Dysmenorrhea does not fit the timing of this patient’s symptoms.

 

Option C. Endometriosis: Endometriosis commonly causes chronic pelvic pain, which often worsens during menstruation and can be associated with infertility and pain during intercourse. However, it is unlikely to cause pain specifically and consistently around the time of ovulation as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Pelvic tuberculosis: Pelvic tuberculosis is a chronic condition that can present with pelvic pain, irregular menstrual cycles, and sometimes systemic symptoms such as fever and weight loss. It would not typically present as a recurrent pain occurring at a specific time each cycle without other symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mittelschmerz, or mid-cycle ovulatory pain, should be suspected in women with recurrent sharp or crampy lower abdominal pain occurring approximately 14 days before menses. 
  • This pain is typically short-lived and associated with the ovulation phase of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of hearing loss and tinnitus. She reports a recent increase in her symptoms, and MRI reveals bilateral masses at the cerebellopontine angle. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen from one of the masses as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this type of tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Malignancy is common

 

  • The tumor described in this question is a schwannoma, specifically an acoustic (vestibular) schwannoma, which typically arises from the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII). 
  • Schwannomas are benign nerve sheath tumors that can present bilaterally in association with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2), a genetic disorder linked to mutations on chromosome 22. 
  • Verocay bodies, which are palisading arrangements of nuclei with intervening acellular areas, are characteristic histopathological features of schwannomas.

 

 

  • Schwannomas are almost exclusively benign and have a very low risk of malignant transformation, which makes option D ("Malignancy is common") the incorrect statement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It originates from cranial nerves: This is correct. Schwannomas often originate from cranial nerves, most commonly the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII).

 

Option B. Verocay bodies are seen: This is also correct. Verocay bodies are a hallmark histopathological feature of schwannomas, with characteristic nuclear palisading and alternating cellular and acellular zones.

 

Option C. It is associated with neurofibromatosis: Correct. Bilateral acoustic schwannomas are strongly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2), which is characterized by the presence of these tumors along with other central nervous system tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schwannomas are benign tumors of the nerve sheath, commonly associated with cranial nerves, especially cranial nerve VIII. 
  • They are frequently benign and may be associated with NF2, particularly when bilateral. The presence of Verocay bodies is a characteristic histological feature, and malignancy is rare.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with an ovarian mass identified on ultrasound. Histological examination reveals an adenofibroma of the ovary with nests of transitional cells in the epithelial component. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brenner tumor

 

  • Brenner tumors are uncommon ovarian neoplasms that are typically benign and characterized by their adenofibromatous stroma with nests of transitional (urothelial-like) cells. 
  • The presence of transitional cell-like epithelium is a hallmark of Brenner tumors, distinguishing them from other ovarian neoplasms. 
  • These tumors are generally solid and well-circumscribed and may contain calcifications. 
  • They are usually asymptomatic, but larger tumors can present with abdominal discomfort or bloating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulosa cell tumor: Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors that are typically estrogen-secreting and may cause symptoms related to hormonal changes. They do not contain nests of transitional cells, which are specific to Brenner tumors.

 

Option B. Serous cystadenoma: Serous cystadenomas are common benign epithelial tumors of the ovary but are characterized by a cystic structure lined with serous epithelium rather than transitional cells. Unlike Brenner tumors, serous cystadenomas do not contain nests of transitional cells.

 

Option D. Thecoma: Thecomas are also sex cord-stromal tumors that may produce estrogen. They consist of lipid-laden stromal cells but lack the transitional cell nests characteristic of Brenner tumors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Brenner tumors of the ovary are adenofibromas with a distinctive epithelial component comprising nests of transitional (urothelial-like) cells. 
  • This feature is essential for differentiating Brenner tumors from other ovarian neoplasms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a blunt trauma to the perineal region sustained while straddling a bicycle. He is experiencing swelling and bruising in the perineum and scrotum, and physical examination reveals blood pooling in the area. There is suspicion of a rupture of the penile urethra. In this scenario, extravasation of blood is least likely to extend into which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischiorectal fossa

 

  • Rupture of the penile urethra, particularly in the bulbar region, commonly results in the extravasation of blood and urine into the superficial perineal pouch. 
  • This can extend into surrounding structures such as the scrotum, perineum, and even the anterior abdominal wall if the injury is severe enough. 
  • However, the ischiorectal fossa, which is located laterally and posteriorly to the perineal region, is typically not involved because it is separated by the perineal membrane and fascial layers. 
  • As a result, blood does not usually extend into the ischiorectal fossa in cases of penile urethral rupture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin around the scrotum: The superficial perineal pouch is continuous with the subcutaneous tissue of the scrotum. In cases of penile urethral rupture, extravasation of blood commonly extends into the skin around the scrotum. 

 

Option C. Superficial perineal pouch: Blood and urine from a ruptured penile urethra primarily accumulate in the superficial perineal pouch, as the urethra lies within this space. 

 

Option D. Deep perineal pouch: While blood extravasation is more common in the superficial perineal pouch, injury to structures deep to the perineal membrane (such as in more extensive trauma) can occasionally involve the deep perineal pouch. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ischiorectal fossa is typically spared from extravasation of blood following penile urethral rupture due to its separation by fascial layers and the perineal membrane.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of epilepsy is receiving valproate for seizure control. Her neurologist decides to add carbamazepine to her treatment plan to improve seizure management. After several weeks, she returns to the clinic with adverse effects. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely to increase when carbamazepine is added to valproate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatotoxicity

 

  • Hepatotoxicity is an adverse effect that becomes more likely when carbamazepine is added to valproate therapy. 
  • Valproate is metabolized in the liver, and one of its metabolites is hepatotoxic. 
  • Carbamazepine, as an enzyme inducer, increases the activity of liver enzymes involved in drug metabolism, leading to enhanced production of valproate’s hepatotoxic metabolite. 
  • This interaction raises the risk of liver injury, which may present as jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, and abdominal discomfort. 
  • Regular monitoring of liver function tests is recommended when these two medications are used together to detect early signs of hepatotoxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Although thrombocytopenia is an adverse effect associated with valproate, carbamazepine does not significantly increase this risk compared to hepatotoxicity.

 

Option C. Pancreatitis: Valproate can rarely cause pancreatitis, but adding carbamazepine does not exacerbate this risk.

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia: Valproate can cause hyperammonemia; however, carbamazepine does not increase this risk directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of valproate and carbamazepine increases the risk of hepatotoxicity due to enzyme induction by carbamazepine, leading to the formation of a hepatotoxic valproate metabolite. 
  • Close monitoring of liver function tests is essential for patients on this combination.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of weight loss, recurrent diarrhea, and painful blistering rashes that evolve into pruritic, crusty lesions and then resolve spontaneously. On physical examination, there is bronze-colored induration and scaling rash involving the perioral region, perineum, and lower extremities. Laboratory findings:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 10.1 g/dL
  • Glucose: 236 mg/dL
  • Serum glucagon: Elevated
  • Serum zinc: Low

 

Abdominal ultrasound reveals a 3-cm, solid, well-defined mass in the head of the pancreas. This patient’s tumor is most likely derived from which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancreatic α-cells

 

This patient’s presentation is indicative of glucagonoma, a neuroendocrine tumor of pancreatic α-cells. Key features include:

 

  • Necrolytic migratory erythema (NME): The described skin findings are pathognomonic for glucagonoma.
  • Hyperglycemia: Caused by excessive glucagon secretion, which stimulates gluconeogenesis.
  • Weight loss and diarrhea: Result from catabolic effects and glucagon's impact on gastrointestinal motility.
  • Low zinc: Often seen in glucagonoma and contributes to the pathophysiology of NME.

 

The mass in the head of the pancreas corresponds to the typical location of a glucagon-secreting tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pancreatic β-cells: Insulin-secreting tumors (insulinomas) typically present with hypoglycemia, which is not seen in this case. Additionally, insulinomas do not cause NME or elevated serum glucagon levels.

 

Option C. Pancreatic δ-cells: δ-cells produce somatostatin. Somatostatinomas can present with diabetes, gallstones, diarrhea, and steatorrhea, but they do not cause NME or elevated glucagon levels.

 

Option D. Enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells: ECL cells produce histamine, which is involved in the pathogenesis of gastrinomas (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Gastrinomas cause recurrent peptic ulcers and diarrhea due to hyperacidity but do not produce glucagon or NME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucagonoma, a tumor of pancreatic α-cells, should be considered in patients with hyperglycemia, necrolytic migratory erythema, and systemic symptoms like weight loss and diarrhea. The addition of serum glucagon and zinc levels can provide diagnostic clues for challenging cases.

The focus is on determining the sex of the individual based on the mandible. Which of the following features would most likely indicate a male mandible compared to a female mandible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

 

  • General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are applicable to most bones, hence no need to remember separately for each bone. These are

  • Texture: Male bones are more rougher due to increased muscle attachment areas.

Inhalation of gastric contents causing inflammation
Release of fibrogenic cytokines by macrophages

questions.text: A 68-year-old man underwent hemicolectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. Post-surgery, he developed respiratory distress with a significant drop in pO2 levels. Despite being intubated and receiving 100% oxygen, a chest X-ray shows diffuse opacities in all lung fields. A transbronchial lung biopsy reveals the findings shown in the image below. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Injury to alveolar capillary endothelium

 

  • The patient's clinical presentation of respiratory distress, diffuse pulmonary opacities on chest X-ray, and severe hypoxemia suggests Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is a severe inflammatory response often triggered by factors such as major surgery, trauma, or sepsis. 
  • The characteristic histological finding in ARDS is diffuse alveolar damage, including hyaline membrane formation, as seen in the biopsy image provided.
  • The primary mechanism in ARDS involves injury to the alveolar capillary endothelium, resulting in increased permeability of the alveolar-capillary barrier. 
  • This allows protein-rich fluid to leak into the alveoli, causing non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema and the formation of hyaline membranes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of coagulation pathways leading to microthrombi formation: While activation of coagulation and the formation of microthrombi can occur in critically ill patients and may worsen ARDS, it is not the direct cause of diffuse alveolar damage or hyaline membrane formation seen in ARDS. Microthrombi may exacerbate hypoxemia but are secondary to the primary injury of the alveolar-capillary barrier.

 

Option B. Inhalation of gastric contents causing inflammation: Aspiration pneumonitis occurs when gastric contents are inhaled, leading to chemical injury and inflammation. While it can lead to respiratory distress, aspiration pneumonitis typically has different histological findings (e.g., inflammation with food particles) and does not typically show the diffuse alveolar damage and hyaline membranes seen in ARDS.

 

Option D. Release of fibrogenic cytokines by macrophages: Although fibrogenic cytokines can contribute to later stages of lung injury, particularly in fibrotic conditions, they are not the primary mechanism in the acute phase of ARDS. ARDS is driven by acute alveolar-capillary damage rather than chronic fibrotic processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ARDS is primarily caused by injury to the alveolar-capillary barrier, leading to increased permeability, pulmonary edema, and hyaline membrane formation. 
  • This condition often follows major surgery or trauma and is marked by severe hypoxemia and diffuse opacities on imaging.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with complaints of pain and swelling in the perineal area, with associated difficulty in walking and sitting. She reports a history of multiple sexual partners. On physical examination, there is a tender swelling with redness on the labia. Based on the clinical presentation and image findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bartholin abscess

 

  • Bartholin abscess is a localized infection of the Bartholin gland, commonly resulting in pain, swelling, and tenderness on one side of the labia. 
  • This condition typically presents with a tender, red, fluctuant mass on the lower aspect of one of the labia, as seen in the provided image. 
  • The presence of pain and difficulty in walking or sitting are classic symptoms, as the location of the swelling can make these activities uncomfortable. 
  • The history of multiple sexual partners could increase the risk of infections that might cause gland duct blockage, leading to an abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes infection: While herpes can cause painful lesions in the genital area, it typically presents as grouped vesicles or ulcers, not as a localized, tender swelling. Herpes lesions do not usually cause a deep abscess-like mass, as observed here.

 

Option C. Genital Tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis can involve the female reproductive organs but generally does not present with acute, painful swelling in the labia. Its presentation tends to be more chronic, often with symptoms such as infertility or irregular menses rather than localized tenderness and redness in the perineal area.

 

Option D. Chlamydial infection: Chlamydia can cause cervicitis or pelvic inflammatory disease, but it typically does not lead to an abscess or a swollen, tender mass on the labia. It is more commonly associated with symptoms like abnormal vaginal discharge or dysuria rather than localized labial swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bartholin abscess should be suspected in a female patient presenting with painful, tender swelling in the perineal area, particularly if associated with redness and difficulty in walking or sitting.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not characteristic of acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal C3 complement levels

 

  • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN) is commonly observed in children following a Group A streptococcal infection, presenting with symptoms such as hematuria, edema, and hypertension.
  • A hallmark feature of APSGN is decreased C3 complement levels due to complement consumption in the immune response to streptococcal antigens. 
  • This decrease in C3 is typically transient, with levels returning to normal within 6-8 weeks, distinguishing APSGN from other forms of glomerulonephritis where C3 levels may not be affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High blood pressure (hypertension): Elevated blood pressure is frequently seen in APSGN due to fluid retention and impaired kidney function, making hypertension a common finding in affected children.

 

Option C. Elevated serum creatinine levels: APSGN often causes reduced glomerular filtration, which leads to increased serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, reflecting kidney impairment.

 

Option D. Positive anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titers: Positive ASO titers indicate a recent streptococcal infection, helping to confirm APSGN when correlated with clinical findings. Anti-DNAase B titers may also be elevated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is typically associated with decreased C3 levels, hypertension, elevated creatinine, and positive streptococcal titers (ASO or anti-DNAase B) following a recent streptococcal infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect associated with endothelin-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchodilation

 

  • Endothelin-1 (ET-1) is a peptide hormone primarily released by endothelial cells and is known for its strong vasoconstrictive properties. It acts through ETA and ETB receptors, which trigger several physiological responses, impacting vascular, cardiac, and renal functions.
  • However, bronchodilation is not an effect of endothelin-1. On the contrary, endothelin-1 generally causes bronchoconstriction by stimulating smooth muscle in the airways, which can worsen respiratory symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive Inotropic Effect: This is a known effect of endothelin-1, which increases the force of myocardial contraction through its effects on cardiac muscle cells, impacting cardiac output.

 

Option B. Decreased Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR): Endothelin-1 causes renal vasoconstriction, reducing blood flow to the kidneys and lowering GFR. This effect plays a role in the kidney-related consequences of elevated ET-1.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction: Vasoconstriction is a major action of endothelin-1, primarily through activation of the ETA receptors on vascular smooth muscle, which significantly raises blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endothelin-1 is a potent vasoconstrictor that reduces GFR and has a positive inotropic effect on cardiac muscle but does not cause bronchodilation.
