The disinfectant is 10 times more potent than phenol
The disinfectant has the same germicidal power as phenol
The effectiveness of the disinfectant is assessed by Bacillus stearothermophilus spores

questions.text: A hospital is evaluating the germicidal effectiveness of a new disinfectant in comparison to phenol. If the disinfectant's Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC) is measured at 10, what does this indicate about its potency relative to phenol?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The disinfectant is 10 times more potent than phenol

 

  • The Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC), also known as the Carbolic Acid Coefficient, is used to measure the germicidal power of a disinfectant compared to phenol. 
  • An RWC of 10 indicates that the disinfectant is ten times as potent as phenol when tested against Salmonella typhi under controlled conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disinfectant is ineffective in the presence of organic matter: This is true for the RWC test but is not specific to an RWC value of 10. The Chic Martin test is used when organic matter is present.

 

Option C. The disinfectant has the same germicidal power as phenol: This would be indicated by an RWC of 1.

 

Option D. The effectiveness of the disinfectant is assessed by Bacillus stearothermophilus spores: These are used to assess the adequacy of autoclaving, not the effectiveness of a disinfectant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rideal-Walker Coefficient indicates the potency of a disinfectant relative to phenol. An RWC of 10 means the disinfectant is 10 times as effective as phenol against Salmonella typhi in ideal conditions.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation with a blood type of B negative has been found to have an elevated Indirect Coombs Test (ICT) titer of 1:32. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV

 

  • The best next step in the management of a pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation with an elevated ICT titer (1:32) is to assess for fetal anemia using middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA-PSV) via ultrasound. 
  • In cases of Rh incompatibility where there is maternal alloimmunization (as indicated by the high ICT titer), MCA-PSV is a non-invasive Doppler ultrasound measure used to assess the risk of fetal anemia. 
  • Elevated MCA-PSV can indicate moderate to severe fetal anemia, and this assessment allows clinicians to monitor fetal well-being and determine if further interventions like intrauterine transfusion are required.
  • A titer of 1:32 or higher in an Rh-negative mother is considered a critical level and signifies a risk for hemolytic disease in the fetus. Therefore, assessing MCA-PSV is essential to determine the severity of the fetal condition and guide further management.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give steroid cover and deliver: At 28 weeks, the fetus is still premature, and delivering at this stage is generally avoided unless absolutely necessary. Steroid cover to enhance fetal lung maturity is appropriate if delivery is imminent, but in this case, assessing MCA-PSV is preferable to determine the need for potential intrauterine intervention rather than preterm delivery.

 

Option C. Perform intrauterine transfusion: Intrauterine transfusion is considered if there is evidence of severe fetal anemia as indicated by elevated MCA-PSV or other markers. However, without first assessing MCA-PSV to confirm fetal anemia, it is premature to proceed with intrauterine transfusion.

 

Option D. Repeat ICT after 2 weeks: While repeating ICT titers can help monitor the mother’s antibody levels, it does not provide direct information about fetal anemia. Since the ICT titer has already reached a critical level (1:32), monitoring the fetus directly with MCA-PSV is more informative and is the appropriate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of maternal alloimmunization with a critical Indirect Coombs Test (ICT) titer (≥1:32), the next step is to assess fetal anemia using middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA-PSV) via ultrasound.

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is able to do all the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Make a tower of 5 cubes

 

  • A 15-month-old child is typically not able to make a tower of 5 cubes. 
  • This skill usually develops later, around the age of 2 years. 
  • At 15 months, a child may be able to stack 2 or 3 cubes, but stacking 5 cubes requires more advanced fine motor skills and coordination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crawl upstairs: Crawling upstairs is a developmental milestone that many 15-month-old children can achieve as they become more mobile and confident in their gross motor skills.

 

Option C. Name familiar objects: A 15-month-old child can start to name familiar objects as language development progresses. At this age, children often recognize and may attempt to label objects or people they encounter regularly.

 

Option D. Pointing to familiar things: It is a common milestone around 12-15 months. By this age, children are often able to recognize and point to objects or people they know, showing early development of communication and social skills.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • By 15 months, children typically develop gross motor skills such as crawling upstairs and social and language skills like pointing to and naming familiar objects. 
  • Fine motor skills such as building a tower with multiple cubes develop later, around age 2.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the pediatric cardiology clinic with a history of cyanosis, difficulty breathing during exertion, and episodes of "tet spells". On examination, a systolic ejection murmur is heard along the left upper sternal border. Echocardiography reveals a right ventricular outflow tract obstruction along with a ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following describes the displacement of the infundibular septum in this congenital heart defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior displacement

 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is characterized by four components: right ventricular outflow tract obstruction, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. 
  • The condition is caused by anterior displacement of the infundibular septum, which leads to the misalignment that produces the structural anomalies seen in TOF. 
  • This anterior shift contributes to the obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract and the characteristic clinical findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a congenital heart defect that results from the anterior displacement of the infundibular septum. 
  • This displacement causes four key anatomical features: right ventricular outflow tract obstruction, a ventricular septal defect, an overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. 
  • Recognizing the significance of infundibular septal displacement helps in understanding the pathophysiology of TOF and its clinical presentation, including cyanosis and "tet spells."

questions.text:
Match each lipid-lowering drug (Column A) with its primary mechanism of action (Column B). 

 

Column A (Drugs)

 

  1. Evolocumab
  2. Bempedoic acid
  3. Lomitapide
  4. Ezetimibe

 

Column B (Mechanism of Action)

 

  1. Inhibits ATP citrate lyase to block cholesterol biosynthesis
  2. Prevents degradation of LDL receptors by inhibiting PCSK9
  3. Blocks Niemann-Pick C1–like 1 (NPC1L1) transporter to reduce cholesterol absorption
  4. Inhibits microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP), reducing VLDL production
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

1. Evolocumab: Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor, which prevents the degradation of LDL receptors (B).

 

2. Bempedoic acid: Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, blocking cholesterol biosynthesis (A).

 

3. Lomitapide: Lomitapide inhibits microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP), reducing VLDL and chylomicron formation (D).

 

4. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe blocks the NPC1L1 transporter in the intestine, reducing cholesterol absorption (C).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each lipid-lowering drug has a unique mechanism: 

 

  • Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor)
  • Bempedoic acid (ATP citrate lyase inhibitor)
  • Lomitapide (MTP inhibitor)
  • Ezetimibe (NPC1L1 inhibitor)

choices.text: Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery
Compression by a meningioma at the cavernous sinus
Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
Infarction of the oculomotor nerve nucleus

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents with 3 weeks of worsening double vision. He reports no pain, but he has difficulty reading and driving due to his symptoms. Medical history includes poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

 

On physical examination:

 

  • The right eye is deviated laterally and inferiorly at rest.
  • The right pupil is dilated and unresponsive to both direct light and accommodation testing.
  • Diplopia improves slightly when the patient looks to the right.
  • Extraocular movements are impaired on the right, but full on the left.

 

MRI brain was planned. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery

 

This patient’s findings are consistent with isolated oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) palsy due to an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery (PComm):

 

  • Eye deviation (down and out): Caused by unopposed action of the lateral rectus (CN VI) and superior oblique (CN IV).
  • Pupil involvement (dilated and unresponsive): Compression of the parasympathetic fibers traveling on the surface of CN III by an aneurysm. This distinguishes compressive lesions (e.g., aneurysms) from ischemic causes (e.g., microvascular disease).
  • Diplopia improves slightly on lateral gaze: Partial compensation by the contralateral eye.
  • Risk factors: Hypertension and hyperlipidemia may contribute to aneurysm formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression by a meningioma at the cavernous sinus: While meningiomas can compress CN III, they typically also involve other structures in the cavernous sinus (e.g., CN IV, CN VI, or V1/V2 branches), leading to more widespread deficits. This patient has isolated CN III palsy.

 

Option C. Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF): MLF demyelination (e.g., in multiple sclerosis) causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia, characterized by impaired adduction of one eye and horizontal nystagmus in the abducting eye. This is not consistent with this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. Infarction of the oculomotor nerve nucleus: Nuclear infarction would cause more complex deficits, often involving bilateral or asymmetric oculomotor dysfunction due to the midline location of the oculomotor nucleus. It would not produce isolated pupil-involving CN III palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior communicating artery aneurysm should be suspected in patients with isolated oculomotor nerve palsy, especially when pupil involvement is present. Prompt neuroimaging and vascular evaluation are critical to confirm the diagnosis and prevent complications, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following equations is used to calculate the resting membrane potential by considering the permeability and equilibrium potential of multiple ions, including sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), and chloride (Cl-)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Goldman equation

 

  • The Goldman equation (also known as the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation) is used to calculate the resting membrane potential of a cell by taking into account the permeability and equilibrium potential of multiple ions, specifically sodium (Na⁺), potassium (K⁺), and chloride (Cl⁻). This equation is more comprehensive than the Nernst equation because it factors in the relative permeabilities of these ions across the cell membrane. The resting membrane potential is determined by the movement of these ions, which is influenced by their concentration gradients and membrane permeability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nernst equation: Incorrect. The Nernst equation is used to calculate the equilibrium potential of a single ion, not the overall membrane potential, which is influenced by multiple ions and their permeabilities.

 

Option C. Henderson-Hasselbalch equation: Incorrect. The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation is used to calculate the pH of a solution based on the concentration of an acid and its conjugate base. It is unrelated to membrane potentials or ion permeability.

 

Option D. Fick's law: Incorrect. Fick's law describes the rate of diffusion of a gas across a membrane and is unrelated to the calculation of membrane potential or ion permeability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Goldman equation is used to calculate the resting membrane potential by incorporating the concentrations and relative permeabilities and equilibrium potential  of multiple ions, including Na+, K+, and Cl-.

questions.text: A patient with a Candida infection is found to be unresponsive to standard fluconazole therapy. Which of the following Candida species is most likely responsible, due to its known intrinsic resistance to fluconazole?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Candida krusei

 

  • Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, meaning this species generally does not respond to fluconazole treatment. 
  • This resistance is linked to specific adaptations, including changes in the enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is the target of fluconazole, as well as enhanced activity of efflux pumps and modifications in membrane sterols.
  • Because fluconazole is often a first-line treatment for Candida infections, the presence of Candida krusei typically requires alternative antifungal therapy, such as amphotericin B, echinocandins, or voriconazole, to effectively manage the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Candida albicans is generally susceptible to fluconazole and is effectively treated with this agent in most cases, unless resistance has developed.

 

Option B. Candida tropicalis: While Candida tropicalis can develop resistance over time, it is not intrinsically resistant to fluconazole and usually responds to standard antifungal therapy.

 

Option D. Candida parapsilosis: Candida parapsilosis is typically susceptible to fluconazole, making it a less likely cause of treatment failure when this antifungal is used.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks gestation presents for a routine ultrasound. The ultrasound reveals reduced amniotic fluid. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of oligohydramnios in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prematurity

 

  • Prematurity by itself is not typically associated with oligohydramnios. 
  • Oligohydramnios is defined as a low level of amniotic fluid and is often due to factors that either decrease amniotic fluid production or increase fluid loss. 
  • Prematurity alone does not usually cause a reduction in amniotic fluid volume; instead, it is the result of various pathological or mechanical factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior urethral valve: This is a common cause of oligohydramnios due to obstruction in the lower urinary tract, which impedes urine flow. Since fetal urine is a major component of amniotic fluid in the second and third trimesters, any obstruction like a posterior urethral valve can reduce amniotic fluid volume.

 

Option B. Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidneys: Bilateral kidney abnormalities can lead to oligohydramnios since the fetus’s ability to produce urine, which contributes to amniotic fluid, is compromised. Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidneys result in minimal or no urine production, thereby reducing amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Prelabor rupture of membranes (PROM): When the amniotic sac ruptures prematurely, it leads to leakage of amniotic fluid, which can subsequently result in oligohydramnios if the membranes do not reseal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oligohydramnios is commonly caused by conditions that either restrict fetal urine production, such as renal abnormalities and urinary tract obstructions, or cause leakage of amniotic fluid, such as prelabor rupture of membranes. 
  • Prematurity, on its own, is not typically a cause of oligohydramnios.

choices.text: Increase in the Depth of Inspiration
Decrease in the Duration of Inspiration
Decrease in the Duration of Expiration
Increase in the Depth of Expiration

questions.text: What is the primary effect of the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in the Duration of Expiration

 

  • The Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex is a reflex that responds to lung deflation. This reflex is primarily triggered by a sudden decrease in lung volume, which sends feedback to the respiratory centers in the brainstem to prevent further deflation. The primary effect of the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex is to decrease the duration of expiration, prompting an earlier onset of inspiration. This response aims to counteract excessive lung deflation and helps to maintain a steady respiratory rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in the Depth of Inspiration: This is incorrect because the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex mainly affects the timing of expiration rather than increasing the depth of inspiration.

 

Option B. Decrease in the Duration of Inspiration: This is incorrect because the reflex specifically acts to decrease the duration of expiration, not inspiration.

 

Option D. Increase in the Depth of Expiration: This is incorrect; the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex does not directly influence the depth of expiration. Instead, it shortens the expiration phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex decreases the duration of expiration, thereby initiating the next inspiratory phase sooner. This reflex is important in maintaining a balanced respiratory cycle and preventing excessive lung deflation.

choices.text: Intravenous thiamine followed by oral diazepam
Intravenous thiamine followed by intravenous lorazepam

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use (1 bottle of whiskey daily for the past 10 years) is brought to emergency with tremors, sweating, and anxiety 24 hours after his last drink. His vitals show BP 160/100 mmHg, pulse 112/min, temperature 37.8°C. On examination, the patient has pallor and icterus. He has a previous history of withdrawal seizures. Which of the following should be the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous thiamine followed by intravenous lorazepam

 

  • The patient presents with signs and symptoms of alcohol withdrawal (tremors, sweating, anxiety, elevated blood pressure, and pulse) and has a history of chronic alcohol use and previous withdrawal seizures. 
  • Alcohol withdrawal can progress to severe complications, including seizures and delirium tremens, making rapid intervention essential. 
  • Intravenous thiamine is crucial to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy, a common complication in chronic alcohol users. 
  • Intravenous lorazepam is preferred for patients at high risk of seizures, as it has a reliable, quick onset and is less affected by liver function, which is important given the patient’s icterus (suggesting possible liver dysfunction).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous thiamine followed by oral diazepam: While thiamine is essential, oral diazepam is not recommended in this case due to liver dysfunction. Lorazepam, given intravenously, is more appropriate in acute settings and for patients with compromised liver function.

 

Option C. Oral chlordiazepoxide with oral thiamine: Chlordiazepoxide, although commonly used for alcohol withdrawal, is not suitable here as it has a long half-life and is processed by the liver, posing a risk in patients with liver impairment. Intravenous administration of thiamine and a benzodiazepine is preferred for quicker effect.

 

Option D. Intravenous haloperidol with thiamine: Haloperidol is not used as a primary treatment for alcohol withdrawal because it may increase the risk of seizures. Benzodiazepines are the preferred treatment for controlling withdrawal symptoms and preventing seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Benzodiazepines are considered the drug of choice for the management of alcohol withdrawal. In presence of liver damage- short-acting benzodiazepines, such as oxazepam or lorazepam, are preferred. 
  • Thiamine must be administered before giving glucose, to prevent the precipitation of Wernicke’s encephalopathy.

questions.text:
Match the following types of waste with their respective descriptions:

 

Column A: Types of Waste

 

  1. Rubbish
  2. Garbage
  3. Sewage
  4. Sullage

 

Column B: Descriptions

 

  1. Liquid waste containing excreta
  2. Processed food waste generated from the kitchen
  3. Liquid waste without excreta
  4. Miscellaneous solid materials including paper, clothing, wood, metal, and glass
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a-4, b-2, c-1, d-3

 

Each type of waste is correctly matched with its description in the options:

 

a-4. Rubbish is described as miscellaneous solid materials that do not decompose and are not food waste, such as paper, clothing, wood, metal, and glass, matching with description

 

b-2. Garbage refers to waste originating from the kitchen, which primarily includes processed food waste, correctly paired with description

 

c-1. Sewage is known for being a liquid waste that contains excreta from toilets and is suitably matched with description

 

d-3. Sullage is another type of liquid waste, but it does not contain excreta. It typically comes from kitchen sinks, dishwashers, and washing machines, making it align well with description

 

Educational Objective :

 

The types and descriptions of waste:

 

  • Rubbish: Miscellaneous solid waste (non-biodegradable).
  • Garbage: Biodegradable food waste.
  • Sewage: Liquid waste with excreta.
  • Sullage: Liquid waste without excreta

questions.text: During an experiment with a bacterial toxin, a researcher observes a marked rise in cAMP levels due to activation of adenylate cyclase through G-protein coupled signalling. Based on this observation, which bacterial toxin is most likely being studied?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholera toxin

 

  • Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, stimulates adenylate cyclase by permanently activating the Gs protein (stimulatory G protein), leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels within intestinal epithelial cells. 
  • This elevated cAMP causes an efflux of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in severe watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shiga toxin: Incorrect. Shiga toxin, produced by Shigella dysenteriae and some E. coli strains, inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 60S ribosomal subunit, leading to cell death. It does not act through G-protein coupled mechanisms or affect adenylate cyclase.

 

Option C. Diphtheria toxin: Incorrect. Diphtheria toxin, produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating elongation factor-2 (EF-2) through ADP-ribosylation. It does not involve G-protein coupled action or affect adenylate cyclase.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas toxin: Incorrect. Pseudomonas exotoxin A, produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, also inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating EF-2, similar to diphtheria toxin. It does not stimulate adenylate cyclase through G-protein coupled action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cholera toxin increases intracellular cAMP by activating adenylate cyclase through G-protein coupled action, specifically by permanently activating the stimulatory Gs protein.

questions.text: A researcher is studying immune responses and wants to identify the smallest structural component of an antigen that can directly interact with an antibody or T-cell receptor. Which of the following best describes this unit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epitope

 

  • The epitope, also known as the antigenic determinant, is the smallest part of an antigen that directly interacts with an antibody or a T-cell receptor.
  • This specific interaction allows the immune system to recognize and respond to the antigen.
  • Each antigen may have multiple epitopes, enabling multiple immune responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paratope: Incorrect. The paratope is the specific part of an antibody that binds to the epitope on the antigen. It is part of the antibody's structure, not the antigen.

 

Option C. Complex hapten: Incorrect. A complex hapten can become antigenic when attached to a larger carrier protein, but it is not an independent unit of antigenicity.

 

Option D. Simple hapten: Incorrect. A simple hapten is a small molecule that, on its own, does not elicit an immune response. It only becomes antigenic when bound to a carrier protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The epitope is the smallest unit of antigenicity, as it is the specific site on an antigen that binds to an antibody or T-cell receptor, initiating an immune response.

questions.text:
Match the following Thyroplasty with their Site of procedure:

 

Thyroplasty: 

  1. Type I                               
  2. Type II                              
  3. Type III                            
  4. Type IV    

     

Site of procedure:

  1. Medialization of Vocal cord   
  2. Lengthening of vocal cord
  3. Shortening of vocal cord        
  4. Lateralization of vocal cord
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

 

  • Type I (A. Medialization of Vocal cord): Type I thyroplasty is a medialization procedure where the vocal cord is brought closer to the midline. It is commonly used for unilateral vocal cord paralysis to improve voice quality.
  • Type II (D. Lateralization of vocal cord): Type II thyroplasty involves lateralization, moving the vocal cord away from the midline to widen the airway, often used to treat conditions causing airway obstruction.
  • Type III (C. Shortening of vocal cord): Type III thyroplasty shortens the vocal cords, which can lower pitch, and is applied in cases where a lower pitch is desired.
  • Type IV (B. Lengthening of vocal cord): Type IV thyroplasty lengthens the vocal cords, increasing pitch, which can be used for pitch elevation surgeries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Thyroplasty is categorized into types based on the intended functional outcome for the vocal cords. Type I is for medialization, Type II for lateralization, Type III for shortening, and Type IV for lengthening of the vocal cords. Understanding these types helps in selecting the appropriate surgical intervention for vocal cord issues.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with a history of allergic symptoms. To evaluate potential allergens, the physician recommends skin testing. Skin tests are primarily used to assess which types of hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Types I and IV

 

  • Skin tests are commonly used to assess Type I and Type IV hypersensitivity reactions. 
  • Type I hypersensitivity reactions involve immediate allergic responses mediated by IgE, such as in skin prick tests for allergies to pollens, foods, or other allergens. 
  • Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are delayed-type reactions mediated by T-cells, such as the Mantoux test for tuberculosis, which assesses cell-mediated immunity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Types I and II: Incorrect. Type I hypersensitivity reactions can be evaluated with skin tests, but Type II hypersensitivity reactions, which involve cytotoxic antibody responses, are generally not assessed through skin tests.

 

Option C. Types II and III: Incorrect. Skin tests are not typically used for Type II (antibody-mediated cytotoxic) or Type III (immune complex-mediated) hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. Types III and V: Incorrect. Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes and is not usually assessed by skin tests, nor is Type V, which involves stimulatory or blocking antibodies affecting receptor functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type I skin test: Casoni skin test
  • Type IV skin test: Tuberculin, Lepromin and patch test

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting lasting several days. These episodes are often triggered by stress and fasting and are accompanied by dark-colored urine and mild lower limb weakness. She denies fever, diarrhea, or any history of similar symptoms in her family. Physical examination reveals no peritoneal signs, but mild proximal muscle weakness is noted. Laboratory findings are significant for hyponatremia. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urinary porphobilinogen


The most appropriate investigation to confirm a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is urinary porphobilinogen measurement. Elevated levels of porphobilinogen during an acute attack are diagnostic of AIP, a disorder of the heme synthesis pathway. This test is critical for differentiating AIP from other causes of abdominal pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum amylase and lipase: While these are useful for diagnosing pancreatitis, they are not relevant in this patient, as her symptoms do not align with pancreatitis (e.g., no epigastric tenderness or history of alcohol use).

 

Option B. Abdominal ultrasound: Ultrasound may identify structural abnormalities in the abdomen, such as gallstones or appendicitis, but it is not diagnostic for AIP. The absence of peritoneal signs makes this investigation less relevant.

 

Option D. Colonoscopy: Colonoscopy is useful for diagnosing inflammatory or functional bowel conditions like Crohn’s disease or irritable bowel syndrome but is not indicated in a case with systemic and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:


Urinary porphobilinogen is the investigation of choice for diagnosing acute intermittent porphyria, particularly in patients with recurrent abdominal pain, dark urine, and neurological symptoms. Early recognition and testing are essential for timely treatment and avoidance of triggers.

questions.text:
In Griffith's experiment that demonstrated the principle of transformation, which bacteria were used to show the transfer of genetic material? 

 

  1. Streptococcus pyogenes
  2. Capsulated Streptococcus pneumoniae
  3. Staphylococcus aureus
  4. MRSA
  5. Non-capsulated Streptococcus pneumoniae
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 5

 

  • Griffith's experiment involved two strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae: a smooth, capsulated (virulent) strain and a rough, non-capsulated (non-virulent) strain. 
  • The capsulated strain (Option 2) could cause disease because it evaded the immune response, while the non-capsulated strain (Option 5) did not cause disease. 
  • Griffith discovered that when he mixed heat-killed capsulated bacteria with live non-capsulated bacteria, the non-capsulated bacteria acquired the virulent trait, indicating a transfer of genetic material, which he called the "transforming principle."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 and 3: Incorrect. Neither Streptococcus pyogenes nor Staphylococcus aureus were involved in Griffith’s experiment.

 

Option C. 1 and 4: Incorrect. Streptococcus pyogenes and MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) were not part of Griffith’s experiment.

 

Option D. 3 and 5: Incorrect. Staphylococcus aureus was not used in the experiment; only strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae (capsulated and non-capsulated) were used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Griffith's experiment demonstrated genetic transformation using capsulated and non-capsulated strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae (Options 2 and 5), showing that genetic traits could be transferred between bacteria.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Plasmodium falciparum malaria was treated with chloroquine and doxycycline for 7 days. The fever resolved within 4 days, but a follow-up peripheral smear on day 7 still showed occasional gametocytes. This pattern of response suggests which type of drug resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) R2 type

 

  • In R2 type resistance, there is a significant reduction in parasitemia (greater than 75%) within the first 48 hours, but the parasite is not completely cleared by day 7.
  • This scenario aligns with the patient’s clinical course, where fever resolved (indicating a reduction in symptoms), but gametocytes were still detectable in the smear after 7 days, indicating incomplete parasite clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. R1 type: Characterized by initial parasite clearance and symptom resolution, followed by recrudescence (reappearance) of infection within 7–28 days after treatment completion.

 

Option C. R3 type: Refers to minimal or no reduction in parasitemia within the first 48 hours, indicating a high level of drug resistance.

 

Option D. R4 type: Not a recognized type in malaria drug resistance classification and serves as a distractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • R2 type resistance is seen when parasitemia significantly decreases initially but is not cleared by day 7. 
  • In malaria treatment, ongoing parasite presence after a week indicates an incomplete response and suggests a need for alternative therapies or closer monitoring.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is undergoing evaluation for left ventricular function. He undergoes a pressure-volume loop assessment, which determines his ejection fraction based on the diagram provided. Using the data points indicated in the loop, calculate the ejection fraction for this patient.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 50%

 

  • The ejection fraction (EF) is a measure of the percentage of blood that is ejected from the left ventricle during each heartbeat. It is calculated with the formula:

 

 

  • To calculate EF from a pressure-volume loop:
  1. End-Diastolic Volume (EDV) is the volume of blood in the left ventricle at the end of diastole.
  2. End-Systolic Volume (ESV) is the volume of blood left in the left ventricle after systole.

 

Stroke Volume (SV)=EDV−ESV

 

Using the values provided:

 

  • Assume EDV = 140 mL and ESV = 70 mL (based on the data points in the loop).
  • Stroke Volume (SV) = 140 mL - 70 mL = 70 mL

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ejection fraction is calculated as (Stroke Volume/End-Diastolic Volume)×100% and is an important indicator of left ventricular function. A normal EF is generally between 55% and 70%, with values below 50% suggesting reduced cardiac efficiency.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the school medical officer with fever, malaise, and painful swallowing. On examination, a diffuse swelling is noted on both sides of the face, below and in front of the ears. The doctor suspects mumps. What is the most appropriate management approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rest, analgesics, and balanced diet

 

  • Mumps is a viral infection caused by the mumps virus, primarily affecting the parotid glands, which are salivary glands located near the ears. Since it is a viral illness, antibiotics are not effective. 
  • The mainstay of management is supportive care, which includes rest, analgesics for pain relief, and a balanced diet to support recovery. 
  • Immunization is preventive and not effective post-infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analgesics only: While analgesics can help relieve pain, they alone are insufficient as rest and proper nutrition are also essential to support the body’s recovery.

 

Option B. Active and passive immunization: Immunization is preventive and not appropriate for a child who has already contracted the infection.

 

Option C. Antibiotics only: Antibiotics are ineffective against viral infections like mumps, as they target bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Mumps is a viral infection best managed with supportive care, including rest, analgesics, and a nutritious diet. Immunization (MMR vaccine) is the key preventive measure but does not help in treating active cases.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with severe ptosis associated with poor levator function. Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontalis Suspension surgery

 

  • Frontalis suspension surgery is the preferred treatment for severe ptosis when there is poor levator muscle function, particularly in children. 
  • In cases where the levator muscle is weak or non-functional, frontalis suspension allows the frontalis muscle to help elevate the eyelid. 
  • This method uses a sling material to attach the eyelid to the frontalis muscle, enabling the child to use forehead movements to lift the eyelid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levator resection: This procedure is typically used when there is moderate to good levator function. It would not be effective in cases of poor levator function.

 

Option C. Mullerectomy: This surgery targets the Müller’s muscle and is usually performed for mild ptosis with good levator function, not suitable for severe cases with poor levator strength.

 

Option D. Fasanella-Servat operation: This technique is also indicated for mild ptosis and requires adequate levator function. It is not appropriate for severe ptosis with poor levator muscle function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For severe ptosis with poor levator function, frontalis suspension surgery is the treatment of choice, as it leverages the frontalis muscle to aid in eyelid elevation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a firm, enlarging midline neck mass over the past few months. Her serum calcitonin levels are elevated. USG neck confirms the swelling to be located in the thyroid. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medullary thyroid cancer

 

  • Goitre with elevated serum calcitonin is likely to be a Medullary thyroid cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A and B. Papillary and Follicular thyroid cancers show elevated serum Thyroglobulin.

 

Option D. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis: Hashimoto’s shows elevated anti TPO/TG antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MTC (Medullary thyroid cancer) is derived from parafollicular C cells and shows elevated serum calcitonin and CEA levels. 
  • Radioactive iodine is ineffective in MTC, as C cells do not take up iodine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and chronic smoking arrives at the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back. His blood pressure is elevated at 170/100 mmHg. A CT scan of the chest is performed, and the image is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and radiologic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thoracic aortic aneurysm

 

  • The clinical presentation of severe, "tearing" chest pain that radiates to the back, along with the patient’s elevated blood pressure and history of hypertension and smoking, is highly indicative of an acute thoracic aortic dissection or thoracic aortic aneurysm. 
  • A CT scan in this context would reveal a dilated or dissected thoracic aorta, which can be seen as a separation within the layers of the aortic wall or as a significant dilation. 
  • This condition is often precipitated by high blood pressure and smoking, both of which are risk factors for aortic pathology.
  • Aortic dissection is characterized by a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta, allowing blood to enter the medial layer and create a false lumen. This produces intense chest pain, often described as tearing or ripping, that radiates to the back, particularly in patients with hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Pulmonary embolism often presents with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and possibly hemoptysis. While it can cause chest pain, it is typically not described as tearing or radiating to the back. CT findings in pulmonary embolism would include filling defects in the pulmonary arteries rather than findings associated with the aorta.

 

Option C. Acute myocardial infarction: Myocardial infarction typically presents with crushing substernal chest pain, which may radiate to the left arm, jaw, or neck, but is not usually described as tearing or radiating to the back. MI is also more commonly associated with symptoms like sweating, nausea, and vomiting. The CT findings would not show the aortic changes seen in this case.

 

Option D. Esophageal rupture: Esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome) can present with severe chest pain and possibly radiate to the back, especially after vomiting. 

 

However, the pain is often accompanied by symptoms such as subcutaneous emphysema and shock. CT would show air leakage into the mediastinum or pleura, rather than the changes in the aorta seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sudden, tearing chest pain radiating to the back in a hypertensive, elderly male with a history of smoking is highly suggestive of an acute aortic dissection or aneurysm and requires immediate imaging, typically with CT, for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with schizophrenia is starting antipsychotic therapy. He is concerned about the potential for daytime drowsiness and requests a medication with minimal sedative effects. Which of the following antipsychotic drugs is associated with the highest level of sedation and should be used cautiously in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Olanzapine

 

  • Olanzapine is known for its strong sedative effects due to its antihistaminic activity. 
  • This property makes it more likely to cause drowsiness compared to other antipsychotics, which can impact patients who need to avoid sedation in their daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asenapine: Asenapine causes moderate sedation, generally less than olanzapine.

 

Option B. Aripiprazole: Aripiprazole has minimal sedative effects, making it a preferred choice for avoiding drowsiness.

 

Option C. Thioxanthine: Thioxanthine has moderate sedation but is generally less sedating than olanzapine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Olanzapine has high sedative potential due to its antihistaminic action, making it less ideal for patients wanting to avoid drowsiness.

questions.text: A water sample was collected from a source near an agricultural area. The sample was deemed unfit for human consumption due to elevated levels of which of the following contaminants?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nitrite


Agricultural runoff often contains high levels of nitrogen-based compounds from fertilizers, which can contaminate nearby water sources. Nitrites, a byproduct of nitrogen-based fertilizers, can be harmful to human health, particularly for infants, as they interfere with oxygen transport in the blood (methemoglobinemia). Elevated nitrite levels indicate contamination from agricultural sources and make the water unfit for human consumption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iodine: Elevated iodine is uncommon in agricultural runoff and is not typically associated with contamination from fertilizers.

 

Option B. Zinc: While zinc can be found in runoff, it is less commonly elevated to harmful levels due to agricultural activities alone.

 

Option C. Chlorides: Chlorides may increase due to various sources, but they are not typically the primary concern in agricultural contamination relative to nitrites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nitrite contamination from agricultural runoff can render water unsafe for drinking due to its toxic effects on human health, particularly in infants and vulnerable populations.

questions.text: During diagnostic laparoscopy for chronic abdominal pain and diarrhoea, the small bowel was noted to have findings as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crohn’s disease

 

  • The image from the diagnostic laparoscopy shows characteristic features of Crohn’s disease, which often involves creeping fat over small intestine, particularly the terminal ileum. 
  • The hallmark of Crohn’s disease includes transmural inflammation, which can lead to strictures, fistulas, and "cobblestone" appearance of the mucosa. 
  • These findings are not typical for the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute appendicits: Presents with swollen and inflamed appendix with a short clinical history.

 

Option C. Sigmoid Diverticuli: Diverticuli are outpouchings of the colon wall, typically found in the large intestine, particularly the sigmoid colon, and are not seen as transmural lesions in the small intestine.

 

Option D. Ulcerative colitis: Ulcerative colitis primarily affects the colon and rectum with continuous mucosal inflammation and does not involve the small intestine or show transmural inflammation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Crohn’s disease is characterized by creeping fat over small intestine and transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly affecting the terminal ileum and colon. 
  • It can present with strictures, fistulas, and a cobblestone appearance on endoscopy, differentiating it from ulcerative colitis and other gastrointestinal conditions.

choices.text: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, and (R) is the correct explanation of (A).
Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A).
Assertion (A) is true, but Reason (R) is false.
Assertion (A) is false, but Reason (R) is true.

questions.text:
Assertion-Reasoning Question

 

Assertion (A): Ritonavir is a suicide inhibitor that irreversibly inactivates its target enzyme, enhancing its effectiveness in HIV therapy.

 

Reason (R): Ritonavir forms a covalent bond with the enzyme, leading to permanent inhibition of CYP2C9 through mechanism-based inhibition.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, and (R) is the correct explanation of (A).

 

Assertion (A) is true: Ritonavir is a suicide inhibitor, meaning it irreversibly binds to and inactivates its target enzyme, making it effective in the treatment of HIV by ensuring prolonged inhibition of viral protease. This mechanism allows ritonavir to enhance its therapeutic impact.

 

Reason (R) is also true and provides an accurate explanation for Assertion (A). Ritonavir’s action involves forming a covalent bond with the enzyme, which leads to a permanent inhibition of the enzyme, including CYP2C9, through mechanism-based (suicide) inhibition. This characteristic affects drug metabolism, as ritonavir's inhibition of CYP2C9 can alter the metabolism of co-administered drugs.

 

Educational Objective

 

Ritonavir, as a suicide inhibitor, irreversibly binds to its target enzyme, inactivating it permanently. This mechanism-based inhibition also impacts CYP2C9, affecting drug interactions in HIV treatment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient diagnosed with HIV is started on antiretroviral therapy. The medication targets an enzyme critical to the virus by preventing the synthesis of double-stranded DNA from the virus's RNA. Which enzyme is most likely being inhibited by this treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reverse transcriptase

 

  • Reverse transcriptase is the enzyme responsible for synthesizing a complementary DNA (cDNA) strand from a single-stranded RNA template, a key step in the life cycle of retroviruses such as HIV. This enzyme allows the viral RNA genome to be transcribed into DNA, which then integrates into the host genome, allowing viral replication to proceed. Many antiretroviral drugs, particularly reverse transcriptase inhibitors (such as NRTIs and NNRTIs), specifically target this enzyme to prevent the virus from replicating and establishing infection within the host cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase is an enzyme responsible for replicating DNA during cellular division. It synthesizes new DNA strands based on an existing DNA template, but it does not use RNA as a template, making it irrelevant to the process described in the question.

 

Option C. Phosphokinase: Phosphokinase (or kinase) enzymes are responsible for transferring phosphate groups to various substrates, playing a role in cellular signaling and metabolism. They do not have a role in DNA or RNA synthesis and are not involved in retroviral replication.

 

Option D. RNA polymerase: RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a DNA template during transcription in cells, converting genetic information from DNA to RNA. However, it is not involved in the synthesis of DNA from an RNA template, which is specific to reverse transcriptase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reverse transcriptase is the enzyme that retroviruses, like HIV, use to create a DNA copy from their RNA genome. 
  • This step is essential for viral integration into the host genome and is a primary target for antiretroviral therapy.

questions.text: An elderly man underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity. He now presents to his physician with complaints of dizziness, fatigue, and tremors 2 hours after the ingestion of a carbohydrate-rich meal. His symptoms occur mainly due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoglycemia

 

  • The patient is presenting with features of late dumping syndrome following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. 
  • This occurs due to an increased release of insulin and hypoglycemia.
  • Dumping syndrome occurs due to rapid gastric emptying. It is commonly seen following gastric surgeries. It can be divided into:
    • Early dumping syndrome: Occurs after ingestion of foods with a high osmotic load. The increased osmotic load in the intestine leads to the sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract. Patients will develop hypovolemia and hypotension.
    • Late dumping syndrome: Occurs after ingestion of a large volume of meals that are rich in carbohydrates. A large amount of glucose is absorbed from the intestine which leads to a rapid increase in blood sugar levels. This in turn results in increased release of insulin which causes hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dumping syndrome can occur after gastric surgeries due to rapid gastric emptying. 
  • The mainstay of management includes dietary manipulation, advising small, regular meals that are low in carbohydrates and high in protein and fat. 
  • Somatostatin analogues like octreotide may be used in intractable cases.

choices.text: Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube
Continue resuscitation for the next 6 hours

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the ER after a high-impact motor vehicle accident. On examination, right-sided hemopneumothorax was noted. Tube thoracostomy (ICD placement) was done, and around 1500 mL of blood was drained within 1 hour. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emergency thoracotomy

 

  • Given the significant blood loss (1500 mL) and the patient’s critical condition, the most appropriate next step is an emergency thoracotomy.
  • Thoracotomy is a surgical procedure where the chest cavity is accessed to control bleeding and repair injuries to the chest structures (lung, blood vessels, heart).
  • The combination of hemopneumothorax and rapid blood loss suggests serious injury to blood vessels or vital structures. Emergency thoracotomy ensures direct control of the bleeding.

 

Indications for thoracotomy include:

 

  • Initial thoracostomy drainage of >1000 mL of blood in penetrating injuries or >1500 mL in blunt injuries.
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 mL/hour for 3 consecutive hours.
  • Caked hemothorax where blood clots impair drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube: While hemostatic agents can help manage smaller bleeds, they are not appropriate for the level of blood loss seen in this case. Emergency surgery is required.

 

Option B. Continue resuscitation for the next 6 hours: This would delay definitive treatment. Given the severity of blood loss, continued resuscitation without addressing the cause of bleeding would not be effective.

 

Option C. Urgent thoracentesis: Thoracentesis is typically used for pleural effusions, not for managing large-volume blood loss or life-threatening hemopneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of hemothorax with significant or rapidly ongoing blood loss, emergency thoracotomy is the definitive treatment to control bleeding and prevent further complications such as hypovolemic shock.

questions.text: A young patient underwent surgery under general anesthesia with Oxygen, nitrous oxide and Desflurane. Just after extubation, the patient develops desaturation and crepts. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negative pressure pulmonary edema

 

  • Negative pressure pulmonary edema (NPPE) can occur immediately after extubation, especially in young, healthy patients who experience upper airway obstruction post-extubation (such as laryngospasm). 
  • The intense inspiratory effort against a closed airway generates significant negative intrathoracic pressure, which can lead to rapid fluid shift into the lungs, causing pulmonary edema. 
  • This is characterized by sudden desaturation and the presence of crepitations on auscultation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pleural effusion: Pleural effusion is unlikely to develop suddenly just after extubation, and it generally does not cause acute symptoms immediately following surgery. Its development is typically gradual, and it would not present with sudden desaturation in the immediate post-extubation period.

 

Option B. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): ARDS can cause similar symptoms of hypoxemia and crackles; however, it typically develops hours to days after an insult rather than immediately post-extubation. ARDS is also characterized by a systemic inflammatory response rather than the rapid onset seen in NPPE.

 

Option D. No crepitations: The presence of crepitations was noted in the scenario, ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Negative pressure pulmonary edema is a rare but important complication to consider in the immediate post-extubation period, especially in young, healthy patients with upper airway obstruction. 
  • Recognizing and managing NPPE promptly is critical to ensure patient recovery and prevent worsening hypoxemia.

choices.text: All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema
Nummular eczema is the other name for Discoid eczema
Pityriasis versicolor is a form of dermatitis & it is associated with atopy

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about Dermatitis among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pityriasis versicolor is a form of dermatitis & it is associated with atopy

 

Pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor, is a superficial fungal infection caused by the yeast Malassezia. It presents as hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches on the skin, particularly on the trunk and upper arms. It is not considered a form of dermatitis and is not associated with atopy. Atopic conditions typically include conditions like atopic dermatitis, asthma, and allergic rhinitis, which are linked to immune dysregulation, not fungal infections.

 

Pityriasis versicolor is treated with antifungal medications rather than therapies used for dermatitis or eczematous conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema: This statement is correct. Dermatitis is a broad term that refers to inflammation of the skin, while eczema specifically refers to a subset of dermatitis characterized by dry, itchy, and inflamed skin. All eczematous conditions are classified under dermatitis, but not all forms of dermatitis are eczematous (for example, contact dermatitis may not have the same chronic features as eczema).

 

Option B. Pruritus is hallmark clinical feature: This is correct. Pruritus (itching) is indeed a hallmark clinical feature of dermatitis and is commonly present in various types of dermatitis, including eczema. Itching is a central symptom that often leads to excoriation and exacerbates inflammation in dermatitis.

 

Option C. Nummular eczema is the other name for Discoid eczema: This statement is also correct. Nummular eczema, also known as discoid eczema, is a type of eczema characterized by coin-shaped, well-defined plaques of eczema on the skin. It is often intensely pruritic and commonly affects adults.

 

Educational Objective:


Pityriasis versicolor is not classified as a form of dermatitis and is unrelated to atopy. It is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia spp., distinct from dermatitis and eczema.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male has a blood volume of 5.5 L and a hematocrit of 45%. What is his plasma volume?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.03 L

 

  • The total blood volume can be expressed as
    • Blood Volume = Plasma Volume / (1 – Hematocrit)
  • Plasma Volume = Blood Volume × (1 – Hematocrit)
    • Here, Blood Volume = 5.5L; Hematocrit = 45% = 45/100 = 0.45
  • Plasma Volume = 5.5 (1 – 0.45)
                                = 5.5 (0.55) = 3.025 L (3.03 L)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To calculate plasma volume, use the formula: Plasma Volume = Blood Volume * (1 - Hematocrit). In this case, with a blood volume of 5.5 L and hematocrit of 45%, the plasma volume is 3.03 L.

questions.text: A parasitology researcher is investigating parasitic reproduction methods. Which of the following parasites is known to be ovo-viviparous, meaning it releases larval-stage eggs instead of fully developed eggs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is an ovo-viviparous parasite, meaning it releases larvae directly rather than fully developed eggs. 
  • This unique reproductive strategy allows the larvae to develop further outside the host's body, enhancing the parasite's survival and infectivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris: Incorrect. Ascaris lumbricoides is oviparous, releasing fully developed eggs that hatch outside the host.

 

Option C. Enterobius: Incorrect. Enterobius vermicularis is also oviparous, releasing fully formed eggs that hatch outside the host.

 

Option D. Ancylostoma: Incorrect. Ancylostoma species, like hookworms, are also oviparous, releasing eggs that hatch in soil under favorable conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis is an ovo-viviparous parasite that releases larvae directly, aiding in its rapid infection cycle and environmental adaptation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman with hormone receptor-positive, HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer previously treated with trastuzumab now presents with disease progression. Her oncologist considers adding a medication that targets both the HER2 and EGFR tyrosine kinases and suggests combining it with an aromatase inhibitor. Which of the following drugs is most likely recommended in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lapatinib

 

  • Lapatinib is an orally bioavailable tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets both HER2 and EGFR, making it suitable for treating HER2-positive breast cancer, especially in cases resistant to trastuzumab. 
  • Lapatinib can be combined with the aromatase inhibitor letrozole in postmenopausal women with hormone receptor-positive, HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer. 
  • This combination approach helps in managing patients with dual receptor positivity (HER2 and hormone receptor-positive) who are refractory to other treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vismodegib: A hedgehog pathway inhibitor, primarily used in metastatic basal cell carcinoma (BCC), not in HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option C. Vemurafenib: A BRAF inhibitor used in metastatic melanoma and thyroid cancers with BRAF V600E mutations, not relevant to HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Erlotinib: An EGFR inhibitor used in non-small cell lung cancer with specific EGFR mutations, not effective for HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lapatinib is used in HER2-positive breast cancer resistant to trastuzumab, often combined with letrozole for hormone receptor-positive cases due to its dual inhibition of HER2 and EGFR.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of progressive unsteadiness, slurred speech, and difficulty with coordination. She denies any history of trauma or previous neurological disorders. Neurological examination reveals dysmetria, intention tremor, and a wide-based gait. MRI of the brain demonstrates cerebellar atrophy. Further evaluation reveals a 3 cm mass in the left breast on mammography. Which of the following antibodies is most commonly associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-Yo antibodies

 

Anti-Yo antibodies are the most commonly associated antibodies with paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, especially in patients with gynecologic or breast malignancies. These antibodies target Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, leading to progressive cerebellar dysfunction. This patient’s presentation, coupled with a breast mass, is consistent with paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration linked to anti-Yo antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-Hu antibodies: Anti-Hu antibodies are associated with paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis and sensory neuronopathy, commonly linked to small-cell lung cancer, not breast cancer.

 

Option C. Anti-Ri antibodies: Anti-Ri antibodies are associated with paraneoplastic opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome and are seen in some cases of breast cancer but are not commonly linked to cerebellar degeneration.

 

Option D. Anti-Ma2 antibodies: Anti-Ma2 antibodies are associated with paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis, particularly in germ cell tumors of the testes, and are not typically associated with cerebellar syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Yo antibodies are hallmark markers of paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration in the context of gynecologic or breast malignancies. Identifying these antibodies is crucial for diagnosing and managing the underlying malignancy.

choices.text: Presence of a foreign body in the esophagus
Ossification of the hyaline cartilage in the cricoid region
Infection leading to calcification in the neck
Calcification of elastic cartilage in the larynx

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent throat discomfort and a sensation of something being stuck in his throat. He has no history of swallowing foreign objects, and his medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals no signs of infection or swelling in the neck. An X-ray of the neck is performed, and the radiologist notes a dense shadow in the area of the larynx, which raises concern for a possible foreign body in the esophagus or larynx. However, on closer examination, the shadow appears consistent with calcified cartilage, specifically in the region of the cricoid cartilage. What is the most likely explanation for the radiographic finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ossification of the hyaline cartilage in the cricoid region

 

  • Hyaline cartilage, specifically the cricoid and thyroid cartilages, undergoes ossification or calcification with age, typically starting between the ages of 25 and 65. 
  • This can appear as a dense shadow on X-ray images, potentially mimicking a foreign body in the laryngeal or esophageal area. 
  • Recognizing this as a normal age-related change is essential to avoid unnecessary interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a foreign body in the esophagus: This option is incorrect in this context. Although the shadow on the X-ray initially raised suspicion of a foreign body, the patient’s history (no known ingestion of a foreign object) and the typical age-related calcification pattern support that it is likely calcified cartilage. Foreign bodies often cause symptoms of acute pain, dysphagia, or drooling and usually have a clear history of ingestion. Additionally, they often appear as irregular shapes or densities, whereas calcified cartilage has a more consistent, predictable appearance.

 

Option C. Infection leading to calcification in the neck: Infection-related calcification, known as dystrophic calcification, can occur in chronically inflamed or damaged tissue but is not typical in healthy cartilage. While infections in the neck area (such as abscesses) can lead to localized calcifications, they are rare in otherwise healthy cartilage like the cricoid. Infections would also present with additional symptoms, such as fever, swelling, redness, and pain, which were absent in this case.

 

Option D. Calcification of elastic cartilage in the larynx: This option is incorrect because only hyaline cartilage, not elastic cartilage, undergoes calcification or ossification. Elastic cartilage structures in the larynx, such as the epiglottic, corniculate, and cuneiform cartilages, do not typically calcify with age. Calcification of elastic cartilage is not a normal physiological process, and finding calcification in these areas would be highly unusual and might indicate an underlying pathology.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Hyaline cartilage in the larynx, such as the cricoid and thyroid cartilages, can ossify with age, creating calcifications visible on X-rays. 
  • These findings can mimic a foreign body but are typically normal age-related changes.
  • Recognizing this can prevent unnecessary diagnostic or therapeutic procedures, as elastic cartilage, unlike hyaline cartilage, does not undergo ossification.

questions.text: Chronic fluorosis has traditionally been associated with high fluoride levels in drinking water, specifically above 1.5 mg/liter. However, studies have indicated that fluorosis can also develop in individuals with prolonged exposure to fluoride through certain dietary staples. Which of the following staple foods is linked to an increased risk of fluorosis, even at lower fluoride concentrations in water?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maize

 

Maize has been identified as a dietary staple that can contribute to fluorosis in populations with even moderate fluoride levels in drinking water. Maize tends to accumulate fluoride from soil and water, and its high consumption, especially in certain regions, can lead to an increased risk of fluorosis. This is particularly significant in areas where maize is a staple food, as it acts as an additional fluoride source on top of water intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wheat: While wheat can contain some fluoride, it typically does not accumulate as much fluoride as maize and is less likely to be a significant contributor to fluorosis.

 

Option B. Potato: Potatoes can absorb fluoride from the soil, but they usually do not accumulate fluoride at levels that would lead to fluorosis when consumed as a staple.

 

Option D. Sea fish: Sea fish can contain fluoride, especially in bones, but it is generally not consumed in quantities sufficient to cause fluorosis in comparison to staple grains.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In areas where maize is a staple food, populations may be at increased risk for fluorosis due to the fluoride content in maize, highlighting the need to consider dietary sources of fluoride in addition to drinking water.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female is scheduled for an abdominal surgery and is being evaluated for anesthesia options. The anesthesiologist explains the differences between epidural and spinal anesthesia, noting that each has distinct characteristics. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding epidural anesthesia when compared to spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Faster onset of action

 

  • This statement is incorrect because epidural anesthesia has a slower onset of action compared to spinal anesthesia. In spinal anesthesia, the anesthetic is injected directly into the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), leading to a rapid onset of anesthesia within minutes. In contrast, epidural anesthesia requires the anesthetic to diffuse across the dura mater into the spinal nerves, which takes more time to take effect. Thus, spinal anesthesia acts faster than epidural anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The density of the block is less: This statement is correct. The density of the block (i.e., the intensity and completeness of the sensory and motor blockade) achieved with epidural anesthesia is generally less than that achieved with spinal anesthesia. Spinal anesthesia typically produces a more intense and dense blockade because it directly affects the spinal cord and CSF. Epidural anesthesia allows for more controlled and graded effects, which may not be as dense as spinal anesthesia.

 

Option C. Less chances of post-dural puncture headache: This statement is also correct. Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a potential complication when the dura mater is punctured, allowing cerebrospinal fluid to leak. In spinal anesthesia, the dura is intentionally punctured to deliver the anesthetic into the CSF, which can lead to PDPH in some cases. In epidural anesthesia, however, the anesthetic is administered outside the dura mater in the epidural space, reducing the risk of PDPH since the dura is not penetrated. If the epidural needle inadvertently punctures the dura, there is still a risk of PDPH, but this is generally lower than with spinal anesthesia.

 

Option D. More useful in postoperative pain relief: This statement is correct. Epidural anesthesia is particularly useful for postoperative pain management because an epidural catheter can be left in place for continuous or intermittent drug delivery. This allows for extended pain control, which is particularly beneficial for surgeries with expected postoperative pain. Spinal anesthesia, on the other hand, is typically a single injection that provides a finite duration of anesthesia and is not suitable for prolonged postoperative pain management.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Epidural anesthesia and spinal anesthesia have distinct characteristics. Spinal anesthesia acts more quickly and provides a denser block but is limited in duration. 
  • Epidural anesthesia has a slower onset and less density but is advantageous for extended postoperative pain control and has a lower risk of post-dural puncture headache.

Adding memantine to modulate glutamate transmission through NMDA receptor antagonism
Switching to rivastigmine to benefit from dual inhibition of both acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase
Adding acetyl-L-carnitine to provide antioxidant support and enhance cholinergic transmission

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with a diagnosis of moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease (AD) presents to her neurologist for follow-up. Her caregiver reports progressive cognitive decline despite the patient’s adherence to donepezil for the past year. The neurologist is considering adding a second agent to her regimen to target an alternative pathway that could further help manage her symptoms. In considering her case, which of the following therapeutic strategies would provide the most benefit while targeting a non-cholinergic pathway and avoiding potential hepatotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adding memantine to modulate glutamate transmission through NMDA receptor antagonism

 

  • Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist approved specifically for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. 
  • Unlike cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, which enhance cholinergic transmission, memantine targets the glutamatergic system by inhibiting excessive NMDA receptor activity. 
  • This helps to reduce excitotoxicity without the risks associated with hepatotoxicity or adding another acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.
  • In patients with moderate to severe AD who are already on a cholinesterase inhibitor, the addition of memantine provides a complementary mechanism of action and has been shown to improve symptoms or slow progression.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Adding tacrine to enhance cholinergic transmission through a different acetylcholinesterase inhibitor: Although tacrine was one of the first drugs used for AD, it is associated with significant hepatotoxicity and requires frequent dosing. Adding tacrine would not provide a different pathway for symptom management and carries increased risk without substantial benefit over existing cholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option C. Switching to rivastigmine to benefit from dual inhibition of both acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase: Rivastigmine inhibits both acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase, providing dual cholinergic support, which can be beneficial for mild to moderate dementia. However, this mechanism is similar to that of donepezil, and switching to rivastigmine would not add a different therapeutic pathway.

 

Option D. Adding acetyl-L-carnitine to provide antioxidant support and enhance cholinergic transmission: Acetyl-L-carnitine has shown some promise due to its antioxidant properties and potential cholinergic benefits. However, it lacks FDA approval and sufficient clinical evidence for use in moderate to severe AD, making it a less reliable option than memantine.

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease who are already on cholinesterase inhibitors, adding memantine provides an alternative mechanism of action by targeting NMDA receptors to reduce excitotoxicity, offering additional benefits in symptom management.

questions.text:
17. At the Primary Health Center (PHC) level, which of the following criteria are used for the diagnosis of diabetes according to the NPCDCS guidelines?

 

  1. HbA1C
  2. Fasting blood sugar ≥126 mg/dL
  3. Random blood sugar ≥200 mg/dL
  4. Capillary blood sugar post-prandial ≥220 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BD

 

  • According to NPCDCS guidelines at the PHC level, diabetes diagnosis primarily relies on fasting blood sugar (FBS) and post-prandial capillary blood sugar measurements:
  • Fasting Blood Sugar (FBS) ≥126 mg/dL is considered diagnostic for diabetes.
  • Capillary Blood Sugar post-prandial (after a meal) ≥220 mg/dL is also indicative of diabetes.
  • HbA1C testing is generally not part of the routine diagnostic criteria at the PHC level due to cost and accessibility constraints, and Random Blood Sugar (RBS) ≥200 mg/dL alone may warrant further testing but is not definitive without follow-up.

 

Other Options:

 

HbA1C: HbA1C is valuable in diagnosing and managing diabetes, but it is not widely used at the PHC level in resource-limited settings.

 

Random Blood Sugar ≥200 mg/dL: While this level may raise suspicion, it typically requires confirmatory testing (e.g., FBS or post-prandial) rather than being diagnostic on its own.

 

Capillary blood sugar post-prandial ≥220 mg/dL: Is used in PHCs for diabetes diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • At PHC level, diabetes diagnosis under NPCDCS guidelines relies on Fasting Blood Sugar (≥126 mg/dL) and Capillary Post-Prandial Blood Sugar (≥220 mg/dL) due to resource constraints. HbA1C and RBS are not primary criteria in this setting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presents to the clinic with ongoing joint pain and swelling. Recent laboratory findings reveal elevated levels of tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α). What is the primary role of TNF-α in the pathophysiology of RA?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stimulation of pro-inflammatory cytokine production

 

  • TNF-α is a key pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). 
  • It plays a critical role in promoting inflammation within the synovium by stimulating the production of other pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin-1 (IL-1) and interleukin-6 (IL-6), which lead to chronic inflammation and joint destruction. 
  • The presence of elevated TNF-α levels in patients with RA contributes to the inflammatory cycle, leading to persistent synovitis, pannus formation, and ultimately joint destruction. 
  • TNF-α is therefore targeted by several biologic therapies used in RA to mitigate inflammation and slow disease progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulation of T-cell proliferation: Incorrect. Although T-cell activation is involved in RA pathogenesis, TNF-α’s primary role is in cytokine signaling rather than directly stimulating T-cell proliferation. T-cells are activated by antigen-presenting cells and subsequently produce TNF-α, but TNF-α itself primarily promotes inflammation through cytokine signaling.

 

Option B. Stimulation of osteoblast activity: Incorrect. Osteoblast activity is not directly influenced by TNF-α in RA. TNF-α more commonly promotes osteoclast activity, leading to bone resorption and joint erosion rather than bone formation.

 

Option D. Inhibition of B-cell activation: Incorrect. TNF-α does not inhibit B-cell activation; rather, its inflammatory environment can promote immune cell activity, including B-cells. B-cell proliferation and activation may be indirectly supported within the inflamed synovium, but TNF-α’s direct role is primarily in stimulating cytokine production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TNF-α’s primary role in RA is to drive inflammation by promoting the release of other pro-inflammatory cytokines, which contributes to chronic joint inflammation and structural damage.

questions.text: The risk of fetal damage due to maternal rubella infection is highest if the mother contracts the infection during which stage of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6-12 weeks of pregnancy

 

  • The risk of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is highest when maternal rubella infection occurs in the early stages of pregnancy, particularly within the first trimester (6-12 weeks). 
  • During this period, the developing organs are most vulnerable, and rubella can lead to severe fetal abnormalities, including heart defects, hearing impairment, and vision issues. 
  • The risk decreases as pregnancy progresses, with infections later in pregnancy being less likely to cause significant fetal damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The highest risk for fetal damage from maternal rubella infection occurs during the first trimester, particularly between 6-12 weeks, due to the critical stages of organ development during this period.

Elective clinical presentation is usually in the form of a lump arising from the liver
Anaphylactic shock due to rupture of the hydatid cyst is the emergency presentation
