questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about hydatid cyst disease in humans:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pericystectomy is the preferred treatment for hydatid cyst

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The preferred treatment for active cysts is PAIR procedure.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Elective clinical presentation is usually in the form of a painful lump arising from the liver: Hydatid cysts can indeed present as a lump or mass in the liver, which may or may not be painful. The presentation can vary from asymptomatic to causing discomfort due to the mass effect.

 

Option C. Anaphylactic shock due to rupture of the hydatid cyst is the emergency presentation: Rupture of a hydatid cyst can lead to anaphylactic shock, which is a severe allergic reaction and is considered an emergency presentation. This statement is correct.

 

Option D. CT scan is the diagnostic test: CT scans are highly effective in the imaging and diagnosis of hydatid cysts, providing detailed images that help in identifying the characteristic features of the cysts, such as their outline and internal structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment of hydatid cyst involves pre operative albendazole followed by PAIR procedure. If contraindicated, peri-cystectomy is done.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with mild dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain that started 2 hours ago. She denies any history of recent trauma, surgery, or prior thromboembolic events. She is a non-smoker and does not use oral contraceptives. On examination, her heart rate is 88/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. In a low-risk patient like this, which set of clinical criteria can help avoid unnecessary imaging by ruling out pulmonary embolism without further testing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PERC – pulmonary Embolism rule-out criteria


The Pulmonary Embolism Rule-Out Criteria (PERC) are specifically designed for low-risk patients to rule out pulmonary embolism without additional testing. If all PERC criteria are met, the probability of PE is low enough that no further diagnostic workup is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Well's criteria: The Well's criteria stratify the pretest probability of PE and guide further testing but do not directly rule out PE like PERC in low-risk patients.

 

Option B. Geneva score: The Geneva score, like Well's criteria, estimates pretest probability but does not provide definitive rule-out capability without further testing.

 

Option D. D-dimer assay: A D-dimer test is often used to rule out PE in low-risk patients but is unnecessary if the PERC criteria are satisfied.

 

Educational Objective:


The PERC criteria are a simple and effective way to rule out pulmonary embolism in low-risk patients, reducing the need for further testing when all 8 criteria are met.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is started on an anticoagulant therapy that requires aPTT monitoring and is excreted by the kidneys. The physician is cautious about dosing due to the drug's lack of an antidote and the patient's moderate renal insufficiency. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor derived from hirudin, used in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). 
  • It is unique among anticoagulants because it requires aPTT monitoring due to its direct thrombin inhibition, and it is primarily excreted by the kidneys. 
  • This renal excretion profile requires caution in patients with renal insufficiency, as there is no available antidote for lepirudin in case of overdose or bleeding complications. 
  • Its production has been discontinued, but it is notable for these properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: A low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that inhibits factor Xa and does not require aPTT monitoring. It is typically used without intensive monitoring.

 

Option B. Fondaparinux: A synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits factor Xa, also not requiring aPTT monitoring. It is often used in HIT due to its low cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: An oral direct thrombin inhibitor that does not require aPTT monitoring and is mainly used for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation and VTE prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor requiring aPTT monitoring and careful dosing in renal impairment, used historically in patients with HIT.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a health promotion strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemoprophylaxis

 

  • Health promotion strategies focus on enhancing overall health and preventing disease through lifestyle changes, environmental improvements, and health education. 
  • Chemoprophylaxis involves administering drugs to prevent specific infections, which falls under specific protection rather than health promotion. 
  • Health promotion generally does not involve medication but emphasizes sustainable changes in behavior, environment, and access to resources that improve health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insecticides spray: Helps control vector-borne diseases by reducing insect populations, contributing to a healthier environment as part of health promotion.

 

Option B. Potable safe water supply: Ensures access to clean drinking water, a key factor in preventing waterborne diseases and promoting public health.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modification: Includes changes in diet, exercise, and other habits that reduce the risk of chronic diseases, aligning directly with health promotion.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Health promotion strategies aim to improve general health through sustainable practices and environmental adjustments, while specific protections like chemoprophylaxis target particular diseases using medical interventions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoes a surgical procedure for evacuation of retained products of conception after experiencing an incomplete abortion. The instrument shown in the image is used during the procedure. Which of the following findings indicates that the procedure is complete?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A grating sensation on all four uterine walls

 

  • During uterine evacuation procedures, such as in cases of incomplete abortion, a curette (as shown in the image) is used to remove any remaining products of conception from the uterine cavity. 
  • When all products have been successfully removed, the curette comes into direct contact with the uterine wall, producing a "grating" or "scraping" sensation. 
  • Feeling this grating sensation on all four uterine walls (anterior, posterior, and both lateral sides) indicates that no remaining tissue is present and the procedure is complete.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A grating sensation on the anterior uterine wall: While a grating sensation on the anterior wall may suggest that the anterior portion of the uterine cavity is clear, it does not confirm that the uterus is fully evacuated. All four walls must be evaluated to confirm completeness.

 

Option B. A grating sensation on the posterior uterine wall: Feeling this sensation only on the posterior wall indicates partial evacuation but does not confirm that all tissue has been removed from the entire uterine cavity.

 

Option C. A grating sensation on the lateral uterine walls: Feeling the grating sensation on just the lateral walls similarly indicates partial evacuation. Complete evacuation is only confirmed when the grating sensation is felt on all four walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In uterine evacuation procedures for incomplete abortion, the procedure is considered complete when a "grating" sensation is felt on all four uterine walls, indicating no remaining products of conception.

questions.text: Which of these systems is used to classify GE junction tumors based on location of epicenter?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sievert

 

  • The Siewert classification is specifically designed to classify gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) tumors based on the location of the tumor’s epicenter relative to the anatomical cardia (where the esophagus meets the stomach). It divides GE junction tumors into three types:
    • Type I: Tumor located 1-5 cm above the GE junction, typically an esophageal adenocarcinoma.
    • Type II: Tumor located within 1 cm above to 2 cm below the GE junction, often considered a true GE junction tumor.
    • Type III: Tumor located 2-5 cm below the GE junction, often arising from the gastric cardia.
  • This classification is crucial for determining the surgical approach and treatment strategy for GE junction tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Truelove and Witt: The Truelove and Witt classification is not related to gastroesophageal junction tumors. It is a classification system used to assess the severity of ulcerative colitis based on symptoms such as the number of bowel movements, presence of blood in the stool, and systemic signs (like fever and anemia).

 

Option B. Los Angeles: The Los Angeles classification is used to evaluate the severity of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) based on endoscopic findings. It categorizes esophagitis based on the extent of mucosal breaks in the esophagus, helping clinicians assess the degree of esophageal inflammation due to acid reflux. While it pertains to the esophagus, it does not classify tumors of the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Option C. Chicago: The Chicago classification is used in the assessment of esophageal motility disorders, specifically for diagnosing and categorizing types of achalasia based on high-resolution manometry findings. Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and loss of peristalsis. This classification helps identify different subtypes of achalasia, not tumors at the GE junction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Siewert classification is used to classify gastroesophageal (GE) junction tumors based on their anatomical location, helping guide treatment decisions. 
  • Other classifications, like Truelove and Witt, Los Angeles, and Chicago, are specific to different conditions: ulcerative colitis, GERD, and esophageal motility disorders, respectively.

questions.text: An 18-month-old female child is brought to the hospital due to recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. The first incident happened at 13 months, noticed by her mother, a nurse, who observed symptoms like lethargy, prolonged sleep, and irritability. On admission, her blood glucose was 30 mg/dl, and she has had five similar episodes since then, requiring treatment with high dextrose (D25%), octreotide, and glucagon. Each time, her blood glucose was critically low (20-40 mg/dl) with a high insulin level (3500-4000 pmol/L). During this hospital stay, needle marks were observed on both of her deltoids, and she appeared unusually calm during injections. C-peptide levels were checked and found to be nearly negligible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy

 

  • The child’s recurrent hypoglycemic episodes with elevated insulin levels but negligible C-peptide levels indicate exogenous insulin administration. 
  • Normally, if insulin is produced endogenously (within the body), as in conditions like insulinoma or congenital hyperinsulinism, both insulin and C-peptide are elevated since C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin synthesis in the pancreas. 
  • However, in this case, high insulin is present with very low or negligible C-peptide, strongly suggesting that the insulin is coming from an external source, ruling out options (b) Insulinoma and (c) Congenital hyperinsulinism.
  • The presence of needle marks, combined with the child's calm response to injections, raises concern for Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy (MSBP). 
  • In MSBP, a caregiver—often a parent—induces or fabricates symptoms in a dependent (usually a child) to seek attention or sympathy from healthcare providers. 
  • In this case, the mother, who is a nurse, may be administering insulin to her child to create hypoglycemic episodes, fitting the diagnosis of MSBP rather than Munchausen Syndrome (d), which involves self-induced illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulinoma and C. Congenital hyperinsulinism: Both would show elevated insulin with elevated C-peptide levels, as they involve endogenous insulin production.

 

Option D. Munchausen Syndrome: This refers to self-inflicted symptoms, not causing symptoms in another individual, and is therefore not applicable here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When encountering unexplained hypoglycemia in a pediatric patient with elevated insulin and negligible C-peptide, consider exogenous insulin administration. 
  • Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy should be suspected if a caregiver appears to be inducing or fabricating symptoms in a child, especially if there are physical signs like needle marks and a history of recurrent, unexplained symptoms.

questions.text: One specific amino acid in collagen synthesis does not require aminoacyl-tRNA for incorporation into the protein chain but is instead added as a post-translational modification. Which amino acid is this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydroxyproline

 

  • Hydroxyproline is an amino acid that plays a critical role in collagen synthesis. 
  • It is not directly incorporated into proteins during translation. Instead, proline residues are hydroxylated post-translationally to form hydroxyproline, a process that does not involve aminoacyl-tRNA. 
  • This modification is essential for stabilizing the collagen triple helix structure by enabling hydrogen bonding. 
  • The hydroxylation of proline to hydroxyproline requires vitamin C as a cofactor, which explains why vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) impairs collagen synthesis and leads to connective tissue disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid used in the initiation of protein synthesis as the start codon (AUG). It requires aminoacyl-tRNA for incorporation into proteins and is not involved in collagen's post-translational modifications.

 

Option B. Lysine: Is another amino acid that can undergo post-translational modification in collagen synthesis, such as hydroxylation to form hydroxylysine. However, lysine itself is initially incorporated into the protein chain by aminoacyl-tRNA, unlike hydroxyproline, which is added post-translationally.

 

Option D. Cysteine: Is incorporated into proteins via aminoacyl-tRNA. While it contributes to the structural integrity of some proteins through disulfide bond formation, it is not specifically involved in collagen’s unique post-translational modifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydroxyproline in collagen synthesis is unique because it is formed through the hydroxylation of proline after the polypeptide chain is synthesized, and it does not require aminoacyl-tRNA. 
  • This modification is essential for collagen stability and requires vitamin C, highlighting the importance of this nutrient in maintaining connective tissue health.

questions.text: Health authorities are implementing a smoking cessation program with a series of activities aimed at reducing smoking rates, despite the high cost of the program. The program aims to reduce lung cancer incidence by preventing smoking. What measure can best indicate the proportion of lung cancer cases that could be prevented if smoking were eliminated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Population Attributable fraction 

 

  • The Population Attributable Fraction (PAF) quantifies the proportion of disease cases in a population that can be attributed to a specific risk factor—in this case, smoking. 
  • It estimates the potential reduction in disease incidence if the risk factor were eliminated. For lung cancer, the PAF indicates the percentage of cases that could be prevented by eradicating smoking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relative risk: Measures the strength of the association between exposure (smoking) and outcome (lung cancer) but does not indicate the proportion of cases attributable to the exposure.

 

Option B. Attributable risk: Refers to the difference in incidence rates between exposed and unexposed groups, indicating the excess risk due to the exposure.

 

Option D. Incidence density: Represents the rate at which new cases occur in a population over a specified time period, without attributing cases to specific risk factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Population Attributable Fraction is a crucial measure in public health, as it helps determine the impact of eliminating a risk factor on disease incidence within a population.

questions.text: Life cycle Image of an organism is given below. Identify the disease associated with this life cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crimean Congo fever

 

  • The life cycle depicted involves ticks, animals (such as ungulates), and humans, which is characteristic of Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF). CCHF is a viral disease primarily transmitted to humans through tick bites or contact with infected animal blood or tissues. 
  • The disease can also spread through human-to-human transmission in healthcare settings (nosocomial transmission), making it a significant health risk, especially for healthcare workers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dengue: Dengue is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, not ticks, and does not involve a complex life cycle with animals or nosocomial transmission.

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD): KFD is also tick-borne, but it primarily involves transmission from monkeys to humans and lacks a similar nosocomial transmission pattern.

 

Option D. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is spread by Aedes mosquitoes and primarily involves human-to-mosquito-to-human transmission without a complex animal cycle or tick involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) involves a complex transmission cycle including ticks, animals, and human-to-human transmission in healthcare settings, distinguishing it from other vector-borne diseases.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 31 weeks of gestation comes to the emergency department with sudden abdominal pain that has lasted for 2 hours. Her blood pressure is recorded at 160/100 mmHg. On examination, she appears pale, and the uterus measures larger than expected at 36 weeks of size and is notably tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abruption

 

  • This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, which can result in bleeding within the uterine cavity. 
  • The presentation of acute abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, a fundal height larger than expected for gestational age, and hypertension (blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg) are classic findings in placental abruption. 
  • Pallor in this patient further suggests blood loss, and the increased uterine size might reflect concealed hemorrhage. 
  • Abruption is more common in patients with hypertensive disorders, making this condition the most probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyhydramnios: This condition involves an excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid. Polyhydramnios can cause an abnormally large uterus and may present with abdominal discomfort. However, it is less likely to cause the acute tenderness and pain seen here, and it would not typically be associated with hypertension or pallor.

 

Option B. Red degeneration of fibroid: Red degeneration is a painful condition that can occur in pregnant women with fibroids. It may present with localized uterine tenderness, but it typically lacks the association with hypertension and would not usually result in a uterine size discrepancy or pallor due to hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Multiple pregnancy: Multiple pregnancies (twins or more) could indeed cause an increased uterine size. However, multiple gestations do not usually present with acute pain, uterine tenderness, or high blood pressure. Furthermore, pallor would not be expected unless there were significant complications such as bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placental abruption should be suspected in a pregnant patient presenting with acute abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, hypertension, and signs of blood loss, especially if there is a discrepancy in the uterine size for gestational age.

questions.text: A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman with severe osteoporosis has been prescribed a medication that stimulates bone formation. The medication is administered once daily via subcutaneous injection, and her doctor instructs her to rotate the injection sites. Which of the following is a serious adverse effect associated with this medication that limits its duration of use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog used in the treatment of severe osteoporosis to stimulate new bone formation. 
  • It is given as a once-daily subcutaneous injection and is one of the few anabolic agents for osteoporosis. 
  • Teriparatide has a black-box warning due to the risk of osteosarcoma, a rare but serious adverse effect observed in animal studies. This risk limits its recommended duration of use to no more than 2 years, especially in patients with increased baseline risk factors for osteosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypercalcemia: Hypercalcemia is a known side effect of teriparatide, but it does not limit the duration of therapy like the risk of osteosarcoma.

 

Option C. Nephrolithiasis: Teriparatide may exacerbate nephrolithiasis, but this is not a reason to limit therapy duration.

 

Option D. Elevated serum uric acid levels: Teriparatide can increase uric acid levels, which may be monitored but is not a serious enough effect to restrict duration.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Teriparatide is limited to a maximum of 2 years of use due to the potential risk of osteosarcoma, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions.

questions.text: A data analyst is examining the distribution of income levels within a specific population and notes that the distribution is positively skewed due to a few very high income values. Which statistical measure is most likely to be overestimated in this positively skewed dataset?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Mean

 

  • In a positively skewed distribution, the presence of a few extreme high values pulls the mean to the right, making it larger than the median and mode. 
  • This results in an overestimation of the central tendency if only the mean is considered, as it is more sensitive to outliers in skewed data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median: The median is less affected by extreme values and remains closer to the center of the dataset, making it a more accurate measure of central tendency in skewed data.

 

Option C. Mode: Representing the most frequently occurring value, is not influenced by extreme values and thus provides a stable measure in skewed distributions.

 

Option D. Correlation: Correlation does not directly measure central tendency and is not impacted by skewed data in the same way as measures like the mean.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In positively skewed distributions, the mean is disproportionately affected by outliers and can give an overestimated sense of the dataset’s central tendency.

choices.text: Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15.
It is characterized by childhood obesity and hypotonia.
Prader-Willi syndrome typically presents with precocious puberty.
Patients with Prader-Willi syndrome often have delayed puberty and growth failure.

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements regarding Prader-Willi syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prader-Willi syndrome typically presents with precocious puberty.

 

  • Prader-Willi syndrome is actually associated with delayed puberty, not precocious puberty. 
  • Precocious puberty refers to the early onset of puberty, which is not characteristic of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15: Correct. Prader-Willi syndrome is indeed caused by a genetic deletion on the paternal chromosome 15, which is a result of genomic imprinting.

 

Option B. It is characterized by childhood obesity and hypotonia: Correct. Childhood obesity and hypotonia (low muscle tone) are hallmark features of Prader-Willi syndrome, often evident in early childhood.

 

Option D. Patients with Prader-Willi syndrome often have delayed puberty and growth failure: Correct. Delayed puberty and growth failure are common in Prader-Willi syndrome, often leading to short stature and delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by a genetic deletion on the paternal chromosome 15, leading to features such as hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems. 
  • It does not present with precocious puberty; rather, puberty is typically delayed.

questions.text: A phenotypically female child with ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly is brought to the clinic. On examination, she is found to have hypertension. A karyotype analysis is as given below. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 17 alpha hydroxylase

 

Karyotype Interpretation:

 

  • The karyotype shows a 46, XY chromosomal pattern, indicating that the child is genetically male.

 

Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Despite the 46, XY karyotype, the patient presents with ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly, suggesting undervirilization.
  • The presence of hypertension is a crucial clue in identifying the specific enzyme deficiency.

 

Diagnosis: 17 alpha hydroxylase Deficiency:

 

  • 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency results in impaired production of sex steroids and cortisol.
  • This deficiency leads to decreased androgen synthesis, causing undervirilization in genotypic males (46, XY) and potentially ambiguous genitalia.
  • Additionally, this defect causes an accumulation of mineralocorticoid precursors, leading to hypertension due to increased mineralocorticoid activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 21-hydroxylase deficiency: Commonly causes congenital adrenal hyperplasia with increased androgen production, resulting in virilization, not undervirilization, and typically does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. 11β-hydroxylase deficiency: Can cause hypertension due to 11-deoxycorticosterone buildup, but it typically leads to increased androgens, causing virilization, which contradicts the presentation here.

 

Option D. 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency: Causes low levels of all steroids (androgens, cortisol, and mineralocorticoids) but does not specifically cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In a 46, XY patient presenting with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension, and features of undervirilization, 17,20 lyase (or 17-hydroxylase) deficiency is the most likely diagnosis. 
  • This enzyme deficiency leads to reduced androgen production (causing undervirilization) and increased mineralocorticoid activity (resulting in hypertension).

choices.text: Apical segment of right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department with 5-days history of fever and productive cough. He reports difficulty breathing and right-sided chest pain. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), and auscultation reveals crepitations on the right side. The chest X-ray is shown below. What is the correct finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right middle lobe consolidation

 

  • The chest X-ray demonstrates an area of increased opacity in the right middle lobe, indicative of consolidation. 
  • This is consistent with pneumonia, given the patient’s symptoms of fever, productive cough, and right-sided chest pain, along with crepitations on auscultation. 
  • The chest X-ray showing opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.
  • Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. 
  • In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. 
  • In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.

 

 

  • The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.
  • The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apical segment of right lower lobe consolidation: The apical segment of the right lower lobe is not the typical location for pneumonia, which is usually seen in the middle or lower lobes. The X-ray does not show consolidation in the apical segment.

 

Option C. Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation: This would present as increased opacity in the lower part of the lung field, not in the middle part as seen in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Loculated pleural effusion: This condition would appear as a localized fluid collection with a distinct edge, such as a meniscus sign, which is not observed in this X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Right middle lobe consolidation is indicative of pneumonia, characterized by symptoms such as fever, productive cough, and crepitations, confirmed by a chest X-ray showing localized opacity in the right middle lobe.

choices.text: Emerges from the Medial Border of Psoas Major
The Anterior Branch of this nerve contributes to Patellar Plexus

questions.text: A 51-year-old female presents with pain, tingling, and numbness over the upper thigh. Upon examination, the neurologist identifies the condition as meralgia paresthetica. Which of the following statements is true about the nerve responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Anterior Branch of this nerve contributes to Patellar Plexus

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica is caused by compression or entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, which is purely a sensory nerve. 
  • This nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L3) and typically passes beneath the inguinal ligament, near the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS). 
  • While the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve primarily provides sensation to the anterolateral thigh, the anterior branch of this nerve also contributes to the patellar plexus, providing sensory innervation around the patellar area.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It arises from Sacral Plexus: The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve arises from the lumbar plexus, specifically from the L2 and L3 nerve roots, not the sacral plexus.

 

Option B. Emerges from the Medial Border of Psoas Major: The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve typically emerges from the lateral border of the psoas major muscle, not the medial border.

 

Option C. Passes beneath Fascia Iliaca: While the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve does pass beneath the inguinal ligament, it is not commonly described as passing beneath the fascia iliaca.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, responsible for meralgia paresthetica, arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L3) and the anterior branch of this nerve contributes to the patellar plexus, providing sensory innervation to the anterolateral thigh and around the patellar area.

choices.text: Celiac disease is associated with HLA DQ6.
Marsh criteria are used for diagnosis.
IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are commonly found.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of chronic diarrhea and weight loss is undergoing evaluation for possible celiac disease. Laboratory results show positive serology for celiac-specific antibodies. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Celiac disease is associated with HLA DQ6.


Celiac disease is primarily associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DQ6. 

 

The presence of these HLA markers is significant for genetic susceptibility to celiac disease, as nearly all individuals with celiac disease carry one of these alleles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-gliadin antibodies are often present: While anti-gliadin antibodies were previously used as a marker for celiac disease, they are now considered less specific than anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies. However, they may still be present in some individuals with celiac disease.

 

Option C. Marsh criteria are used for diagnosis: This is correct. The Marsh classification system describes the histological stages of small intestinal mucosal damage in celiac disease, which ranges from mild inflammation to complete villous atrophy.

 

Option D. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are commonly found: This is also correct. IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are highly specific and sensitive for celiac disease and are the preferred initial serological test for its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Celiac disease is strongly associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 alleles, not HLA-DQ6.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department with joint pain, dizziness, and skin rash after returning from a diving trip. He reports that he surfaced rapidly after a deep dive. His symptoms began shortly after he left the water. Physical examination reveals a patchy rash and tenderness in multiple joints. Based on his history, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysbarism

 

  • Dysbarism refers to a spectrum of medical conditions caused by the changes in ambient pressure experienced during diving or flying. In this case, the patient’s rapid ascent after a deep dive resulted in decompression sickness, a form of dysbarism. Nitrogen dissolved in the blood during the dive forms bubbles when there is a rapid reduction in pressure, leading to symptoms such as joint pain, dizziness, fatigue, and skin rash (known as “the bends”). Immediate management involves supplemental oxygen and possibly hyperbaric oxygen therapy to reduce nitrogen bubbles and enhance reabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Mountain sickness: Incorrect. Acute mountain sickness occurs due to reduced oxygen pressure at high altitudes and is characterized by headache, nausea, dizziness, and shortness of breath. It is unrelated to rapid pressure changes experienced during diving.

 

Option C. Hypothermia: Incorrect. While hypothermia is a risk during diving in cold water, this patient’s symptoms (joint pain, rash, and dizziness after a rapid ascent) are more consistent with decompression sickness, a form of dysbarism.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Incorrect. Although pulmonary embolism may cause shortness of breath and chest pain, it does not typically present with joint pain or a skin rash following a diving trip. The history of rapid ascent suggests dysbarism rather than embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dysbarism refers to a group of conditions caused by changes in ambient pressure, such as decompression sickness, which occurs after a rapid ascent from a deep dive. Symptoms may include joint pain, rash, dizziness, and fatigue due to nitrogen bubble formation in the blood.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with generalized lymphadenopathy and significant weight loss over the past 3 months. A biopsy of a lymph node is performed, and the histological image is given below. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for CD30. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL)

 

  • Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL) is a type of T-cell lymphoma that often presents with systemic symptoms such as weight loss, fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy.
  •  It is characterized by large, atypical cells, often with horseshoe-shaped nuclei, known as "Hallmark cells," which can be seen in the provided image. Immunohistochemical staining for CD30 is a key diagnostic feature of ALCL. 
  • The presence of these features supports the diagnosis of ALCL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells, which are large, atypical cells with a characteristic "owl-eye" appearance. This differs from the hallmark cells seen in ALCL.

 

Option C. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL): DLBCL is a B-cell lymphoma that is usually negative for CD30 staining and does not exhibit the hallmark cells seen in ALCL. DLBCL presents with sheets of large B-cells rather than the pleomorphic cells typical of ALCL.

 

Option D. Burkitt lymphoma: Burkitt lymphoma is known for its "starry sky" appearance due to high mitotic activity and apoptotic cell debris. It typically involves the jaw or abdomen in endemic cases and is associated with EBV infection. It does not show CD30 positivity or the hallmark cells characteristic of ALCL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL) is a T-cell lymphoma that is positive for CD30 and characterized by large, pleomorphic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei (Hallmark cells).

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is being evaluated for syncope. Holter monitoring reveals intermittent sinus pauses suggestive of dysfunction in the cardiac pacemaker cells. The pacemaker cells contain unique ion channels that contribute to their automaticity. Two statements are presented about these channels: 

 

  • Statement A: The f (funny) channels are present in cardiac pacemaker cells.
  • Statement B: The f (funny) channels become activated after depolarization, leading to the action potential.

 

Which of the following is correct regarding these statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement A is true, and Statement B is false

 

  • Statement A is true: The funny channels, also known as If channels, are unique ion channels found in cardiac pacemaker cells, particularly in the sinoatrial (SA) node. These channels play a crucial role in initiating the pacemaker potential, leading to spontaneous depolarization and automaticity.
  • Statement B is incorrect because the funny channels are activated during hyperpolarization (not after depolarization). Following the repolarization phase, these channels open and allow a slow inward flow of sodium ions, leading to the gradual depolarization of pacemaker cells until the threshold for an action potential is reached.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The funny (f) channels in cardiac pacemaker cells are activated by hyperpolarization, allowing slow inward sodium currents that lead to gradual depolarization and automaticity.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after he experienced excessive bleeding following a minor fall. The parents report that the boy often bruises easily and has prolonged bleeding after minor injuries or dental procedures. He has no significant family history of bleeding disorders, but his maternal uncle has similar symptoms. Laboratory tests show an increased partial thromboplastin time (PTT) with normal prothrombin time (PT). What could be the probable mode of inheritance of this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) XLR 

 

The clinical case given is the case of a Hemophilia A, and the pattern of inheritance seen in Hemophilia is XLR. 

 

Deficiency of factor VIII.

 

C/F:

 

            •          ﻿﻿Family history

            •          ﻿﻿Bleeding/Bruising

            •          ﻿﻿Hemarthrosis (ankle > knee)

 

Pathology: Intrinsic pathway is affected-prolonged aPPT (Normal PT, BT, Platelet count).

 

 

Note that X-linked recessive inheritance means that the gene for the disorder is located on the X chromosome, and males are typically more severely affected since they only have one X chromosome. Females who inherit one copy of the mutated gene are usually carriers and may have milder symptoms or be asymptomatic. Autosomal recessive inheritance means that both parents must carry a copy of the mutated gene for their child to be affected, and the disorder affects males and females equally. Acquired haemophilia is not inherited and can occur in anyone, regardless of their family history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in clotting factor VIII.

questions.text:
Biochemical mechanisms of drug resistance are shown in the given image. 

 

 

The efflux mechanism (E) is a major mode of bacterial resistance against which of the following antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetracyclines

 

  • Efflux pumps are one of the primary mechanisms by which bacteria develop resistance to tetracyclines. 
  • These pumps actively transport tetracycline molecules out of the bacterial cell, reducing intracellular concentrations and rendering the antibiotic ineffective. Efflux-mediated resistance is a well-documented mechanism in both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria for tetracycline resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: While efflux pumps can contribute to chloramphenicol resistance, enzymatic inactivation via chloramphenicol acetyltransferase is more common.

 

Option C. Ampicillin: Resistance to ampicillin is typically due to beta-lactamase production (enzymatic degradation) rather than efflux pumps.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: Resistance to ciprofloxacin is usually due to mutations in DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV (target site modification) and sometimes through efflux pumps, but efflux is not the major mechanism.

 

Educational Objective

 

Efflux pumps are a primary mechanism of bacterial resistance to tetracyclines, actively transporting the drug out of the cell to reduce its efficacy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida in early labor arrives at the emergency department. She has regular, adequate uterine contractions, and a recent rupture of membranes. On vaginal examination, her pelvis is gynecoid, and the fetus is in the right occipito-posterior (ROP) position with the vertex presenting. What is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal vaginal delivery

 

  • The right occipito-posterior (ROP) position is a common fetal position during labor, where the fetal occiput is directed towards the mother’s right posterior side. 
  • Although ROP is not the ideal position (occiput anterior being preferred), many fetuses in this position will rotate to an occiput anterior position as labor progresses. 
  • Since the patient has a gynecoid pelvis, which is favorable for vaginal delivery, and she is in early labor with adequate contractions, the management approach should be to allow labor to continue naturally. 
  • Monitoring the progression of labor is essential, but there is no indication for operative delivery at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: Cesarean section is not indicated for a vertex presentation in an otherwise normal labor with a favorable pelvic type (gynecoid). Cesarean is typically reserved for cases of fetal distress, labor arrest, or other complications.

 

Option C. Forceps delivery: Forceps-assisted delivery may be considered in specific cases of prolonged second stage of labor, maternal exhaustion, or fetal distress when the head is low enough in the birth canal. However, this is not indicated in early labor without signs of fetal or maternal distress.

 

Option D. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Like forceps, vacuum-assisted delivery is generally used in the second stage of labor for specific indications such as maternal exhaustion or fetal distress. This intervention is not appropriate in early labor with no complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fetus in the occipito-posterior position with adequate contractions and a favorable pelvic type (gynecoid) can often achieve a normal vaginal delivery without immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a high spiking fever, a salmon-colored maculopapular rash, and symmetric arthritis involving the wrists and knees. She has also experienced significant fatigue and a sore throat over the past few weeks. Laboratory results reveal an elevated ESR (80 mm/hr), an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). Which of the following will be markedly elevated, given the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ferritin

 

This patient's presentation, including high spiking fever, salmon-colored maculopapular rash, symmetric arthritis, and elevated ESR and CRP, is highly suggestive of Adult-Onset Still’s Disease (AOSD). A key laboratory finding in AOSD is markedly elevated ferritin levels, which reflect systemic inflammation and are a hallmark of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): ANA is typically negative in Adult-Onset Still’s Disease. Positive ANA is more commonly seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases, not in AOSD.

 

Option B. Rheumatoid factor (RF): Rheumatoid factor is usually negative in AOSD. It is often positive in rheumatoid arthritis, but this patient’s presentation with fever, rash, and elevated ferritin suggests AOSD rather than rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies: Anti-CCP antibodies are typically positive in rheumatoid arthritis, not in AOSD. This patient's symptoms and lab results are more consistent with AOSD, which does not feature anti-CCP positivity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Markedly elevated ferritin is a distinguishing feature of Adult-Onset Still’s Disease and serves as an important diagnostic clue. It helps differentiate AOSD from other systemic inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis or lupus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman, presented to the OPD with back pain. Initial screening shows serum calcium levels of 11.7mg%, Vit. D is 55 ng/ml and elevated PTH. What might be the most common cause of such clinical manifestations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parathyroid Adenoma

 

Elevated serum calcium and PTH with normal Vit. D Levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Causes:

 

i. PTH secreting adenoma: M/C cause

 

ii. Multiglandular hyperplasia: seen in MEN syndrome

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tumor lysis syndrome: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a condition typically seen in patients undergoing treatment for high-burden tumors, such as lymphomas or leukemias, where rapid cell destruction releases large amounts of intracellular contents, including potassium, phosphate, and uric acid, into the bloodstream. Hypercalcemia is not characteristic of TLS; in fact, TLS may even cause hypocalcemia due to the precipitation of calcium with phosphate. Additionally, elevated PTH is not a feature of TLS, making this option incorrect in the context of this case.

 

Option C. Secondary hyperparathyroidism: Secondary hyperparathyroidism typically occurs as a compensatory response to chronic hypocalcemia, often due to Vitamin D deficiency or chronic kidney disease. In secondary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated, but serum calcium levels are usually low or normal, not elevated as in this patient. Therefore, this option does not fit the clinical picture, as elevated calcium with elevated PTH is not characteristic of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option D. Multiglandular Parathyroid hyperplasia: Multiglandular parathyroid hyperplasia is a less common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism and is often associated with genetic conditions such as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) syndromes. While it can cause primary hyperparathyroidism, it is not the most common cause. Parathyroid adenomas are far more common as the cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. Therefore, while this option could potentially fit the clinical scenario, it is not the most likely answer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Elevated serum calcium and PTH with normal Vitamin D levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma. 
  • Recognizing this pattern helps in identifying the underlying cause and differentiating it from other causes of hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with sensory loss along the medial side of the leg and foot after undergoing surgery for varicose veins. Based on this sensory deficit, which nerve is most likely to have been injured during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saphenous nerve

 

  • The saphenous nerve is a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies the medial aspect of the leg and foot. 
  • During varicose vein surgery, the saphenous nerve can be inadvertently damaged due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein. 
  • Injury to this nerve would result in sensory loss in the medial part of the leg and foot.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial peroneal nerve: This nerve provides sensory innervation to the lower lateral leg and dorsum of the foot. It does not innervate the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: This nerve provides sensory innervation to the web space between the first and second toes and is involved in motor innervation of the anterior compartment of the leg. It does not affect the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option D. Sural nerve: This nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the lower leg and foot. It is not responsible for sensation in the medial leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The saphenous nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the medial aspect of the leg and foot. 
  • It can be injured during varicose vein surgery, leading to sensory loss in its distribution area.
