Pulse methylprednisolone 250 mg four times daily for three days

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the right brow after a fall from a scooter and now presents with sudden loss of vision in the right eye. Examination reveals an absent direct light reflex in the right pupil but a normal consensual light reflex. The fundus appears normal. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emergency optic canal decompression

 

  • The presentation of absent direct light reflex with a normal consensual light reflex suggests optic nerve injury, likely due to compression or trauma resulting from the brow injury. 
  • In this scenario, emergency optic canal decompression is indicated to relieve the pressure on the optic nerve, as this could potentially restore vision or prevent further damage. 
  • The normal fundus finding indicates that the retinal structure is intact, reinforcing the likelihood of an optic nerve issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intensive intravenous corticosteroids as prescribed for spinal injuries, to be started within six hours: This treatment is used primarily for spinal cord injuries and may not be effective in acute optic nerve compression scenarios.

 

Option B. Pulse methylprednisolone 250 mg four times daily for three days: While corticosteroids can reduce inflammation, they may not be sufficient in cases of mechanical compression of the optic nerve, where surgical decompression is often required.

 

Option C. Oral prednisolone 1.5 mg/kg body weight: Oral corticosteroids might help in mild cases of inflammation but are not appropriate for acute, traumatic optic nerve compression requiring immediate intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of acute optic nerve compression with sudden vision loss following trauma, emergency optic canal decompression is the treatment of choice to prevent permanent optic nerve damage and potentially restore vision.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not typically used for neuromuscular monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Saphenous nerve

 

  • The saphenous nerve is a purely sensory nerve and does not have any motor function.
  • It does not innervate any muscles, so it cannot produce a muscle response when stimulated. 
  • Since neuromuscular monitoring relies on observing muscle contractions, the saphenous nerve is unsuitable for this purpose. 
  • This is why it is not used in neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior tibial nerve: The posterior tibial nerve is commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring. It is a motor nerve that supplies the flexor hallucis brevis muscle, which allows for muscle contractions in response to nerve stimulation. By stimulating this nerve and observing the muscle response, anesthesiologists can assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and monitor its reversal.

 

Option B. Facial nerve: The facial nerve is another commonly used nerve in neuromuscular monitoring, especially in the head and neck region. It innervates muscles such as the orbicularis oculi (around the eye) and the corrugator supercilii (in the forehead). Monitoring these muscles can provide an indication of neuromuscular function, particularly useful when monitoring is needed in the upper body. The facial nerve is often used because responses here can sometimes recover sooner than those in peripheral muscles.

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve is one of the most frequently used nerves for neuromuscular monitoring. It supplies the adductor pollicis muscle (in the hand), which produces a visible muscle contraction when the nerve is stimulated. The ulnar nerve is typically chosen because the adductor pollicis muscle is easy to observe and provides a reliable indication of the depth and recovery of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Neuromuscular monitoring requires a motor nerve to stimulate a muscle response, which helps assess the degree of muscle relaxation or recovery from neuromuscular blockade.
  • The posterior tibial, facial, and ulnar nerves are commonly used because they innervate muscles, whereas the saphenous nerve is purely sensory and unsuitable for neuromuscular monitoring.

choices.text: Amino acid activation by attachment to a tRNA
Correct alignment of the mRNA on the 40S ribosome

questions.text: During the process of protein synthesis, the factor eEF-2 induces the hydrolysis of GTP. The energy of this hydrolysis is coupled to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Translocation of the ribosome

 

  • The translation factor, eEF-2, is involved in the process of peptide elongation. Specifically, eEF-2 catalyses the GTP-dependent translocation of the ribosomes along the mRNA to the next codon. 
  • Attachment of an amino acid to a tRNA (Option A) is catalysed by the aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases. Alignment of the mRNA on the 40S ribosome (Option B) is facilitated by the initiation factor eIF-1. 
  • Formation of the 80S initiation complex (Option C) occurs after complete assembly of the 40S preinitiation complex and requires the activity of eIF-5. Formation of the peptide bond occurs through the action of peptidyl transferase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acid activation by attachment to a tRNA: This process is catalysed by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases, which require ATP, not GTP. Therefore, it is unrelated to the function of eEF-2 or the hydrolysis of GTP.

 

Option B. Correct alignment of the mRNA on the 40S ribosome: This occurs during the initiation phase of protein synthesis and involves initiation factors such as eIF-4, not eEF-2. It is not powered by GTP hydrolysis facilitated by eEF-2.

 

Option C. Formation of the 80S initiation complex: Formation of the 80S ribosome from the 40S and 60S subunits occurs during the initiation phase and is driven by GTP hydrolysis involving eIF-5, not eEF-2. This step is distinct from the elongation phase where translocation occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The elongation factor eEF-2 utilizes the energy from GTP hydrolysis to facilitate ribosome translocation, a critical step in the elongation phase of protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a five-day history of high fever, severe headache, muscle aches, and a dry cough. She mentions recently returning from a hiking trip in a forested area known for tick and mite activity. On examination, her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), and there is a 1-cm blackened lesion with a surrounding red rim on her left thigh. She also has tender lymphadenopathy near the lesion site and mild crackles on lung auscultation. Laboratory studies reveal a normal white blood cell count and elevated liver enzymes. A chest X-ray shows diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral doxycycline

 

  • The patient's presentation, including a high fever, eschar (blackened lesion), regional lymphadenopathy, and recent exposure to a forested area with ticks and mites, is suggestive of scrub typhus, a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by chiggers (mite larvae). 
  • The diffuse interstitial infiltrates on the chest X-ray, along with her respiratory symptoms, support the possibility of atypical pneumonia secondary to this infection.
  • The preferred treatment for scrub typhus and other rickettsial infections is doxycycline, which effectively targets intracellular pathogens like Orientia tsutsugamushi. 
  • Oral doxycycline is typically sufficient, as it has excellent bioavailability and tissue penetration, including within cells where rickettsial organisms reside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is often used to treat bacterial infections but is not effective against rickettsial pathogens, as it does not target intracellular organisms like Orientia tsutsugamushi. Therefore, it would not be the most appropriate choice.

 

Option B. Oral azithromycin and intravenous ceftriaxone: Although azithromycin has some efficacy against atypical bacterial pneumonia, it is less effective than doxycycline for rickettsial infections. Adding ceftriaxone would not be beneficial in this case, as it does not cover the likely rickettsial organism.

 

Option D. Intravenous vancomycin and levofloxacin: This combination is used for serious bacterial infections, including MRSA and other resistant organisms, but neither drug effectively treats rickettsial infections. It would not address the most likely underlying cause in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For rickettsial infections such as scrub typhus, which present with fever, eschar, and potential atypical pneumonia, doxycycline is the most effective initial treatment.

choices.text: Perform serum VDRL of the baby
Perform CSF VDRL of the baby
Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman, underwent routine investigations that revealed a VDRL test positive at a 1:16 titer, with confirmatory TPHA also positive. She received adequate treatment with injection benzathine penicillin. Following this maternal treatment, what is the next appropriate management step for her newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform serum VDRL of the baby

 

In cases where a pregnant woman has tested positive for syphilis and has been treated appropriately with benzathine penicillin, the newborn requires assessment to rule out congenital syphilis. The most appropriate step is to perform a serum VDRL test on the baby after birth. This will help identify if there is serological evidence of congenital infection. Since maternal antibodies may cross the placenta, the baby’s titer should be compared to the mother's; a titer that is fourfold or higher in the baby than in the mother would suggest infection rather than passive antibody transfer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait and Watch: This option would be inadequate as newborns exposed to maternal syphilis require assessment to identify any active infection early, and "wait and watch" could delay essential intervention.

 

Option C. Perform CSF VDRL of the baby: A CSF VDRL is indicated only if congenital syphilis is suspected based on serum VDRL findings, clinical signs, or if the baby has high risk factors for infection. Routine CSF testing is not the initial step unless serum findings or symptoms indicate a need.

 

Option D. Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby: Aqueous penicillin treatment is reserved for cases where congenital syphilis is confirmed or highly suspected based on clinical and laboratory evaluation. Immediate empirical treatment is not necessary if there is no evidence of infection.

 

Educational Objective:


When a mother is treated for syphilis during pregnancy, a serum VDRL test is essential for the newborn to determine possible congenital syphilis. A comparative titer assessment helps guide further intervention or the need for additional testing like CSF VDRL.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old rice farmer from northern Australia presents with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, weight loss, and productive cough. He reports generalized body aches and night sweats. Physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly and tenderness in the right upper quadrant.

 

Laboratory findings:

 

  • WBC count: 14,500/mm³
  • Haemoglobin: 11.8 g/dL
  • Platelets: 170,000/mm³
  • Blood cultures: Positive for a Gram-negative bacillus
  • Imaging:
    • Chest X-ray: Multiple nodular infiltrates and cavitary lesions in both lungs.
    • Abdominal CT: Liver and spleen show multiple small hypodense lesions consistent with abscesses.

 

Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burkholderia pseudomallei

 

This patient’s presentation, including abscesses in multiple organs (lungs, liver, spleen), fever, and exposure to a tropical environment, is highly suggestive of melioidosis, caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei. Key points:

 

  • Geography and occupation: Common in Southeast Asia and northern Australia, especially among farmers.
  • Clinical presentation: Can cause disseminated disease with abscesses in multiple organs, including the lungs, liver, spleen, and sometimes soft tissues.
  • Laboratory findings: B. pseudomallei is a Gram-negative bacillus, typically isolated from blood, sputum, or abscess cultures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Although tuberculosis can present with lung cavitations and systemic symptoms, it rarely causes abscesses in multiple organs (e.g., liver and spleen) simultaneously. The Gram-negative bacillus on blood culture excludes M. tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Escherichia coli: E. coli is a common cause of liver abscesses (e.g., pyogenic abscesses), especially in biliary infections, but it does not explain the pulmonary involvement and cavitary lesions.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: S. aureus can cause lung abscesses and disseminated infections (e.g., septic emboli), but it is a Gram-positive organism and less likely in a patient from a tropical, rural setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melioidosis caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei should be suspected in patients with abscesses in multiple organs, especially in endemic regions and with occupational exposure to soil or water. Disseminated disease requires aggressive antibiotic therapy with ceftazidime or meropenem for the acute phase, followed by oral eradication therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

choices.text: Renal deposition of immunoglobulin light chains
Renal deposition of AL amyloid fibrils
Hypercalcemia from a primary parathyroid adenoma

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased urine output. Three weeks ago, she had a sore throat. She reports a history of chronic constipation.

 

On physical examination:

 

  • Blood pressure: 150/100 mm Hg
  • Conjunctival pallor and bilateral pitting pedal edema are noted.
  • There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine and right 8th rib.

 

Laboratory findings:

 

  • Calcium: Elevated
  • Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL
  • Urine dipstick: Negative for blood and protein
  • Serum creatinine: Elevated
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP): M-spike detected

 

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal deposition of immunoglobulin light chains

 

This patient's presentation is consistent with multiple myeloma:

 

  • Hypercalcemia, anemia, renal involvement, and bone pain (CRAB criteria): These are classic features of multiple myeloma.
  • Negative urine dipstick despite renal dysfunction: Light chains (Bence Jones protein) do not react with dipstick tests.
  • M-spike on SPEP and rouleaux formation: Indicators of a monoclonal gammopathy due to clonal plasma cell proliferation.

 

The renal failure is due to light chain cast nephropathy, where immunoglobulin light chains accumulate in the renal tubules, causing obstruction and damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis with immune complex deposition: This condition typically occurs in younger patients and is associated with hematuria, proteinuria, and low complement levels. Negative urine dipstick for blood and protein makes this unlikely.

 

Option C. Renal deposition of AL amyloid fibrils: Amyloidosis can occur in multiple myeloma but typically presents with nephrotic syndrome (proteinuria) and organomegaly (e.g., enlarged liver or spleen). Negative urine protein and absence of organomegaly make this less likely.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia from a primary parathyroid adenoma: While primary hyperparathyroidism causes hypercalcemia, it does not explain the anemia, renal failure, M-spike, or bone pain in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This case demonstrates the importance of recognizing the classic features of multiple myeloma, particularly when renal dysfunction and hypercalcemia are present with an M-spike and rouleaux formation.

choices.text: Failure to use splintage in safety position

questions.text: The commonest cause of stiffness in hand injuries is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure to use splintage in safety position

 

  • The "safety position" (or functional position) is an optimal position in which to splint or immobilize the hand to prevent contractures and stiffness during the healing phase. This position is designed to preserve tendon length and joint alignment while the hand heals. It typically involves:
  • Wrist extension of 20–30 degrees
  • MCP joint flexion (metacarpophalangeal joints) around 60-70 degrees
  • IP joints (interphalangeal joints) slightly flexed
  • Thumb in a relaxed position to avoid contracture of the thenar muscles
  • When splintage is not used correctly or when the hand is immobilized in an inappropriate position, it can lead to several types of problems:
  • Immobilization in an improper position can cause soft tissue structures (e.g., ligaments, tendons) to adapt to a shortened or fixed position. This can result in permanent stiffness once healing is complete.
  • If the hand is not immobilized in the functional position, the flexor tendons may shorten, leading to a loss of normal motion (e.g., a "claw hand" deformity).
  • Prolonged immobilization in an improper position can also cause the muscles to weaken, which further contributes to stiffness and loss of function.
  • Increased risk of deformities: Without proper splinting, the hand may heal in an abnormal position, leading to deformities like boutonnière deformity, mallet finger, or clawing of the fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Presence of Fractures:

 

  • Fractures of the hand, such as those involving the phalanges, metacarpals, or carpals, can lead to stiffness, but fractures themselves are not the most common cause of stiffness in hand injuries. While fractures cause pain and limit movement during the acute healing phase, stiffness is typically a result of complications arising from the healing process. Some factors related to fractures can lead to stiffness:
  • Inadequate fracture reduction or poor alignment of the bone during healing can result in joint malalignment, which in turn contributes to stiffness.
  • Post-traumatic arthritis may develop in some fractures, particularly if the joint surface is involved or if the fracture is not properly aligned.
  • Immobilization for prolonged periods can lead to muscle atrophy and joint stiffness as the surrounding soft tissues lose flexibility and strength.

 

Option B. Tendon Injuries:

 

  • Tendon injuries are a common cause of stiffness in hand injuries, particularly flexor tendon injuries (e.g., lacerations or ruptures of the flexor tendons). Tendons are responsible for the smooth movement of the hand and fingers, and any disruption in their function can result in stiffness:
  • After tendon injuries, scar tissue can form around the injured tendon, restricting its ability to glide smoothly through its tendon sheath. This results in functional stiffness in the affected fingers or hand.
  • After tendon repairs, immobilization is often necessary during the healing phase to avoid disrupting the repair. However, this can lead to stiffness if not carefully managed, as prolonged immobilization can result in joint contractures and muscle atrophy.
  • If proper rehabilitation exercises are not followed after tendon repair or injury, it can result in long-term stiffness due to the lack of normal tendon movement.

 

Option D. The Presence of Edema:

 

  • Edema (swelling) is a common and normal response to hand injuries, including fractures, sprains, tendon injuries, and soft tissue damage. Swelling can initially contribute to stiffness by limiting the ability of the joints and tendons to move smoothly.
  • Edema is typically a short-term issue: Swelling usually resolves with appropriate elevation, compression, and movement once the acute inflammatory phase has passed.
  • Edema-related stiffness is typically temporary and improves as the swelling goes down. It is a secondary cause of stiffness, especially in the acute phase of injury, but not the most common long-term cause of stiffness.
  • Edema can affect movement temporarily, but it is not usually the cause of long-term stiffness. Once the swelling subsides, the range of motion should return unless there are other complications, such as tendon adhesions or joint contractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The safety position is critical for preventing joint contractures, tendon shortening, and muscle atrophy during the healing phase after a hand injury. 
  • Failing to use this position or splint the hand properly is the most common cause of long-term stiffness in hand injuries.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of P waves, consistent with atrial fibrillation. His ventricular rate is 140 beats per minute. The physician decides to initiate rate control. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to manage his heart rate in the context of atrial fibrillation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diltiazem

 

  • Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that is effective for rate control in atrial fibrillation. 
  • In patients with atrial fibrillation, rate control is often achieved with beta blockers (e.g., propranolol, metoprolol), calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem, verapamil), or digoxin, especially when the goal is to reduce ventricular response in cases of rapid atrial fibrillation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flecainide: Flecainide is a sodium channel blocker used for rhythm control rather than rate control. It is primarily indicated for rhythm conversion in atrial fibrillation in patients without significant structural heart disease.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone, a potassium channel blocker, is used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation, not rate control. It may be used in rhythm conversion or in maintaining sinus rhythm.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Adenosine is not effective in treating atrial fibrillation as it has a very short half-life and is primarily used for terminating paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For rate control in atrial fibrillation, calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem), beta blockers, or digoxin are effective choices, while adenosine is ineffective for atrial fibrillation and is used only for PSVT.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling, bloody vaginal discharge mixed with mucous. Physical examination reveals a necrotic lesion on the cervix with lateral extension into the parametrium. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chemoradiation

 

  • The patient’s presentation suggests advanced cervical cancer, likely stage IIB or higher, as indicated by the involvement of the lateral parametrium. 
  • In cases of locally advanced cervical cancer (stages IB2 to IVA), the recommended treatment is chemoradiation, which includes both external beam radiation and concurrent chemotherapy, typically with cisplatin. 
  • This combined approach has been shown to improve local control of the tumor, reduce the risk of recurrence, and enhance overall survival by addressing both the primary tumor and potential micrometastatic disease.
  • Chemoradiation is particularly beneficial in treating parametrial involvement, as surgery alone is typically insufficient for achieving complete disease control in such cases.
  • The radiation helps to target the local tumor and adjacent tissues involved, while concurrent chemotherapy enhances the effects of radiation and treats micrometastatic spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chemotherapy: Although chemotherapy is part of the treatment, it is generally not used alone for primary management of locally advanced cervical cancer. Chemotherapy alone is less effective than chemoradiation in controlling locoregional disease and is typically reserved for palliative care in metastatic settings.

 

Option C. Surgery: Surgery, such as a radical hysterectomy, is generally indicated for early-stage cervical cancer without parametrial involvement. For advanced-stage disease with parametrial extension, surgery alone is less effective and does not provide adequate disease control, making chemoradiation the preferred approach.

 

Option D. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy is a component of the radiotherapy regimen for cervical cancer but is usually combined with external beam radiation and chemotherapy for locally advanced disease. Brachytherapy alone would be insufficient in this case due to the extent of local spread to the parametrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In locally advanced cervical cancer with parametrial involvement, chemoradiation is the treatment of choice to effectively manage locoregional disease and improve survival outcomes.

questions.text:
Both Staphylococcus epidermidis and Escherichia coli were simultaneously grown on a culture medium in a lab. After overnight incubation, only E. coli flourished while S. epidermidis did not grow. What is the possible reason for this observation? 

 

  1. Temperature of growth was set incorrectly 
  2. Culture medium was selective
  3. E. coli produced colicin that inhibited S. epidermidis growth 
  4. Gram-positive bacteria have a longer generation time 
  5. Culture medium was differential
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2 only

 

  • The most likely reason for E. coli flourishing while S. epidermidis did not grow is that the culture medium was selective.
  • Selective media are designed to favor the growth of certain types of organisms while inhibiting others. In this case, the medium likely favored the growth of E. coli (a Gram-negative bacterium) and inhibited the growth of S. epidermidis (a Gram-positive bacterium).
  • Selective media often contain agents that specifically inhibit Gram-positive bacteria while allowing Gram-negative bacteria to thrive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 5 - Culture medium was selective and Culture medium was differential: Incorrect. While a differential medium distinguishes bacteria based on biochemical reactions, it does not inhibit the growth of certain organisms. Therefore, differential media alone would not prevent S. epidermidis from growing.

 

Option B. 4 only - Gram-positive bacteria have a longer generation time: Incorrect. Although Gram-positive bacteria like S. epidermidis may have a different generation time, this difference is insufficient to prevent growth if the medium is appropriate for both types of bacteria.

 

Option C. 1 and 3 - Temperature of growth was set incorrectly and E. coli produced colicin that inhibited S. epidermidis growth : Incorrect. An incorrect temperature setting would likely affect both organisms, not just one. Additionally, colicin production by E. coli would typically target other Gram-negative bacteria, not Gram-positive bacteria like S. epidermidis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The use of selective media can inhibit the growth of certain bacteria (e.g., Gram-positive organisms) while promoting the growth of others, such as E. coli (Gram-negative bacteria).

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a 10-year history of systemic sclerosis presents with worsening shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations. On examination, she has a narrow split S2, elevated JVP, and bilaterally diminished breath sounds at the lung bases. Echocardiography estimates the pulmonary artery pressure at 45 mmHg, and pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern with reduced DLCO. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for managing her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endothelin receptor antagonists

 

Endothelin receptor antagonists (e.g., bosentan, ambrisentan) are considered the first-line therapy for pulmonary hypertension in patients with systemic sclerosis. These medications block endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor, and help reduce pulmonary vascular resistance, improving symptoms and hemodynamics in such patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous prostacyclin therapy: While prostacyclin therapy (e.g., epoprostenol) is effective for severe cases of pulmonary hypertension, it is typically reserved for advanced or refractory disease due to the need for continuous intravenous infusion and the risk of serious side effects.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers may be beneficial in a small subset of patients with idiopathic pulmonary hypertension who are vasoreactive. However, they are generally not effective in pulmonary hypertension associated with systemic sclerosis, which is non-vasoreactive.

 

Option D. Sildenafil: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor that can be used in pulmonary hypertension. However, endothelin receptor antagonists are preferred as first-line therapy for systemic sclerosis-related pulmonary hypertension due to their greater efficacy in reducing pulmonary vascular resistance in these patients.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Endothelin receptor antagonists are the first-line treatment for pulmonary hypertension in systemic sclerosis, as they effectively target the underlying pathophysiology of pulmonary vascular remodeling. In contrast, treatments like prostacyclin therapy and calcium channel blockers are generally reserved for more severe or specific cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with delusions that his thoughts are being broadcast on the radio, along with episodes of uncontrollable laughter without any emotional context. He has progressive cognitive decline and ataxia. EEG shows periodic sharp wave complexes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease

 

  • The patient's presentation of thought broadcasting, inappropriate emotional displays (e.g., uncontrollable laughter), progressive cognitive decline, ataxia, and the EEG finding of periodic sharp wave complexes is strongly suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD). 
  • CJD is a rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disease caused by prion proteins, characterized by rapid cognitive decline, behavioral changes, myoclonus, and ataxia. 
  • The EEG finding of periodic sharp wave complexes is highly suggestive of this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Sclerosis: MS primarily involves demyelinating lesions in the central nervous system and typically presents with motor and sensory deficits, visual disturbances, and progressive neurological impairment. It is not associated with periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG.

 

Option C. Frontotemporal Dementia: FTD often presents with behavioral changes and language deficits, but it does not show periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG, and it is not usually associated with myoclonus or rapid progression.

 

Option D. Late-onset Schizophrenia: While late-onset schizophrenia can present with delusions and hallucinations, it lacks the progressive cognitive and motor decline seen in CJD and would not show periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonic jerks, seizures and cerebellar ataxia. EEG usually shows periodic sharp wave complexes with slow background.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with developmental delay, growth failure, and distinctive coarse facial features. Laboratory findings show elevated lysosomal enzymes in the plasma, suggesting impaired lysosomal function. The condition is diagnosed as I-cell disease. Deficiency in which phosphorylating enzyme leads to the lack of which critical recognition marker responsible for lysosomal targeting in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mannose 6-phosphate

 

  • I-cell disease, also known as mucolipidosis II, is a rare lysosomal storage disorder caused by a defect in the enzyme N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase. 
  • This enzyme is responsible for phosphorylating mannose residues on lysosomal enzymes to form mannose 6-phosphate (M6P), which serves as a critical recognition marker. M6P tags these enzymes for transport to the lysosomes. 
  • In the absence of this tagging, lysosomal enzymes are instead secreted into the extracellular space, leading to elevated lysosomal enzymes in the plasma and impaired lysosomal function within cells. 
  • This dysfunction results in cellular accumulation of waste products, causing developmental delays, failure to thrive, and the characteristic facial features observed in I-cell disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactocerebroside: Galactocerebroside is a component of myelin and is associated with disorders like Krabbe disease. It is not involved in the lysosomal enzyme targeting process and does not serve as a recognition marker for lysosomal enzymes, making it unrelated to I-cell disease.

 

Option B. Globoside: Globoside is a glycosphingolipid found in cell membranes and is associated with Fabry disease when its metabolism is disrupted. It does not function as a lysosomal targeting marker and is not relevant to the pathology of I-cell disease.

 

Option D. GM2 ganglioside: GM2 ganglioside accumulation is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, caused by a deficiency in hexosaminidase A. GM2 ganglioside does not play a role in the lysosomal enzyme targeting system and is not related to the mechanism underlying I-cell disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In I-cell disease, a deficiency in N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase prevents the formation of mannose 6-phosphate (M6P), a recognition marker necessary for the targeting of lysosomal enzymes. 
  • This lack of M6P tagging leads to the misdirection of lysosomal enzymes into the extracellular space, causing lysosomal dysfunction and cellular waste accumulation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of cholecystectomy presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and nausea for the past 2 weeks. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant without guarding or rebound. Laboratory tests show:

 

  • Total bilirubin: 1.2 mg/dL
  • Alkaline phosphatase: 190 U/L
  • Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 45 U/L
  • Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 50 U/L

 

An abdominal CT scan is shown  in image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus


Pneumobilia (air in the biliary tree) is most commonly associated with a biliary-enteric fistula, which allows air to enter the biliary system. In gallstone ileus, a large gallstone passes through this fistula and becomes lodged in the gastrointestinal tract, leading to bowel obstruction. This patient’s intermittent abdominal pain and history of cholecystectomy increase the likelihood of gallstone ileus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute cholangitis: Acute cholangitis is characterized by Charcot’s triad (fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain), often associated with biliary obstruction and infection. Pneumobilia alone without systemic signs of infection is less likely to indicate cholangitis.

 

Option C. Biliary-enteric fistula: While pneumobilia is caused by a biliary-enteric fistula, the specific clinical diagnosis in this case is gallstone ileus, which results from the fistula. The two conditions are related, but the ileus is the more accurate answer.

 

Option D. Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction: Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction can cause biliary colic and abnormal liver function tests but does not typically result in pneumobilia.

 

Educational Objective:


Pneumobilia, when identified on imaging, should prompt evaluation for gallstone ileus, especially in patients with abdominal pain and a history of cholecystectomy or biliary disease.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents with progressive lower extremity weakness, severe back pain, and urinary incontinence over the past week. He also reports difficulty maintaining an erection. His medical history includes a herpes zoster infection 5 months ago, which resolved without complications.

 

Physical examination reveals:

 

  • Bilateral lower extremity motor weakness (grade 2/5)
  • Loss of pinprick and vibration sensation below the T8 level
  • Absent bulbocavernosus reflex

 

Laboratory findings:

 

  • ESR: Elevated
  • CSF analysis: Mildly elevated protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis, negative oligoclonal bands

 

Spine MRI shows diffuse spinal cord swelling with hyperintense lesions involving more than two-thirds of the cross-sectional area of the cord, extending over multiple vertebral levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transverse myelitis

 

This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with transverse myelitis (TM), a demyelinating inflammatory disorder of the spinal cord. Key features:

 

  • Progressive weakness and sensory loss: TM affects motor and sensory pathways, often with a well-defined neurological level.
  • Autonomic dysfunction: Includes urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction.
  • MRI findings: Enlarged spinal cord with lesions involving more than two-thirds of the cross-sectional area is typical of TM.
  • History of herpes zoster: TM can occur as a post-infectious or immune-mediated phenomenon after viral infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD): NMOSD can present with longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM). However, NMOSD typically involves optic neuritis and has aquaporin-4 (AQP4) antibodies, which are not reported here. The prior herpes zoster infection and absence of optic symptoms favor TM over NMOSD.

 

Option B. Multiple sclerosis: MS lesions are usually smaller, peripherally located, and do not involve more than two-thirds of the spinal cord cross-section. TM’s longitudinally extensive lesion and bilateral deficits make MS unlikely.

 

Option D. Spinal cord abscess: While abscesses can cause similar symptoms, they are often associated with fever, localized tenderness, and risk factors for infection (e.g., IV drug use). MRI findings would typically show a localized ring-enhancing lesion, not diffuse spinal cord swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse myelitis should be considered in patients with rapidly progressive motor, sensory, and autonomic dysfunction, particularly after a viral infection. MRI findings of longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesions are a hallmark feature. Early recognition and treatment with corticosteroids or immunotherapy are crucial.

questions.text: Which of the following structures primarily divides the liver into its anatomical segments under Couinaud classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Portal vein

 

  • In the Couinaud classification system, the liver is divided into segments based on the distribution of the portal vein branches. 
  • Each segment is an area of the liver tissue that is anatomically defined by its own vascular inflow, outflow, and biliary drainage. 
  • This system is widely used to describe liver anatomy and plan liver surgeries, such as resections, by dividing the liver into eight functionally independent segments.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Hepatic artery: While the hepatic artery does supply blood to the liver, it does not serve as the primary anatomical divider in the Couinaud classification system.

 

Option C. Bile duct: The biliary system, including the bile ducts, is important for the drainage of bile from the liver segments, but it is not the primary structure used to divide the liver anatomically in this system.

 

Option D. Cystic duct: The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct and has no role in the anatomical division of the liver according to the Couinaud classification.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Couinaud classification system uses the distribution of the portal vein branches to anatomically divide the liver into segments, which is essential for understanding liver anatomy, especially in the context of surgical planning and hepatic resections.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a history of intermittent dysphagia to solid foods and occasional episodes of food impaction. He has no weight loss, chest pain, or heartburn. His symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past year. He has a history of seasonal allergies and eczema. Upper endoscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eosinophilic esophagitis 

 

Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic, immune-mediated condition associated with atopic disorders. It commonly presents with dysphagia and food impaction. Endoscopic findings include concentric rings (also called trachealization), linear furrows, and white exudates. Diagnosis is confirmed by esophageal biopsy showing ≥15 eosinophils per high-power field.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): GERD can cause dysphagia but does not typically present with concentric rings or linear furrows. Biopsy findings would show basal cell hyperplasia and inflammatory changes rather than eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Infectious esophagitis: Infectious esophagitis (e.g., due to Candida, HSV, or CMV) typically occurs in immunocompromised patients and presents with odynophagia, not concentric rings or linear furrows.

 

Option D. Achalasia: Achalasia is a motility disorder characterized by dysphagia to both solids and liquids, with imaging showing a bird-beak appearance on barium swallow. Endoscopic findings are typically unremarkable.

 

Educational Objective:


Eosinophilic esophagitis should be suspected in patients with dysphagia and endoscopic findings of concentric rings and linear furrows, particularly if there is a history of atopic conditions.

The condition is autosomal dominant, with anticipation due to further CAG repeat expansion during paternal transmission
The condition is X-linked dominant, with anticipation due to further CAG repeat expansion during maternal transmission

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with involuntary, jerky movements of his arms and legs, difficulty walking, and irritability over the past several months. His mother had similar symptoms and was diagnosed with a neurodegenerative disorder in her 50s. Genetic testing reveals an abnormal expansion of CAG trinucleotide repeats in the HTT gene. The patient is concerned about his 10-year-old son’s risk of developing the condition. Which of the following statements best explains the inheritance pattern and the likelihood of earlier onset in subsequent generations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The condition is autosomal dominant, with anticipation due to further CAG repeat expansion during paternal transmission.

 

Huntington’s disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene on chromosome 4. Key features:

 

  • Anticipation: Successive generations tend to have an earlier onset and more severe disease due to further expansion of CAG repeats.
  • Paternal transmission: CAG repeat expansion is more likely during spermatogenesis, making paternal inheritance a stronger contributor to anticipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The condition is autosomal recessive, and anticipation is unlikely: Huntington’s disease is autosomal dominant, not recessive. Anticipation is a hallmark feature.

 

Option C. The condition is X-linked dominant, with anticipation due to further CAG repeat expansion during maternal transmission: Huntington’s disease is autosomal, not X-linked, and anticipation occurs predominantly with paternal transmission.

 

Option D. The condition is autosomal dominant, and the severity of symptoms is unrelated to the number of CAG repeats: The severity and onset of symptoms are directly correlated with the number of CAG repeats. Larger expansions lead to earlier onset and more severe disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Huntington’s disease demonstrates anticipation, with earlier and more severe disease in successive generations, particularly with paternal transmission of expanded CAG repeats in the HTT gene.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes and newly diagnosed heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) presents with worsening shortness of breath and peripheral edema. His recent lab results show an elevated HbA1c, and his ejection fraction on echocardiography is 35%. Despite being on a loop diuretic, he continues to exhibit signs of fluid overload and a recent HbA1c indicates suboptimal glucose control. Which of the following antidiabetic medications would be the most appropriate addition to his treatment regimen to address both his diabetes and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, with the potential to enhance diuresis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Empagliflozin

 

  • Empagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, which has been shown to provide dual benefits for patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). 
  • Clinical trials have demonstrated that empagliflozin reduces the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalizations for heart failure in patients with HFrEF, even in those without diabetes. 
  • The SGLT2 inhibition leads to osmotic diuresis, which may help reduce fluid overload in heart failure patients by increasing urine output, complementing traditional diuretics.
  • Empagliflozin’s effect on both glucose control and heart failure outcomes makes it an ideal choice for this patient with both diabetes and HFrEF.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Linagliptin: Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor used to manage blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetes but has no established cardiovascular benefits or indications for heart failure management. It would not be effective in addressing the fluid overload seen in HFrEF.

 

Option C. Rosiglitazone: Rosiglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, is associated with an increased risk of fluid retention and heart failure exacerbation due to its potential to cause weight gain and edema. It is contraindicated in patients with heart failure.

 

Option D. Insulin degludec: Insulin degludec is a long-acting insulin used to control blood sugar in diabetes. It has no cardiovascular benefits and is not indicated for heart failure, nor does it assist with diuresis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is beneficial for patients with both diabetes and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) due to its effects on reducing cardiovascular risk, hospitalizations, and aiding diuresis through osmotic effects.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male farmer presents with a 2-week history of dry cough, shortness of breath, and fever. He reports frequent exposure to organic dust while working with hay and grains in poorly ventilated barns. His symptoms are worse in the mornings and improve as the day progresses. On examination, he has bilateral crackles on chest auscultation. Chest X-ray is shown in the image  below. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP), also known as "farmer's lung," is a type of interstitial lung disease caused by repeated inhalation of organic dusts such as those found in hay, moldy grains, or bird droppings. It results in an inflammatory response in the lungs, leading to symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, fever, and bilateral crackles. Chest imaging often shows diffuse infiltrates, and pulmonary function tests typically reveal a restrictive pattern due to inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Asthma typically presents with wheezing, episodic breathlessness, and reversible airflow obstruction on pulmonary function tests. It is not associated with organic dust exposure in the same way as hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

 

Option C. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): COPD is characterized by progressive airflow obstruction, often due to smoking, and does not cause a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. It also lacks the acute inflammatory response seen in hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

 

Option D. Pulmonary tuberculosis: Tuberculosis often presents with chronic cough, night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis, with a history of exposure to individuals with active TB. It is less likely to cause the diffuse infiltrates seen in hypersensitivity pneumonitis and does not fit the occupational exposure pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a lung condition triggered by inhalation of organic dust, common in occupations like farming, and is characterized by a restrictive pulmonary pattern and diffuse infiltrates on chest imaging. Early identification and removal from exposure are key to preventing progression to chronic lung disease.

questions.text: The following documents are exceptions to the requirement for oral evidence in court, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Postmortem reports

 

  • In legal proceedings, most forensic documents, such as Fingerprint Bureau reports and Chemical Examiner's reports, are accepted as exceptions to the requirement for oral evidence. 
  • However, postmortem reports typically require the testimony of the medical examiner who conducted the autopsy. 
  • This is because the findings and interpretations, particularly regarding the cause of death, can be complex and may require clarification. 
  • Thus, postmortem reports are not automatically exempt from oral evidence requirements in court.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dying declaration: Dying declarations are considered exceptions to oral evidence requirements. These are statements made by an individual shortly before death, regarding the cause or circumstances of their death, and are admissible as documentary evidence without additional oral testimony.

 

Option C. Reports of Fingerprint Bureau: Fingerprint Bureau reports are generally accepted as reliable and do not require oral testimony. Courts consider these standardized and allow them as evidence without the necessity of further explanation from the preparer.

 

Option D. Chemical Examiner’s reports: Chemical Examiner’s reports, such as toxicology analyses, are also treated as exceptions to oral evidence. They are accepted based on established scientific methods, and thus, typically do not require supplementary oral testimony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While many forensic documents are accepted as exceptions to oral evidence in court, postmortem reports generally require the testimony of the medical examiner to clarify findings, especially in complex cases.

questions.text: A 42-year old patient with iron deficiency anemia is being evaluated for proper iron absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. Which of the following is the transporter responsible for iron uptake into enterocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Divalent Metal Transporter 1

 

  • DMT1 is the primary transporter responsible for the uptake of ferrous iron (Fe²⁺) from the intestinal lumen into enterocytes in the duodenum, the main site of iron absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. This transporter plays a crucial role in iron homeostasis by facilitating iron entry into the cells of the intestine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin 1: Ferroportin 1 is involved in exporting iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream, not in the initial uptake of iron from the intestinal lumen into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Hephaestin: Hephaestin is an enzyme that works with Ferroportin to oxidize iron from Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ as it exits the enterocytes, enabling iron to bind to transferrin for transport in the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Transferrin Receptor: Transferrin receptors are present on cell surfaces and facilitate the uptake of iron-bound transferrin into cells via endocytosis. However, they are not involved in the direct absorption of iron into enterocytes from the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1) is responsible for the uptake of iron into enterocytes in the duodenum, which is the main site of iron absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with a genetic mutation affecting the structure of a protein involved in cellular signaling. Genetic sequencing reveals a missense mutation that introduces a new amino acid into an existing alpha helix structure within the protein. Which of the following amino acids, if introduced by this mutation, would most likely disrupt the alpha helical structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycine

 

  • Glycine is unique among amino acids due to its small size and lack of a bulky side chain. This structural simplicity gives glycine a high degree of flexibility, which can destabilize alpha helical structures. 
  • When glycine is introduced into an alpha helix, it increases flexibility at that position, potentially causing bends or kinks that disrupt the regular helical structure. 
  • Alpha helices require rigidity and uniformity to maintain their shape, and glycine’s flexibility tends to interrupt this, making it a helix breaker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine: Alanine is a small, hydrophobic amino acid that is commonly found within alpha helices. Its simple side chain does not disrupt the helical structure, and it actually helps stabilize alpha helices by promoting a uniform and compact structure.

 

Option B. Aspartic acid: Aspartic acid, with its charged side chain, can sometimes disrupt an alpha helix, especially if present in high concentrations. However, it does not generally break the helical structure as predictably as glycine, as it can still participate in helical structures depending on its location and interactions with other residues.

 

Option C. Tyrosine: Tyrosine, with its bulky side chain, may occasionally interfere with helical packing if multiple tyrosine residues are present. However, it can still participate in alpha helices and does not disrupt the structure as severely as glycine, which is much more flexible and lacks steric constraints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycine is known as a "helix breaker" due to its high flexibility, which can disrupt the stability of alpha helical structures in proteins.

questions.text: A 29 years old male underwent surgery for cervical myelopathy and radiculopathy. Given below is his postoperative X-ray. 12 hours after surgery he complains of difficulty in breathing, swallowing, and talking, which exacerbates in the supine position. He also exhibits tense incision line. However, his oxygen saturation remains normal. What is the likely cause and management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retropharyngeal hematoma and immediate evacuation

 

  • A retropharyngeal hematoma (RPH) is a known and serious complication that can occur after cervical spine surgery, especially in cases of anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF) or similar procedures. The retropharyngeal space is closely related to critical structures such as the trachea, esophagus, and major blood vessels (e.g., internal carotid arteries). A hematoma in this space can compress these structures, leading to airway obstruction and difficulty swallowing.
  • Symptoms of retropharyngeal hematoma typically include:
    • Difficulty breathing, especially in the supine position, as gravity causes the hematoma to compress the airway.
    • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and talking (dysphonia) due to compression of the pharynx and larynx.
    • A tense incision line may be palpable, and it can indicate significant swelling from blood collection.
  • The immediate treatment of a retropharyngeal hematoma involves evacuating the hematoma to relieve the compression on the airway. This may involve surgical intervention to drain the hematoma and prevent progressive airway obstruction or other complications such as infection or nerve damage.
  • Since the patient is already experiencing significant symptoms and the situation is evolving, immediate evacuation is required to prevent further compromise of the airway and to relieve pressure on the surrounding structures. Without prompt intervention, the hematoma can progress to complete airway obstruction or lead to other complications like necrosis or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retropharyngeal Hematoma and Supportive Treatment:

 

  • While a retropharyngeal hematoma is a likely cause in this case, supportive treatment alone (such as monitoring, oxygen, or pain control) is not sufficient for the management of a significant hematoma that is causing respiratory distress and compression of vital structures.
  • In a case where there is significant compression of the airway, as seen in this patient, urgent evacuation is needed to prevent further deterioration. Supportive treatment alone might only be appropriate if the hematoma is small, asymptomatic, or minimally symptomatic. Given the tense incision line, the progression of symptoms, and the risk of airway compromise, immediate evacuation is necessary.

 

Option C. Angioedema and Intravenous Corticosteroids:

 

  • Angioedema refers to swelling of the deeper layers of the skin or mucous membranes, commonly due to an allergic reaction or as a side effect of medications (such as ACE inhibitors). Angioedema can lead to swelling of the tongue, lips, or airway, and may cause difficulty breathing, swallowing, and speaking.
  • Symptoms of Angioedema:
    • Sudden swelling of the face or neck, particularly around the tongue and throat.
    • Difficulty breathing and swallowing due to airway obstruction.
    • Exacerbation in the supine position as gravity can worsen airway obstruction.
  • Although angioedema could cause similar symptoms (difficulty breathing, swallowing, and talking), the patient has undergone cervical spine surgery, and the tense incision line, along with the lack of significant facial or neck swelling (as would be seen in angioedema), makes retropharyngeal hematoma the more likely diagnosis. Additionally, oxygen saturation remains normal, which would be less likely in severe angioedema causing significant airway obstruction. 
  • Corticosteroids and antihistamines are often used in angioedema, but these would not address the underlying mechanical obstruction caused by a hematoma.

 

Option D. Pharyngo-laryngeal Edema and Cricothyrotomy:

 

  • Pharyngo-laryngeal edema refers to swelling of the pharynx and larynx, which can lead to airway obstruction. This can result from surgical trauma, infection, or other causes, and may lead to difficulty breathing, swallowing, and speaking.
  • Cricothyrotomy is an emergency procedure used to establish an airway in cases of severe upper airway obstruction where other methods (such as intubation) are not possible. It is typically reserved for situations where immediate life-threatening airway compromise is imminent.
  • The patient's oxygen saturation remains normal, which suggests that his airway is not yet critically compromised. In this case, a retropharyngeal hematoma is more likely than pharyngo-laryngeal edema, and it requires surgical evacuation rather than a cricothyrotomy. A cricothyrotomy would be more appropriate if there were imminent airway collapse and failure to maintain oxygenation, but at this point, it seems unnecessary given that the patient still has normal oxygen saturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retropharyngeal hematoma and immediate evacuation, the patient is presenting with classic symptoms of a retropharyngeal hematoma (difficulty breathing, swallowing, and talking), and the tense incision line suggests a collection of blood in the retropharyngeal space. 
  • Immediate evacuation is required to prevent worsening airway obstruction and further complications.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty gripping objects and noticeable weakness in the thumb. On physical examination, there is significant atrophy of the thenar eminence and an inability to oppose the thumb. Which of the following muscles, primarily supplied by the median nerve, is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flexor Pollicis Brevis

 

  • The median nerve innervates the thenar muscles, which are responsible for thumb movements, including opposition. 
  • The flexor pollicis brevis (specifically, the superficial head) is one of these muscles and is primarily innervated by the median nerve. 
  • Atrophy of the thenar eminence and loss of thumb opposition are clinical signs indicative of median nerve involvement, which is often seen in conditions such as carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

  • 4 Hypothenar Muscles shown in image: 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmaris Brevis: This muscle is innervated by the ulnar nerve and is involved in tensing the skin on the ulnar side of the hand to improve grip. It is not involved in thumb opposition and is not affected by median nerve pathology.

 

Option B. Dorsal Interossei: These muscles are innervated by the ulnar nerve and function to abduct the fingers. They do not contribute to thumb opposition or show atrophy in median nerve lesions.

 

Option D. Extensor Pollicis Longus: This muscle is innervated by the radial nerve and extends the thumb at the interphalangeal joint. It is not involved in the movements typically affected by median nerve dysfunction, such as opposition of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The flexor pollicis brevis, a muscle primarily supplied by the median nerve, plays a crucial role in thumb opposition. 
  • Atrophy of the thenar eminence and difficulty gripping objects are indicative of median nerve dysfunction, commonly seen in carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is undergoing a surgical procedure requiring direct access to the brachial plexus. Before beginning, the surgeon emphasizes the need to carefully navigate through the correct fascial layers to avoid nerve injury. Which fascial layer contributes to the formation of the sheath that encases the brachial plexus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevertebral fascia

 

  • The fascia around the nerve bundles of the brachial plexus, crucial for safe surgical navigation, is derived from the prevertebral fascia. 
  • This specific layer of deep cervical fascia extends laterally to form the axillary sheath, which provides a protective covering around the brachial plexus and associated vascular structures as they pass from the neck into the upper limb.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectoral fascia: Incorrect. This fascia primarily covers the pectoralis major muscle and is not involved in surrounding the brachial plexus.

 

Option B. Deep cervical fascia: Partially correct, but too broad. The deep cervical fascia includes several distinct layers, and the specific layer responsible for encasing the brachial plexus is the prevertebral fascia.

 

Option C. Clavipectoral fascia: Incorrect. While important in the pectoral region for covering the subclavius and pectoralis minor muscles, the clavipectoral fascia does not extend to form the sheath around the brachial plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The prevertebral fascia, as part of the deep cervical fascia, extends to form the axillary sheath that encloses the brachial plexus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is undergoing genetic testing due to a family history of chromosomal abnormalities. She is specifically being evaluated for potential aneuploidies. Which of the following techniques are appropriate for detecting aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization)

 

  • FISH is a highly specific and reliable technique for detecting aneuploidy. It involves the use of fluorescent probes that attach to specific regions on chromosomes, making it possible to visualize the presence of extra or missing chromosomes within the cell.
  • This method is commonly used in both prenatal and postnatal diagnostics to detect common chromosomal aneuploidies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Comparative Genomic Hybridization (CGH): CGH can detect copy number variations across the genome but is not the primary choice for diagnosing aneuploidy. It is less specific for counting chromosome numbers and typically requires more complex analysis.

 

Option C. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Standard PCR amplifies specific DNA segments, which is useful for detecting point mutations or small deletions but not for assessing whole chromosome numbers or aneuploidies.

 

Option D. QF-PCR (Quantitative Fluorescent PCR): Although QF-PCR is sometimes used for rapid detection of common aneuploidies, FISH remains the gold standard due to its accuracy and visualization capabilities in directly assessing chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is the primary and most effective method for detecting aneuploidy, as it provides direct visualization of chromosomal numbers, allowing for the identification of extra or missing chromosomes.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman reports post-coital bleeding. A recent Pap smear revealed atypical cells. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy-directed biopsy

 

  • In a patient with post-coital bleeding and an abnormal Pap smear indicating atypical cells, colposcopy-directed biopsy is the next appropriate step. 
  • Colposcopy provides a magnified view of the cervix and allows for precise evaluation of suspicious areas. 
  • During colposcopy, the clinician can take directed biopsies from any abnormal areas to assess for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) or invasive carcinoma. 
  • This approach is essential in establishing an accurate diagnosis before proceeding to any definitive treatment.
  • Since the Pap smear already indicated abnormal cells, it suggests possible cervical dysplasia or malignancy, which mandates further investigation. 
  • Colposcopy-directed biopsy is the standard next step in cases with abnormal cytology findings, especially with additional risk factors like post-coital bleeding, which may indicate underlying cervical pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cone biopsy: A cone biopsy (or conization) is a more invasive procedure typically reserved for cases where high-grade lesions are suspected, or if the colposcopy-directed biopsy is inconclusive. It is not the immediate next step after an abnormal Pap smear without a confirmed high-grade lesion.

 

Option B. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive surgical procedure, usually indicated for confirmed cases of invasive cervical cancer or when other conservative treatments fail. It is not an initial step in the evaluation of abnormal cytology.

 

Option C. Repeat Pap smear: Repeating the Pap smear is unnecessary at this stage since an initial abnormal result has already been obtained. Instead, colposcopy is recommended to further investigate and directly sample any suspicious lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with an abnormal Pap smear showing atypical cells and symptoms such as post-coital bleeding, the next step is colposcopy with directed biopsy to obtain a definitive diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment.
