questions.text: A 2-day-old child has not passed meconium. The paediatrician suspects meconium ileus. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meconium causes occlusion at DJ flexure

 

  • Inspissated meconium pellets usually get stuck at the terminal ileum, not DJ flexure. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis is most often the associated finding: Cystic is commonly associated. It leads to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, leading to failure of digestion of meconium, forming meconium pellets which lead to obstruction at ileum.

 

Option C. Barium enema is useful for diagnosis: An abdominal radiograph may show a dilated small intestine with mottling. Fluid levels are generally not seen. The contrast enema shows an unused microcolon.

 

Option D. Bishop Koop operation was used for treating meconium ileus: The Bishop–Koop operation with its irrigating stoma is now rarely used. Various surgical procedures are used, including intestinal resection and temporary stoma formation, resection and primary anastomosis, and, in uncomplicated cases, enterotomy and irrigation of the bowel. 

 

Educational objective: 

 

  • Correctly understanding and identifying the location of meconium obstruction and its associated conditions and treatment options are critical in pediatric surgical care. 
  • The goal is to accurately diagnose and manage meconium ileus, often associated with cystic fibrosis, and recognize that obstruction typically occurs at the terminal ileum, not the DJ flexure.

choices.text: It stimulates platelet production by activating the thrombopoietin receptor.
It inhibits platelet destruction by blocking Fc receptors on macrophages.
It increases platelet count by enhancing megakaryocyte maturation through IL-11 receptor activation.
It reduces platelet clearance by inhibiting splenic macrophages.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) presents to the clinic with persistent low platelet counts despite prior treatment with corticosteroids and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG). Her hematologist prescribes eltrombopag to help increase her platelet count. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of eltrombopag?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It stimulates platelet production by activating the thrombopoietin receptor.

 

  • Eltrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that stimulates platelet production by binding to and activating the thrombopoietin receptor (TPO-R or c-Mpl receptor) on megakaryocyte progenitor cells. 
  • This activation promotes megakaryocyte differentiation and increases platelet production, which can be beneficial for patients with chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) or other conditions causing thrombocytopenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It inhibits platelet destruction by blocking Fc receptors on macrophages: This mechanism is more closely associated with IVIG therapy, which helps reduce platelet destruction in autoimmune thrombocytopenic conditions.

 

Option C. It increases platelet count by enhancing megakaryocyte maturation through IL-11 receptor activation: IL-11 receptor agonists stimulate platelet production but eltrombopag specifically works through the thrombopoietin receptor, not IL-11.

 

Option D. It reduces platelet clearance by inhibiting splenic macrophages: This is not the primary mechanism of eltrombopag, as it acts on platelet production rather than on platelet clearance or macrophage activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eltrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that increases platelet production by stimulating the thrombopoietin receptor, making it useful in conditions like chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).

questions.text:
Which of the following are a cause of neonatal seizures? 

 

1. Hyponatremia

2. Hypomagnesemia

3. Hypocalcemia

4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) 1, 2, 3 & 4. 

 

  • All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.
  • Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. 
  • Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

  • Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic. 
  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies. 
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint. 
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk. 
    • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint. 
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint. 
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of frequent falls and difficulty with balance, especially when walking. Upon examination, he displays an unsteady gait and mild tremor. A lesion is suspected in the cerebellum (marked in blue on an associated diagram). The fibers from this marked region primarily terminate in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red nucleus

 

  • The superior cerebellar peduncle (marked in blue in the image) is primarily responsible for carrying efferent fibers from the cerebellum to the brainstem. 
  • The majority of these fibers project to the red nucleus and the thalamus. 
  • The red nucleus is involved in motor coordination, and lesions in this area can result in tremors and difficulties with balance and gait, as seen in this patient. 
  • The cerebellum, through these connections, plays a crucial role in fine-tuning motor movements and maintaining balance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is primarily associated with the inferior cerebellar peduncle and receives afferent fibers from multiple sources to relay information to the cerebellum. This nucleus is not the termination point for fibers from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option C. Subthalamus: The subthalamus is involved in motor control but is not the primary termination site for fibers from the superior cerebellar peduncle. It plays a more significant role in the indirect pathways related to motor control but is not directly related to cerebellar outputs.

 

Option D. Fastigial nucleus: The fastigial nucleus is a deep cerebellar nucleus and is involved in maintaining posture and balance. However, it is an output source from the cerebellum and does not serve as a termination site for fibers from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fibers from the superior cerebellar peduncle primarily project to the red nucleus, which plays a critical role in motor coordination and balance.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing a patient’s protein sample for amino acid content. To confirm the specific presence of tyrosine, which color reaction should yield a positive result?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Millon’s test

 

  • Millon’s test is a chemical reaction specifically used to detect the presence of tyrosine in a protein sample. 
  • Tyrosine is one of the few amino acids that contain a phenolic group, which reacts uniquely with Millon’s reagent (a mixture of mercuric nitrate in nitric acid) to produce a red-colored complex upon heating. 
  • This reaction is specific to phenolic groups, which makes Millon’s test a reliable indicator for the presence of tyrosine in protein samples.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biuret test: The Biuret test is a general test for detecting peptide bonds and hence the presence of proteins. It does not identify specific amino acids, such as tyrosine, as it reacts with any compound containing two or more peptide bonds to produce a purple color.

 

Option B. Ninhydrin test: The Ninhydrin test is used to detect free amino acids in a sample by producing a deep blue or purple color. However, this test is non-specific and will react with most amino acids, not just tyrosine. It is commonly used for detecting amino acids in general but cannot confirm the specific presence of tyrosine.

 

Option D. Aldehyde test: The Aldehyde test is used to detect aldehyde functional groups and is not applicable for identifying specific amino acids such as tyrosine. This test is unrelated to protein or amino acid analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Millon’s test is specifically used to confirm the presence of tyrosine in a protein sample by producing a red-colored complex, distinguishing it from other amino acids that lack a phenolic group.

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing data collected from a survey of 500 individuals in a community to understand the general trends in health behavior. She organizes the data into tables and graphs and calculates the average age, income level, and health scores of the participants. Which statistical approach is she using?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Descriptive statistics

 

  • Descriptive Statistics: In this scenario, the researcher is organizing and summarizing the data using tables, graphs, and calculating measures like averages. 
  • Descriptive statistics are used to represent and describe the main features of a dataset in a straightforward manner without making predictions or generalizations beyond the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Applied statistics focuses on applying statistical techniques to address real-world problems but doesn't specifically refer to summarizing data.

 

Option B. Theoretical statistics deals with the mathematical theories underpinning statistical methods, not data organization or summarization.

 

Option D. Inferential statistics would involve making predictions or inferences about a larger population based on this sample, which is not the focus here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Descriptive statistics are essential for summarizing and visualizing data to highlight key features of a dataset, while inferential statistics allow for making broader generalizations based on that data.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman is undergoing a cesarean section, and the obstetrician finds that the fetal head is deeply engaged in the pelvis, making elevation difficult. An instrument is inserted vaginally, as shown in the image below, to assist in elevating the fetal head. What is this instrument called?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal pillow

 

  • The given image is Fetal pillow. The fetal pillow is a device used in cesarean sections where the fetal head is deeply engaged in the maternal pelvis. 
  • It is inserted vaginally and then inflated to gently lift the fetal head, facilitating a safer and easier extraction during a cesarean delivery. 
  • The device helps reduce trauma to both the mother and fetus by reducing the amount of force needed to dislodge the head.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal push: This is not a recognized instrument for elevating the fetal head in obstetric practice. “Push” does not refer to any specific device used during cesarean section to elevate a deeply engaged fetal head.

 

Option B. Fetal elevator: Although "elevator" describes the function of lifting the fetal head, this term is not commonly used to describe the device specifically designed for this purpose. The correct term for the device is "fetal pillow."

 

Option D. Fetal cushion: While “cushion” might imply a similar purpose, it is not the correct term for the instrument shown in the image. The device used in this scenario is specifically called a "fetal pillow."

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The fetal pillow is a device used in cesarean sections to elevate a deeply engaged fetal head, reducing delivery difficulty and minimizing trauma to both mother and fetus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of ulcerative colitis has been unresponsive to corticosteroid therapy. His symptoms include frequent bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. The physician decides to initiate a medication that can be effective in steroid-resistant cases of ulcerative colitis. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyclosporine

 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent often used as a rescue therapy in cases of severe, steroid-resistant ulcerative colitis. It acts by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby reducing T-cell activation and immune response. 
  • Cyclosporine is typically reserved for patients who have not responded to corticosteroids and may help avoid surgical intervention in refractory cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA): This is a first-line therapy for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis but is usually ineffective in cases that are steroid-resistant.

 

Option C. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is used as a maintenance therapy in ulcerative colitis and can help in reducing corticosteroid dependence. However, it is not as effective for immediate control of severe, steroid-resistant cases.

 

Option D. Racecadotril: Racecadotril is an anti-secretory agent used primarily to treat acute diarrhea. It has no role in the management of ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Cyclosporine is an effective option for managing severe, steroid-resistant ulcerative colitis, especially when patients fail to respond to corticosteroids.

questions.text:
Match each antimicrobial in Column A with its primary mechanism of action in Column B. 

 

Column A (Antimicrobials)

 

  1. Vancomycin
  2. Ciprofloxacin
  3. Amphotericin B
  4. Azithromycin

 

Column B (Mechanism of Action)

 

A. Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase
B. Binds to ergosterol, disrupting fungal cell membrane
C. Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to D-Ala-D-Ala
D. Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

 

  • Vancomycin (1-C): Vancomycin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of cell wall precursors, which prevents cross-linking and weakens the cell wall.
  • Ciprofloxacin (2-A): Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase, an enzyme critical for DNA replication and transcription.
  • Amphotericin B (3-B): Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores and leading to cell death.
  • Azithromycin (4-D): Azithromycin is a macrolide that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit, preventing peptide chain elongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each antimicrobial targets a specific cellular component: 

 

  • Vancomycin (cell wall)
  • Ciprofloxacin (DNA gyrase)
  • Amphotericin B (ergosterol in fungal membrane)
  • Azithromycin (50S ribosomal subunit)

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman with a history of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) undergoes the surgical procedure depicted in the image. Identify the most common complication of this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysphagia

 

  • The surgical procedure shown in the image is a fundoplication, commonly performed to treat GERD. 
  • The most common complication following a fundoplication is short term dysphagia, which occurs due to the wrap causing edema, making it difficult for food to pass through the esophagus into the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrence of symptomatic reflux: While a potential complication, recurrence of reflux is less common than dysphagia immediately after surgery.

 

Option C. Esophageal perforation: This is a serious but rare complication of fundoplication.

 

Option D. Gas bloat: It can occur but are not as common as dysphagia in patients undergoing this procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Short term dysphagia is the most common complication following fundoplication surgery for GERD. 
  • It is essential to monitor patients for this issue postoperatively and manage it promptly to ensure optimal recovery and function.

choices.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis
Forced expiration against an open glottis
Forced inspiration against a closed glottis
Forced inspiration against an open glottis

questions.text: Which of the following best describes what occurs at the start of the cough reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

 

The cough reflex begins with a deep inspiration, followed by forced expiration against a closed glottis, which builds up intrathoracic pressure. When the glottis suddenly opens, the air is expelled forcefully, clearing irritants from the airways. This phase of forced expiration with a closed glottis is crucial to generating an effective cough.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Forced expiration against an open glottis: Incorrect. Forced expiration against an open glottis does not allow for the buildup of the necessary intrathoracic pressure to expel air forcefully during a cough.

 

Option C. Forced inspiration against a closed glottis: Incorrect. Inspiration cannot occur against a closed glottis because air cannot enter the lungs when the glottis is closed.

 

Option D. Forced inspiration against an open glottis: Incorrect. While this describes normal inspiration, it does not apply to the mechanics of the cough reflex, which begins with a deep inspiration followed by forced expiration against a closed glottis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • he cough reflex starts with forced expiration against a closed glottis, generating high intrathoracic pressure before the glottis opens and air is expelled to clear the airways.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman opts for a transdermal contraceptive method and is prescribed the contraceptive patch, which contains both estrogen and progesterone components. What is the progesterone component in this contraceptive patch?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Norelgestromin

 

  • The progesterone component is Norelgestromin. The transdermal contraceptive patch typically combines an estrogen component (ethinyl estradiol) and a progesterone component (norelgestromin). 
  • Norelgestromin is a progestin that helps prevent ovulation, thickens cervical mucus to impede sperm penetration, and alters the endometrial lining to prevent implantation. 
  • The patch is worn on the skin and releases a steady dose of these hormones to provide effective contraception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Etonogestrel: Etonogestrel is used as the active progestin in certain contraceptive implants, not in transdermal patches. It provides long-term contraception when implanted subdermally but is not present in the patch.

 

Option C. Desogestrel: Desogestrel is a progestin used in some oral contraceptive pills, but it is not the progestin in the transdermal patch. It has different pharmacokinetics and is designed for daily oral intake rather than sustained release through a patch.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel: Levonorgestrel is used in various forms of contraception, such as emergency contraceptive pills and intrauterine devices, but it is not the progestin used in the transdermal patch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The progesterone component in the transdermal contraceptive patch is norelgestromin, combined with ethinyl estradiol for effective contraception.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most associated with malrotation during antegrade or retrograde femoral nailing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fracture comminution

 

  • Fracture comminution refers to the degree of fragmentation or splintering of the femoral bone at the site of the fracture. Comminuted fractures involve multiple bone fragments, making the reduction and realignment process more difficult.
  • Malrotation risk with comminuted fractures: In comminuted fractures, the fracture fragments may not be able to be aligned easily because the fragments often have no clear anatomical relationship to one another. This leads to difficulty in maintaining correct rotational alignment during the reduction process. 
  • Comminution can result in soft tissue interposition, loss of fracture reduction, or inability to achieve a proper rotational alignment during the insertion of the intramedullary nail.
  • Comminuted fractures are one of the primary causes of malrotation during femoral nailing because they make it more difficult to achieve and maintain the correct rotational alignment. The smaller and more fragmented the pieces of bone, the more likely the surgeon is to over-rotate or under-rotate the fragments while attempting to reduce and align the femur. Therefore, fracture comminution is the most associated factor with malrotation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entry Point:

 

  • The entry point for femoral nailing is critical for achieving proper alignment of the nail and maintaining the mechanical axis of the femur. The antegrade femoral nailing technique uses an entry point at the distal femur, typically at the greater trochanter, while retrograde nailing uses an entry point at the distal femoral condyles.
  • Malrotation risks from entry point: The correct entry point is crucial because misplacement of the entry point can lead to incorrect alignment of the femoral nail in the bone, which in turn can lead to rotational malalignment. However, entry point errors typically affect the anteroposterior alignment (i.e., the position of the nail in the sagittal plane) more than rotation specifically. Entry point errors would likely cause varus/valgus deformities rather than rotational malalignment, though it is a contributing factor.

  • Impact on malrotation: While an incorrect entry point can influence the alignment of the nail and overall fixation, it is not the most significant contributor to rotational malalignment compared to other factors like fracture pattern.

     

     

Option B. Fracture Level:

 

  • The fracture level refers to the location of the femoral fracture, whether it is in the proximal, mid-shaft, or distal femur. The level of the fracture is important because it influences the biomechanical forces acting on the fracture, the method of reduction, and the potential for deformities after fixation.
  • Higher fractures (proximal femur) might be associated with more difficult reductions because of the bony and soft tissue structures in the region (e.g., hip joint, muscles). Distal fractures, especially those near the knee, may also be challenging because of the close proximity to the knee joint, which can make rotational alignment more difficult.
  • While the fracture level affects the technical challenges of reduction, it is not the most important factor in causing rotational malalignment during nailing. The degree of comminution (destruction of the bone) or other factors like soft tissue interference are more likely to influence the outcome.

 

Option D. Surgeon's Experience:

 

  • The surgeon’s experience is an important factor in determining the success of a femoral nailing procedure. Experienced surgeons are more likely to achieve proper fracture reduction and alignment, and to be able to make adjustments if rotational malalignment occurs.
  • Inexperienced surgeons may struggle more with achieving correct alignment and managing complex fractures, which could increase the risk of malrotation. However, a skilled surgeon can generally correct malrotation during the procedure, especially if they are aware of the challenges associated with certain fracture types.
  • While surgeon experience is important, it is not as directly related to malrotation as the comminution or fracture pattern itself. Even experienced surgeons can struggle with highly comminuted fractures or with fractures in challenging anatomical locations.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Comminution makes it significantly more difficult to achieve proper reduction and rotational alignment of the femur during nailing. 
  • When the bone is shattered into multiple fragments, it becomes harder to align them properly, leading to a higher risk of malrotation.

questions.text: A large healthcare facility is planning to establish a waste management system specifically for the disposal of high-risk infectious materials. Given that budget constraints are not an issue, which of the following options provides the most comprehensive method for safe and effective management of infectious waste, ensuring minimal environmental impact?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double chamber incinerator

 

  • A double chamber pyrolytic incinerator is designed to handle infectious waste more effectively than single chamber models. 
  • The first chamber incinerates the waste, while the second chamber ensures any remaining hazardous emissions, such as gases and particulates, are further combusted at high temperatures. 
  • This dual process significantly reduces harmful emissions, making it a preferred choice for facilities that prioritize environmental safety and effective pathogen destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single chamber incinerator: While useful, it lacks the secondary combustion feature of a double chamber, potentially releasing more pollutants into the atmosphere.

 

Option C. Microwave disinfection system: Although it is effective for certain sterilization needs, it does not incinerate waste and may not be suitable for all types of infectious materials.

 

Option D. Chemical disinfection process: While this approach can disinfect waste, it may not completely eliminate all pathogens, particularly in solid and high-risk medical waste. It also requires careful handling of chemicals, which can pose additional safety concerns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Double chamber pyrolytic incinerators provide the most thorough and environmentally safe solution for the disposal of infectious medical waste by utilizing a two-step combustion

choices.text: It is characterized by cellular pleomorphism
It is not associated with architectural abnormalities
It is a feature of mesenchymal cells

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a biopsy after an abnormal screening test. The pathology report describes dysplasia in the sampled cells. Which of the following accurately describes a characteristic feature of this dysplasia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is characterized by cellular pleomorphism

 

  • Dysplasia refers to abnormal cellular growth, commonly occurring in epithelial tissues. 
  • Dysplastic cells exhibit cellular pleomorphism (variation in cell shape and size), nuclear abnormalities (such as hyperchromatism), and increased mitotic activity. 
  • These features are often accompanied by architectural disorganization within the tissue.
  • Pleomorphism is a key characteristic of dysplasia, which differentiates it from other forms of abnormal cellular changes. 
  • While dysplasia can progress to cancer, it does not do so inevitably; some cases may regress, especially if the stimulus causing the dysplasia is removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It inevitably progresses to cancer: Incorrect. Dysplasia has the potential to progress to cancer, particularly if the dysplasia is high-grade or if the causative factors persist. However, it does not invariably lead to cancer and may regress if treated or if the underlying cause is removed.

 

Option C. It is not associated with architectural abnormalities: Incorrect. Dysplasia is indeed associated with architectural abnormalities, such as disorganized cell layers and loss of normal tissue structure.

 

Option D. It is a feature of mesenchymal cells: Incorrect. Dysplasia most commonly occurs in epithelial cells rather than mesenchymal cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dysplasia is characterized by cellular pleomorphism, nuclear abnormalities, and architectural disorganization within epithelial tissues. 
  • It is a potentially reversible precursor to cancer but does not always progress to malignancy.

questions.text: A researcher is evaluating a new diagnostic test and wants to compare its results with those of an established gold standard test. Which of the following is the best method for comparing the results between the two tests?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bland and Altman analysis

 

  • Bland and Altman analysis is the best method for comparing the agreement between a new test and a gold standard test.
  • This method assesses the agreement by plotting the differences between the two tests against their average, which allows visualization of any systematic bias and limits of agreement. 
  • It’s especially useful for continuous data where the goal is to evaluate how well the new test results match those of the gold standard across a range of values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Correlation study: Correlation only measures the strength of association, not agreement, between two tests. It can indicate that two tests yield similar trends, but it does not confirm that they give similar results.

 

Option B. Regression study: Regression analysis models the relationship between two variables, but it does not assess agreement and is not appropriate for comparing new tests with gold standards.

 

Option D. Kolmogorov-Smirnov test: This is a non-parametric test to compare two sample distributions, not to measure agreement between two tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bland and Altman analysis is the preferred method for assessing agreement between a new test and a gold standard, as it visually represents differences and identifies systematic biases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman attends her 14-week antenatal checkup and undergoes a Doppler ultrasound of the uterine arteries. This test is primarily used at this stage of pregnancy to predict which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early-onset preeclampsia

 

  • Uterine artery Doppler ultrasound at 14-16 weeks of pregnancy is primarily conducted to assess the risk of developing early-onset preeclampsia. 
  • This test measures blood flow resistance in the uterine arteries, which supply blood to the placenta. 
  • Increased resistance in these arteries at this stage may suggest poor placentation, a condition linked to the development of early-onset preeclampsia, which often presents before 34 weeks of gestation. 
  • Identifying high resistance patterns enables healthcare providers to monitor patients closely and implement preventive measures to reduce the risk of preeclampsia.
  • The early detection of preeclampsia, especially the early-onset form, is critical because this condition can lead to severe complications in both the mother and fetus, including hypertension, renal dysfunction, and preterm birth. 
  • Early-onset preeclampsia is typically more severe than late-onset preeclampsia and is often associated with other complications, such as fetal growth restriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal growth restriction: Although abnormal uterine artery Doppler findings can be associated with fetal growth restriction, this test is not primarily used to detect growth restriction at 14 weeks, as this condition typically manifests later in pregnancy. Fetal growth restriction becomes a primary concern in the second and third trimesters and is monitored through serial growth ultrasounds.

 

Option C. Placenta accreta: Placenta accreta refers to the abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall, often due to scarring from previous surgeries. It is usually assessed through ultrasound later in pregnancy and confirmed by imaging findings suggestive of placental invasion. Uterine artery Doppler is not a primary test for placenta accreta diagnosis.

 

Option D. Late-onset preeclampsia: While uterine artery Doppler ultrasound can sometimes indicate risk factors for preeclampsia in general, it is specifically valuable for detecting early-onset preeclampsia. Late-onset preeclampsia, which typically occurs after 34 weeks, is less likely to show abnormal uterine artery Doppler findings during the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine artery Doppler ultrasound at 14-16 weeks is primarily used to assess the risk for early-onset preeclampsia by detecting abnormal blood flow patterns in the uterine arteries, indicating potential poor placentation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with fever, malaise, and pleuritic chest pain for the past 3 days. He denies recent travel or contact with sick individuals. On examination, his temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), heart rate is 105/min, and there is a systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration. Chest auscultation reveals scattered crackles. Blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following valves is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tricuspid valve


In intravenous drug users, infective endocarditis most commonly affects the tricuspid valve due to direct introduction of pathogens into the venous system. Right-sided endocarditis, particularly of the tricuspid valve, is typically associated with symptoms like fever, septic pulmonary emboli (causing pleuritic chest pain and crackles), and a murmur that increases with inspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic valve: While the aortic valve can be involved in endocarditis, it is more common in left-sided endocarditis and is less frequently affected in intravenous drug users, where the tricuspid valve is usually involved.

 

Option B. Mitral valve: The mitral valve is commonly affected in left-sided endocarditis, especially with non-IV drug users or in patients with pre-existing valve disease. It is less commonly involved in IV drug use-associated endocarditis.

 

Option C. Pulmonary valve: The pulmonary valve is rarely involved in endocarditis, even in IV drug users, as it is less susceptible than the tricuspid valve.

 

Educational Objective:


For intravenous drug users, infective endocarditis most frequently affects the tricuspid valve due to its direct venous connection, which leads to right-sided symptoms and septic emboli in the lungs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to a tropical disease clinic with swelling and discomfort in his lower limbs. He reports spending extended periods outdoors in a rural area of Southeast Asia, where he was frequently exposed to mosquitoes. A nighttime blood smear stained with Giemsa reveals microfilarial organisms, as shown in the image. Which species is most likely causing this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brugia malayi

 

  • The distinctive characteristics of Brugia malayi microfilariae include its short cephalic space, nuclei that extend to the tip of the tail, and the presence of two nuclei at the tip, which are clearly identifiable in a stained preparation.
  • These specific traits help differentiate Brugia malayi from other filarial species.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wuchereria bancrofti: Incorrect. Wuchereria bancrofti also has microfilariae that appear in blood smears, but its tail is typically free of nuclei at the tip, distinguishing it from Brugia malayi.

 

 

Option C. Loa loa: Incorrect. Loa loa microfilariae also circulate in blood, but they can be distinguished by their larger size and the lack of terminal nuclei at the tip of the tail.

 

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Incorrect. Onchocerca volvulus microfilariae are found primarily in skin snips, not in peripheral blood, and they lack nuclei at the tail tip.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brugia malayi microfilariae can be identified by the presence of nuclei extending to the tail tip, with two terminal nuclei, a characteristic that helps distinguish it from other filarial species.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old newborn is brought to the emergency department with vomiting, poor feeding, and lethargy. The infant has had low weight gain since birth and appears dehydrated. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmentation of the skin, particularly around the nipples and genitalia. Laboratory results show the following: 

 

  • Serum sodium: 124 mEq/L (Normal: 135-145 mEq/L)
  • Serum potassium: 6.3 mEq/L (Normal: 3.5-5.0 mEq/L)
  • Serum glucose: 52 mg/dL (Normal: 70-110 mg/dL)
  • Plasma renin activity: Elevated
  • Serum cortisol: Low
  • 17-hydroxyprogesterone: Significantly elevated

 

Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the CYP21A2 gene. Based on the findings, which of the following additional abnormalities is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated androstenedione levels

 

  • In 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which is the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), the enzymatic block prevents the conversion of 17-hydroxyprogesterone to cortisol and aldosterone. 
  • As a result, precursors like 17-hydroxyprogesterone accumulate and are shunted toward the production of androgens, leading to increased levels of androstenedione and other androgens. 
  • This accounts for the virilization and hyperpigmentation seen in affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased 11-deoxycorticosterone levels: This is incorrect. Elevated 11-deoxycorticosterone levels are typically seen in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, not in 21-hydroxylase deficiency. In 21-hydroxylase deficiency, the blockage in the pathway leads to decreased production of both aldosterone and cortisol, but not 11-deoxycorticosterone.

 

Option C. Decreased levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone: This is incorrect. In 21-hydroxylase deficiency, there is an accumulation of 17-hydroxyprogesterone due to the blocked pathway. Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone is actually a hallmark diagnostic marker of 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

Option D. Increased aldosterone synthesis: This is incorrect. In 21-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthesis is reduced due to the enzyme defect, leading to symptoms of salt wasting such as hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and dehydration, as seen in this patient. The deficiency in aldosterone further stimulates renin secretion, hence the elevated plasma renin activity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • 21-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, results in low cortisol and aldosterone levels and increased androgen production. 
  • This leads to salt-wasting symptoms (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia), hypoglycemia, and hyperpigmentation due to elevated ACTH. 
  • Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone and androstenedione levels are characteristic of this condition and are crucial diagnostic markers.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is most commonly associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MEN II

 

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is frequently associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type II (MEN II), especially in patients with a family history of endocrine tumors or other features of MEN II. 
  • MEN II is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism (specifically in MEN IIa). 
  • There are two subtypes of MEN II: MEN IIa and MEN IIb, both of which include MTC as a major feature. 
  • MEN II is linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, and early detection through genetic testing is crucial for patient management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MEN I: MEN I, also known as Wermer syndrome, is associated with tumors in the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary gland. It does not include medullary thyroid carcinoma, making it an incorrect association with MTC.

 

Option C. Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a hereditary cancer syndrome associated with various malignancies, including sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors. However, it is not typically associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is an autoimmune thyroid disorder associated with hypothyroidism. While chronic inflammation in Hashimoto's can increase the risk of papillary thyroid carcinoma, it is not linked to medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma is strongly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type II (MEN II), a genetic syndrome that includes MTC, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism in MEN IIa.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with mildly greasy lesions emitting a strong odor on the scalp, knees, elbows, and behind the ears. There are keratotic papules over the seborrheic areas. Histopathology reveals the presence of corps ronds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratosis follicularis

 

The correct answer is Keratosis follicularis (also known as Darier disease). This condition often presents in childhood or adolescence with greasy, malodorous papules, particularly in seborrheic areas (scalp, face, and central chest), along with keratotic papules. The presence of corps ronds and grains on histopathological examination is characteristic of keratosis follicularis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus foliaceus: This autoimmune condition presents with superficial blisters and erosions but typically lacks the greasy, keratotic papules and malodor seen in keratosis follicularis. Histologically, it does not exhibit corps ronds.

 

Option C. Seborrheic Dermatitis: Seborrheic dermatitis is a common inflammatory condition that affects seborrheic areas of the skin and presents as erythematous, scaly patches with mild itching. While it can produce greasy lesions on the scalp and face, it does not typically cause keratotic papules or a strong odor.

 

Option D. Hailey-Hailey disease: This genetic disorder affects the intertriginous areas and may have a malodorous quality. However, it lacks corps ronds and does not typically show the keratotic papules seen in keratosis follicularis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis follicularis (Darier disease) is characterized by greasy, malodorous papules in seborrheic areas, and histopathology reveals corps ronds and grains.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman in her third trimester presents with abdominal cramping and lower back pain. She is unsure if she is experiencing true labor. She describes the pain as intermittent and sometimes relieved by rest and pain medication. On examination, which finding would best help distinguish true labor from false labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progressive cervical dilation and effacement

 

  • True labor is characterized by progressive changes in the cervix, including both dilation (widening of the cervical canal) and effacement (thinning of the cervix). 
  • In true labor, contractions lead to these progressive cervical changes, which indicate that labor is advancing and the body is preparing for delivery. In contrast, false labor, often called Braxton Hicks contractions, does not cause significant or sustained cervical changes. 
  • Therefore, the best parameter to differentiate true labor from false labor is observing progressive cervical dilation and effacement on physical examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relief on sedation and NSAIDs: Pain relief with sedation or NSAIDs can be seen in false labor. False labor contractions often subside or decrease with rest, hydration, and pain relief measures. However, relief from sedation or NSAIDs is not a definitive indicator of true labor and can be misleading, as true labor contractions will typically continue despite such interventions.

 

Option B. Rupture of membranes: While rupture of membranes (breaking of the water) can occur during true labor, it is not always present initially and can also occur without labor, particularly in cases of prelabor rupture of membranes (PROM). Therefore, it is not the most reliable parameter to distinguish true labor from false labor.

 

Option C. Formation of bag of waters: The formation of the bag of waters, or the amniotic sac bulging through the cervix, may occur in labor but is not a specific finding that reliably differentiates true from false labor. Additionally, it is not always visible or palpable in all cases of true labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Progressive cervical dilation and effacement is the most reliable parameter to differentiate true labor from false labor, as true labor involves cervical changes that signify advancing labor.

questions.text: A patient of HIV developed visual problems. The fundus examination revealed the features shown in the image. Drug of choice for treatment of this condition is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ganciclovir

 

  • The image and clinical presentation are suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis, a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS. 
  • CMV retinitis is characterized by retinal hemorrhages, white fluffy retinal infiltrates, and exudates, often described as a "pizza pie" appearance. 
  • If left untreated, CMV retinitis can lead to retinal detachment and blindness.
  • Ganciclovir is the drug of choice for CMV retinitis due to its antiviral activity against CMV. It can be administered intravenously or as an intravitreal injection to achieve high concentrations in the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole: Cotrimoxazole is used for prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) in HIV patients but is ineffective against CMV.

 

Option C. Acyclovir: Acyclovir is effective against herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) but has limited activity against CMV.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, primarily effective against bacterial infections, and has no efficacy against viral infections like CMV.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Ganciclovir is the drug of choice for treating CMV retinitis in HIV patients, a condition characterized by retinal hemorrhages and exudates on fundus examination.

Management of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) with lifestyle changes

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct indication for the use of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists in gynecology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use of GnRH agonists to treat endometriosis

 

  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are commonly used in gynecology to manage symptoms of endometriosis by creating a hypoestrogenic state, which helps reduce the growth and activity of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. 
  • These medications act by initially stimulating, then downregulating GnRH receptors in the pituitary gland, leading to reduced estrogen production and ultimately creating a temporary menopausal-like state. 
  • This treatment can provide significant relief from the pain and heavy bleeding associated with endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone replacement therapy for menopause: GnRH agonists are not used as hormone replacement therapy in menopausal women. Hormone replacement therapy for menopause typically involves estrogen and/or progestin to relieve menopausal symptoms, which is contrary to the estrogen-suppressive effects of GnRH agonists.

 

Option B. Ovulation induction to improve fertility: GnRH agonists are generally not used to induce ovulation. Ovulation induction for infertility is more commonly achieved using medications like clomiphene citrate or gonadotropins. In fact, GnRH agonists initially suppress ovarian function, which would counteract the goal of inducing ovulation.

 

Option D. Management of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) with lifestyle changes: While lifestyle changes are an essential part of managing PCOS, GnRH agonists are not a standard treatment for PCOS. Management of PCOS usually focuses on lifestyle modifications, hormonal contraceptives, metformin, and anti-androgen medications to regulate menstrual cycles and manage symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • GnRH agonists are indicated in gynecology for the treatment of endometriosis by inducing a hypoestrogenic state to reduce the growth of ectopic endometrial tissue, alleviating pain and bleeding.

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 5 hours of worsening difficulty breathing, dizziness, and a sensation of "fluttering" in his chest. He has a known history of heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction but does not adhere to his medication regimen. On physical examination, bilateral crackles are heard in the lower lung fields, and pulses are diminished in all extremities. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome Type A

 

WPW Syndrome Type A is characterized by the presence of a delta wave on the ECG, which is a slurred upstroke at the beginning of the QRS complex, and a short PR interval. This condition can present with palpitations, dizziness, and dyspnea due to its association with arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: This condition would show an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG with no distinct P waves, which is not consistent with WPW features.

 

Option C. Multifocal atrial tachycardia: This arrhythmia shows varying P wave morphologies on ECG with irregularly irregular intervals, typically in patients with significant pulmonary disease, unlike the specific delta wave pattern seen in WPW.

 

Option D. Left bundle branch block (LBBB): LBBB presents with a broad QRS complex and a specific pattern of delayed left ventricular activation, not with the delta waves or short PR interval characteristic of WPW.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

WPW Syndrome should be suspected when an ECG shows a short PR interval and delta waves, and it can lead to potentially life-threatening arrhythmias due to an accessory conduction pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-absorbable suture material?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Silk

 

  • Silk is a non-absorbable suture material, typically used for ligature and suturing where long-term tissue support is necessary. 
  • It can be braided or twisted multifilament and is coated or uncoated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyglyactin (Vicryl): It is a braided multifilament absorbable suture material used in gut and biliary anastomoses, vascular ligatures, and subcuticular wound closures.

 

Option B. Poliglecaprone (Monocryl): It is a monofilament absorbable suture material often used for subcuticular skin suturing, soft tissue ligation, and gastrointestinal surgeries.

 

Option D. Catgut: It is another absorbable suture material used for ligation of superficial vessels and suturing of tissues that heal rapidly, such as subcutaneous tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-absorbable suture materials, such as Silk, are ideal for use in scenarios where long-term tissue support is needed, unlike absorbable sutures that degrade over time.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient refusal

 

  • Patient refusal is considered an absolute contraindication for spinal anesthesia. 
  • Informed consent is essential in medical procedures, and if a patient refuses the procedure, it cannot be performed under any circumstances. 
  • Respecting patient autonomy is a core principle in medical ethics, making this a strict contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mild hypovolemia: Mild hypovolemia (slight decrease in blood volume) is generally not an absolute contraindication for spinal anesthesia. However, severe hypovolemia is an absolute contraindication, as spinal anesthesia can cause vasodilation and a further drop in blood pressure, which could be dangerous for a severely hypovolemic patient. Mild hypovolemia should be corrected, but it does not strictly prohibit spinal anesthesia.

 

Option C. Controlled hypertension: Controlled hypertension is not a contraindication for spinal anesthesia. If a patient’s blood pressure is well-managed, they can safely undergo spinal anesthesia. However, patients with uncontrolled or very high blood pressure may require further evaluation and management before proceeding with any anesthesia, but it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option D. History of migraine headaches: A history of migraines is not a contraindication for spinal anesthesia. Although spinal anesthesia can sometimes cause a headache as a side effect (post-dural puncture headache), having a history of migraines does not increase the risk of complications directly related to spinal anesthesia. Proper technique and hydration can help manage the risk of headache.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Absolute contraindications for spinal anesthesia are conditions where the risks of the procedure outweigh any potential benefits. 
  • These include patient refusal, infection at the injection site, increased intracranial pressure, allergy to anesthetic drugs, coagulopathy or bleeding disorders, and severe hypovolemia. 
  • Recognizing these contraindications is crucial to ensure patient safety and appropriate anesthesia management.

choices.text: Skinfold thickness is measured in the subscapular region
Weight is measured to the nearest 100 grams
Standing height is about 1.7 cm less than recumbent length

questions.text: All are true about anthropometric measurements except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Standing height is about 1.7 cm less than recumbent length

 

  • Standing height is not typically 1.7 cm less than recumbent length. 
  • According to Growth Standards, 2008, standing height is actually around 0.7 cm less than recumbent length. 
  • This discrepancy is due to differences in body positioning when measuring height versus length. 
  • For children under 2 years of age, recumbent length (measured lying down) is preferred, while for children over 2 years who can stand, standing height is measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth weight triples by 1 year: Birth weight does indeed typically triples by 1 year. This is a well-recognized pediatric growth milestone, with birth weight doubling by 6 months and tripling by the end of the first year.

 

Option B. Skinfold thickness is measured in the subscapular region: Skinfold thickness can be measured in various locations, one of which is the subscapular region. This region is commonly used in clinical settings to assess body fat and nutritional status.

 

Option C. Weight is measured to the nearest 100 grams: Weight measurement is generally taken to the nearest 100 grams in clinical practice to ensure accuracy and monitor growth, especially in children where slight changes in weight can indicate important health trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When performing anthropometric measurements in children, standing height for those over 2 years is typically about 0.7 cm less than recumbent length. 
  • Accurate anthropometric measurements are essential for tracking growth and development in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a 3-week history of fever, unresponsive to antibiotics and anti-malarials. He also has abdominal distension, and the rk39 dipstick test is positive. What is the most appropriate next management step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B

 

  • The rk39 dipstick test is a rapid diagnostic test for Leishmania donovani, which causes visceral leishmaniasis (also known as kala-azar). 
  • The patient’s presentation with prolonged fever, abdominal distension (likely from splenomegaly), and positive rk39 test suggests visceral leishmaniasis. Amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for this condition, particularly in endemic areas and cases where there is resistance to first-line agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bedaquiline: This is an anti-tuberculosis drug used primarily for multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and has no role in treating visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Tigecycline: An antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, particularly those resistant to other antibiotics. It is not effective for leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Fluconazole: An antifungal medication with no efficacy against Leishmania infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive rk39 dipstick test along with prolonged fever and abdominal symptoms strongly suggests visceral leishmaniasis. 
  • The preferred treatment for this condition is Amphotericin B, particularly in cases where the disease does not respond to standard treatments for common febrile illnesses.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of various drugs on cellular signal transduction pathways. Which of the following drugs is most likely to utilize the signaling mechanism illustrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin

 

  • The image illustrates a receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) signaling pathway. 
  • This mechanism involves ligand binding, receptor dimerization, activation of intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, and phosphorylation of tyrosine residues on the receptor. 
  • These phosphorylated sites then serve as docking sites for intracellular signaling proteins, which relay the signal further into the cell.
  • Insulin functions through this type of receptor (an RTK) and follows a similar signaling cascade. 
  • Upon binding to its receptor, insulin induces dimerization and activation of the tyrosine kinase domains, leading to downstream effects on glucose uptake and metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salbutamol: Salbutamol is a beta-2 adrenergic agonist, which acts via G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) rather than through receptor tyrosine kinases. GPCR signaling does not involve the phosphorylation cascade shown here.

 

Option C. Aldosterone: Aldosterone is a steroid hormone that binds to intracellular receptors, not surface receptors like RTKs. Its mechanism involves direct modulation of gene transcription, rather than phosphorylation cascades.

 

Option D. Nicotine: Nicotine acts on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which are ligand-gated ion channels. This mechanism is distinct from RTKs and does not involve receptor dimerization or tyrosine phosphorylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Insulin signals through receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) pathways, involving receptor dimerization and phosphorylation, as shown in the image.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with a progressive onset of involuntary movements, changes in personality, and gradual cognitive decline. He mentions that his father exhibited similar symptoms and passed away in his 50s. A brain MRI is performed, showing characteristic findings. Based on the clinical presentation and MRI results, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington’s disease

 

  • Huntington’s disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric disturbances, often with a family history of similar symptoms. 
  • The MRI of a patient with Huntington’s disease typically shows atrophy of the caudate nuclei and putamen, which results in enlarged lateral ventricles, creating a distinctive appearance sometimes described as "boxcar ventricles."
  • In this case, the patient's age, family history of similar symptoms, progressive involuntary movements (chorea), personality changes, and cognitive decline all point towards Huntington’s disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer’s disease: Alzheimer’s disease typically presents with progressive memory impairment and cognitive decline, often without significant involuntary movements or motor symptoms like those in Huntington’s disease. Alzheimer’s disease is not associated with caudate atrophy on MRI; instead, it commonly shows generalized cortical atrophy, particularly in the hippocampal region.

 

Option B. Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disorder presenting with neurological deficits that fluctuate over time and affect multiple parts of the central nervous system. MRI in multiple sclerosis shows demyelinating plaques, not the caudate atrophy seen in Huntington’s disease.

 

Option C. Parkinson’s disease: Parkinson’s disease primarily involves motor symptoms such as resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, along with cognitive decline in later stages. MRI findings in Parkinson’s disease are usually unremarkable in early stages, though later stages may show atrophy of the substantia nigra. The characteristic caudate and putamen atrophy with ventricular enlargement is not typical of Parkinson’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Huntington’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, marked by progressive chorea, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.
  •  MRI findings typically include atrophy of the caudate and putamen, leading to enlarged lateral ventricles.

questions.text: A junior resident is studying virus structures for her thesis and notes that certain viruses possess a lipid envelope, which plays a key role in viral entry into host cells. Which of the following viruses is known to have a lipid envelope?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpesvirus

 

  • Herpesviruses are enveloped viruses, possessing a lipid envelope derived from the host cell membrane. 
  • This lipid envelope contains viral glycoproteins essential for attachment and entry into host cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reovirus: Reoviruses are non-enveloped and have a double-layered protein capsid.

 

Option C. Picornavirus: Such as poliovirus, are also non-enveloped and have an icosahedral capsid structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpesviruses are enveloped viruses, unlike reoviruses and picornaviruses, which lack a lipid envelope.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with symptoms of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) eight months after a previous abortion. Laboratory results reveal an elevated hCG level of 120,000 mIU/mL. X-ray findings indicate metastatic disease in liver. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) EMA-CO regimen

 

  • This patient has advanced gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) with a high hCG level (120,000 mIU/mL) and evidence of metastatic disease in the liver, which classifies her as a high-risk case. 
  • The presence of metastasis and a significantly elevated hCG level indicate that a more aggressive and multi-agent chemotherapy regimen is needed.
  • EMA-CO (Etoposide, Methotrexate, and Actinomycin D, followed by Cyclophosphamide and Vincristine) is the preferred treatment for high-risk GTN with metastatic disease. This combination regimen is effective for advanced GTN cases and has been shown to improve outcomes, even in patients with metastatic disease in organs like the liver or brain. The combination therapy targets the neoplastic cells from multiple pathways, thereby enhancing the chance of remission in high-risk cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate-folinic acid 8-day regimen: This regimen is typically used for low-risk GTN cases, not for high-risk or metastatic disease. Methotrexate alone would not be effective for advanced cases with liver metastasis and a high hCG level.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Although hysterectomy may reduce tumor burden, it is not the primary treatment for high-risk GTN with metastasis. Surgery alone would not address the metastatic disease in the liver and is generally reserved for cases unresponsive to chemotherapy or when bleeding from the uterus poses a life-threatening risk.

 

Option D. Actinomycin D injection 5-day regimen: Like methotrexate, Actinomycin D is typically used in low-risk GTN. For high-risk cases with distant metastases, single-agent chemotherapy regimens are insufficient, and combination chemotherapy (like EMA-CO) is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) with metastasis and elevated hCG levels, multi-agent chemotherapy (e.g., EMA-CO) is the most appropriate treatment approach to improve survival and achieve remission.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of extensive small bowel resection due to mesenteric ischemia presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. She has been managing her symptoms with oral rehydration solutions and dietary modifications. Despite these measures, she continues to experience malabsorption and progressive weight loss. Laboratory studies reveal hypoalbuminemia, vitamin B12 deficiency, and low iron levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic therapy to improve intestinal adaptation and nutrient absorption in this patient with short bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Teduglutide

 

Teduglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analog that promotes intestinal adaptation by increasing mucosal growth, enhancing absorptive capacity, and reducing the need for parenteral nutrition in patients with short bowel syndrome. It is particularly effective in patients with severe malabsorption who do not respond to dietary or symptomatic management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loperamide: Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal agent that can help manage symptoms of diarrhea but does not address the underlying malabsorption or promote intestinal adaptation.

 

Option B. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): PPIs can reduce gastric acid secretion, which may help in patients with small bowel syndrome by decreasing diarrhea from acid hypersecretion. However, they do not improve nutrient absorption or intestinal adaptation.

 

Option D. Octreotide: Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, reduces gastrointestinal secretions and may be used in cases of refractory diarrhea. However, it may worsen nutrient absorption and is not the preferred therapy for short bowel syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Teduglutide is the treatment of choice in patients with short bowel syndrome who experience severe malabsorption, as it promotes intestinal adaptation and improves nutrient absorption, potentially reducing dependency on parenteral nutrition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of acid reflux begins taking an over-the-counter antacid. After a few days, she notices an increase in bowel movements and occasional loose stools. Which of the following components in her antacid is most likely causing this gastrointestinal side effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Magnesium hydroxide

 

  • Magnesium hydroxide is commonly found in antacids and is known for causing diarrhea due to its osmotic effect, which draws water into the intestines. 
  • This can lead to loose stools or diarrhea, especially with regular use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium carbonate: Calcium carbonate is more likely to cause constipation, not diarrhea.

 

Option C. Aluminium hydroxide: Aluminium hydroxide is also associated with constipation and is often combined with magnesium hydroxide in antacids to balance side effects.

 

Option D. Bismuth subsalicylate: This ingredient, commonly found in anti-diarrheal medications, can cause dark stools but does not typically lead to diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Magnesium hydroxide in antacids can lead to diarrhea, whereas calcium and aluminium based antacids are more likely to cause constipation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with jaundice, pruritus, and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a mass at the hepatic hilum involving the bifurcation of the right and left hepatic bile ducts. Which of the following best describes this type of tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nodular type of cholangiocarcinoma

 

  • A Klatskin tumor, also known as a hilar cholangiocarcinoma, specifically arises at the confluence of the right and left hepatic bile ducts at the hepatic hilum. 
  • It is a nodular type of cholangiocarcinoma that leads to bile duct obstruction, causing symptoms such as jaundice, pruritus, and weight loss. 
  • Due to its location, it is challenging to resect and often has a poor prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma: This variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) typically affects younger patients without liver cirrhosis and originates from liver cells, not bile duct cells, so it does not occur at the hepatic hilum as Klatskin tumors do.

 

Option C. Gallbladder carcinoma: Gallbladder carcinoma arises within the gallbladder itself and isanatomically distinct from the bile duct confluence. It typically presents differently and does not affect the hepatic hilum like a Klatskin tumor.

 

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Hepatocellular carcinoma originates in liver parenchyma, not in the bile ducts. While HCC can occasionally cause symptoms such as jaundice, it does not typically arise at the hepatic hilum where Klatskin tumors are found.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Klatskin tumors, or hilar cholangiocarcinomas, are nodular cholangiocarcinomas located at the hepatic hilum, specifically at the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. 
  • They present with obstructive jaundice due to bile duct obstruction and are challenging to manage surgically due to their anatomical location.

questions.text: A public health researcher aims to investigate the cause-effect relationship between physical activity levels and the development of cardiovascular diseases over time. To best establish this sequence and strengthen the evidence for causation, which study design should the researcher choose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Longitudinal

 

  • A longitudinal study is the preferred design when assessing causality, as it follows participants over time, observing the sequence of exposure and outcome. 
  • This helps establish a temporal relationship necessary for causation. 
  • By repeatedly observing the same individuals, a longitudinal design can track changes and patterns that inform the direction of causality between physical activity levels and cardiovascular outcomes. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Case report: Describes an individual case and lacks generalizability or causal inference.

 

Option C. Case series report: Examines a series of cases but still lacks control and causative inference.

 

Option D. Quasi-experimental: While useful in intervention studies, it may lack the robust control needed to definitively establish causation compared to a longitudinal design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Longitudinal studies are ideal for establishing temporal relationships, which are crucial for demonstrating causality in epidemiological research.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. He also complains of nasal congestion, occasional epistaxis, and arthralgia. On examination, there is a saddle-nose deformity, bilateral crackles on chest auscultation, and lower limb edema. Chest CT is shown below.

 

 

Laboratory findings are as follows:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL
  • Platelets: 230,000/µL
  • Creatinine: 3.4 mg/dL 
  • Urinalysis: Hematuria, RBC casts, proteinuria (2.5 g/day)
  • anti-proteinase 3 antibodies: Positive
  • ESR: 80

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)

 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a systemic vasculitis affecting small-to-medium-sized vessels, commonly involving the respiratory tract and kidneys. The patient’s cavitary lung lesions, hemoptysis, nasal deformity, renal involvement (elevated creatinine, hematuria, RBC casts, and proteinuria), and positive c-ANCA (anti-proteinase 3 antibodies) strongly suggest GPA. Renal involvement in GPA manifests as pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis can cause cavitary lung lesions, but renal findings (e.g., RBC casts) are atypical. Additionally, c-ANCA positivity and systemic vasculitis symptoms do not occur in TB.

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome causes hemoptysis and glomerulonephritis but is associated with anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies, not c-ANCA. It also does not cause cavitary lung lesions or upper respiratory tract findings such as epistaxis or saddle-nose deformity.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: Lung abscesses cause cavitary lesions but are typically accompanied by fever, foul-smelling sputum, and a history of aspiration or infection. Renal involvement is not a feature of lung abscesses.

 

Educational Objective:


Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a multisystem vasculitis characterized by respiratory tract involvement (e.g., cavitary lesions, epistaxis, saddle-nose deformity) and pauci-immune glomerulonephritis (e.g., RBC casts, hematuria, and proteinuria), with c-ANCA positivity being a hallmark diagnostic feature.

questions.text: The plate shown depicts colonies of Haemophilus influenzae growing in proximity to a streak of Staphylococcus on blood agar. Which of the following factors is responsible for this growth phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) V factor

 

  • Haemophilus influenzae requires specific growth factors, X factor (hemin) and V factor (NAD or NADP), which are not naturally available in standard blood agar. 
  • In the setup shown, Staphylococcus releases V factor (NAD) as it grows, enabling H. influenzae to grow nearby. 
  • This phenomenon is known as satellitism, where H. influenzae colonies form in proximity to other bacteria that provide essential growth factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. X factor: Incorrect. X factor, or hemin, is required by H. influenzae but is available in blood agar itself. However, without the presence of V factor, H. influenzae cannot grow independently on blood agar.

 

Option C. PRP antigen: Incorrect. PRP (polyribosyl ribitol phosphate) is a component of the H. influenzae type b capsule, not a growth factor necessary for the organism’s survival in culture.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect. Only V factor (NAD) is responsible for the satellitism effect seen in the image, as it is provided by the Staphylococcus streak on the plate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The satellitism phenomenon observed in Haemophilus influenzae cultures on blood agar is due to V factor (NAD), which is released by adjacent bacterial colonies, enabling H. influenzae growth in their vicinity.

questions.text:
Match the following fundus appearances with their corresponding conditions:

 

Column A: (Fundus Appearances)

  1. Tomato splash fundus appearance
  2. Berlin’s edema
  3. Cattle tracking fundus appearance
  4. Bull’s eye maculopathy

 

Column B:

  1. CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion)
  2. Ischemic CRVO (Central Retinal Vein Occlusion)
  3. Stargardt’s disease
  4. Cherry red spot at macula
questions.solution:
Ans. A) I – B, II – D, III – A, IV – C

 

I-B. Tomato splash fundus appearance is associated with Ischemic CRVO (Central Retinal Vein Occlusion), characterized by extensive retinal hemorrhages that give the fundus a “tomato splash” look.

 

II-D. Berlin’s edema commonly presents with a cherry red spot at the macula following blunt trauma, due to retinal whitening with a preserved foveal color.

 

III-A. Cattle tracking fundus appearance is typically seen in CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion), where the segmented retinal vessels resemble "cattle tracks."

 

IV-C. Bull’s eye maculopathy is characteristic of Stargardt’s disease, where macular atrophy leads to a bull’s-eye pattern on fundus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • I-B. Tomato splash: Ischemic CRVO
  • II-D. Berlin’s edema: Cherry red spot at macula
  • III-A. Cattle tracking: CRAO
  • IV-C. Bull’s eye maculopathy: Stargardt’s disease

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with symptoms including irritability, depression, and anemia. Blood work indicates a deficiency in pyridoxine (vitamin B6). Which of the following enzymes is likely to have reduced catalytic activity as a result of this deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alanine aminotransferase

 

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is an enzyme that plays a critical role in amino acid metabolism by catalyzing the transfer of an amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate. This process requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6, as a cofactor. In cases of vitamin B6 deficiency, ALT activity is compromised because PLP is essential for the enzyme's function. Vitamin B6 deficiency thus affects amino acid metabolism and can lead to neurological and hematological symptoms due to impaired synthesis of neurotransmitters and heme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutaminase: Glutaminase converts glutamine to glutamate and ammonia, which is important in renal ammonia production. However, this enzyme does not require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a cofactor and is therefore not directly affected by a deficiency in vitamin B6.

 

Option B. Glutamate dehydrogenase: Glutamate dehydrogenase catalyzes the reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate and ammonia. This enzyme uses NAD+ or NADP+ as cofactors but does not depend on pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), making it unaffected by vitamin B6 deficiency.

 

Option D. Glutamine synthetase: Glutamine synthetase catalyzes the conversion of glutamate and ammonia to glutamine. It requires ATP but does not use pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a cofactor, so its activity is not impacted by a lack of vitamin B6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is dependent on pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6, for its catalytic activity. 
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency impairs enzymes that rely on PLP, which disrupts amino acid metabolism and can lead to neurological and hematological symptoms.

Ans. B) Phoropter

 

  • The instrument in the image is a Phoropter, which is used in subjective refraction to measure the refractive error of a patient's eyes. 
  • It has multiple lenses that the examiner can switch between to help the patient achieve the clearest vision, thus determining the proper prescription for corrective lenses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auto-Refractor: This instrument measures refractive error automatically without input from the patient but does not involve manual lens changes as in the Phoropter.

 

 

Option C. Keratometer: A keratometer measures the curvature of the cornea, typically used for fitting contact lenses, not for determining lens prescriptions.

 

 

Option D. Lensometer: A lensometer verifies the prescription of existing lenses, such as in glasses, rather than determining the prescription.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A phoropter is a key tool in optometry and ophthalmology for determining a patient’s refractive error and is essential in prescribing corrective lenses.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 6-mm basal cell carcinoma on the tip of his nose. He is scheduled to undergo excision of the tumor in the operating room with repair of the defect using skin and subcutaneous tissue from his earlobe. Which of the following terms most appropriately describes this form of reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Composite graft

 

  • A composite tissue graft contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis. 
  • Depending on the donor site, it can contain subcutaneous fat, cartilage, and even muscle. 
  • This makes it ideal for deeper defects in which a partial-thickness or full-thickness skin graft would give a poor cosmetic outcome. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A and B. Free flap and Pedicle flap A flap is a vascularized piece of tissue that is mobilized from its original site to another location. A free tissue flap involves severing the original blood supply with anastomosis to blood vessels in the recipient site. The remaining defect in this patient is too small to warrant the need for a flap.

 

Option C. Full-thickness graft: Full thickness graft involves using epidermis and dermis, but not subcutaneous tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Tissue where dermis + subcutaneous tissue is used directly (without blood supply) is a composite graft.
